{"code":1,"isDone":false,"toInsertArticleList":[{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:26:48","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:26:48","title":"What is a Media Kit — and How to Make One [+ Press Kit Examples]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/media-kit-examples","description":"<p>Your competitor releases a new product or service. You offer something similar — but, of course, much better.</p>  \n<p>Then, suddenly, your competitor's product is <em>everywhere</em>. News articles, online reviews, best-of lists, buyers' guides, even TV segments.</p> \n<p>How is this happening? And your real question: why isn't it happening to <em>you</em>?</p> \n<p>To compete against your competitors, there's one thing you'll need in your wheelhouse: a media kit.</p> \n<p>Here, we'll explore what a media kit is, and how it can help you increase brand awareness and, ultimately, sales.</p> \n<p>Plus, how to make one for your own brand.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=0adc0556-31bd-4bf1-924b-6a0e48a4bedb&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download Now: Free Media Kit Template\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/0adc0556-31bd-4bf1-924b-6a0e48a4bedb.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p>Media kits may live fully-online as responsive online <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/agency/perfect-press-page\"><span>press pages</span></a>. Or, businesses may choose to make their press kits available as static, downloadable resources, like a presentation deck.</p> \n<p>Whatever format you choose, this much is clear: businesses of all sizes benefit from having a professional, readily-accessible media kit. This vital resource is a key to the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-earned-media-faqs\"><span>earned media coverage</span></a> all businesses covet — from massive Fortune 500 corporations all the way down to individual influencers and solopreneurs.</p> \n<p>A comprehensive media kit should include a description of the company or individual, contact information, social media statistics, case studies, information on partnerships and collaborations, and testimonials from past customers.</p> \n<p>Basically, it's all the information a journalist would need to feature your brand in a breaking news story — without the headache of a last-minute information request.</p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">How to Make a Media Kit: What to Include</h2> \n<p>So, you want press coverage and partnerships (what brand doesn't?). And you understand how a media kit helps make this all possible. But how do you <em>make</em> a media kit?</p> \n<p>Here's some good news: most of the content and creative assets you need to create your press kit likely already exist.</p> \n<p>Key elements of a media kit include a bio or About Us page, social media statistics, case studies, partnerships and collaborations, and testimonials. To make it even easier for the press to cover your work, you'll want to include high-quality brand identity images (think both logos, and other brand images or product/service images).</p> \n<p>It's up to you to (1) find this information, (2) make it look spectacular, and (3) make it painfully easy to find on your site. The rumors you've heard about journalists and how overworked they are? Entirely true.</p> \n<p>To catch the attention of someone on tight deadlines with an internet full of story prospects, you're going to want to make this simple. Most brands choose a direct page name like \"Press\" or \"Media\" –– or, if they're really fancy, \"Newsroom\" –– and make it accessible directly from their homepage (often in the Footer).</p> \n<p>Even if you prioritize a web version, having a downloadable media kit or deck is worth the time investment. Some media users might prefer the traditional form of this resource, and it gives you the best opportunity to control your pitch and tailor content to all audiences.</p> \n<h3>Biography or About Us</h3> \n<p>Let's start with the star of your media kit: <em>you</em>. Here's where you introduce your name, your logo, your mission. Make sure your media kit design reinforces your overall brand identity, utilizing the colors, fonts, and other visual hallmarks set out in your branding guide.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://evernote.com/about-us\"><span>Evernote</span></a> goes all-out in this section, housing their press kit information within the broader \"About Us\" portion of their website. All the essentials for journalists and partners are there too, but the organization's values take center stage.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Media%20Kit_Evernote-min.png?width=1205&amp;name=Media%20Kit_Evernote-min.png\" alt=\"Evernote's media kit homepage\" width=\"1205\" style=\"width: 1205px;\"></p> \n<h3>Social Statistics</h3> \n<p>For social stats, you'll need to conduct a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/customers/check-pulse-digital-strategy-social-media-audit\"><span>social media audit</span></a> or collect this data from whoever manages your social channels. Remember your audience for the press kit: media and PR professionals.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>Your media kit needs to effectively pitch your brand to people who specialize in getting people's attention. So show them you're capable of sparking conversation — and show them there's <em>already</em> an audience eager for stories about you and your work.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.kickstarter.com/help/brand_assets\"><span>Kickstarter</span></a> puts a unique stamp on this section of their media kit page, highlighting a few top metrics that show massive engagement with their service.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Media%20Kit_Kickstarter-min.png?width=2138&amp;name=Media%20Kit_Kickstarter-min.png\" alt=\"Kickstarter's media kit social media statistics\" width=\"2138\" style=\"width: 2138px;\"></p> \n<p>Media kits aimed at partnerships and collaborations should prioritize <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/vanity-metrics-to-stop-measuring-and-better-alternatives\"><span>engagement rates and similar actionable metrics</span></a> alongside the bread-and-butter statistics like follower counts. Savvy marketers want to partner with brands and influencers that move people to action.</p> \n<p>[Note: If you are a HubSpot Social user, you can use <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/social-media-user-guide-v2/how-to-use-the-social-reports-tool\"><span>Reports</span></a> to analyze the performance of your social posts and determine how well your social media efforts are performing.]</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Partnerships and Case Studies</h3> \n<p>This section is your chance to let past partnerships and brand collaborations speak for themselves. Let the old adage \"<em>show; don't tell</em>\" be your guide here. Featuring the right partnerships –– either via logos or through short case studies –– is a subtle but powerful tool for positioning your brand.</p> \n<p>International football influencers <a href=\"http://thef2.com/campaigns/\"><span>The F2</span></a> highlight past campaigns, putting reputable brand names and logos front-and-center. They also note key engagement statistics for these campaigns</p> \n<h3><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Media%20Kit_TheF2%20Influencer%20Campaigns%20MLS-min.png?width=1318&amp;name=Media%20Kit_TheF2%20Influencer%20Campaigns%20MLS-min.png\" alt=\"F2's media kit homepage\" width=\"1318\" style=\"width: 1318px;\"></h3> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Testimonials</h3> \n<p>Testimonials are another great way to <em>show</em> media professionals the impact and effectiveness of your brand or product.</p> \n<p>Keep this section succinct: just a single testimonial should suffice. Only a few lines of text (even just a single short quote) and a single related image gets the point across, lending your pitch greater credibility thanks to <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/jaysondemers/2015/02/19/the-importance-of-social-validation-in-online-marketing/#50f51463364d\"><span>social validation</span></a>.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://briogeohair.com/pages/press\"><span>Briogeo</span></a> does a fantastic job highlighting testimonials on its Press &amp; Buzz page, right below the rewards section for easy access:<br><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/briogeo.png?width=1388&amp;name=briogeo.png\" alt=\"briogeo's media kit homepage with testimonials\" width=\"1388\" style=\"width: 1388px;\"></p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Visual Assets (Downloadables)</h3> \n<p>Your media kit isn't a style guide, but it should pull in the most essential elements of your visual brand. Want your logo and that slick product screenshot to display correctly?</p> \n<p>Provide exactly the images and files you want featured. Have a killer data visualization, infographic, or product video? Include that, too.</p> \n<p>Journalists will especially appreciate portraits of your management team. They're most likely to cover stories involving people, so show them the people they'll want to write about.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.birchbox.com/press/news\"><span>Birchbox</span></a> makes this easy. They highlight \"Press Materials\" and link to a short but comprehensive set of resources. Having everything in well-organized cloud folders is a nice touch –– especially for those browsing on mobile.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/HkoNrtUC4K3mBp4EB3E9XjtDt0rxF9XvAI3jHPHpVBNd8KLmbSTOaAMxdjuKs7_8SOaeSlxyN3PoIjhGfMUbsLwWgoLm0YSNjiCo3_pimDHDQ4nQ-st0Dszh1DE1E4RECkDWh1Ec\" width=\"672\" height=\"277\" alt=\"birchbox's media kit homepage\"></p> \n<p>Without downloading or unzipping a large batch of images, visitors can quickly confirm you have visual assets to make their publication look good. Remember, the audience for your media kit is especially busy and juggling lots of competing priorities. Jump to the top of their \"potential posts\" pile by making their job as easy and painless as possible.</p> \n<p>(Added bonus: your external media resources are easily updated –– sparing you anxiety about outdated media kits and image files misrepresenting your brand.)</p> \n<h2>Media Kit Design</h2> \n<p>Now that you know what to include in your media kit, you might be wondering how to put all of that valuable information together so that it’s navigable and easy to understand. You’ll do this through a table of contents.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>The way your table of contents looks can vary depending on how you design your media kit. On Slack’s website, its media kit has a table of contents that features summaries of each section with hyperlinks that bring users to a separate page, as shown in the image below.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/slack%20website.jpg?width=1480&amp;name=slack%20website.jpg\" alt=\"slack website media kit table of contents\" width=\"1480\" style=\"width: 1480px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://slack.com/media-kit\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>If you download Slack’s media kit as a PDF, the table of contents lists a page number for each section, so viewers can quickly scroll to the page they need or type the page number into the search bar.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/slack%20image%202.jpeg?width=1650&amp;name=slack%20image%202.jpeg\" alt=\"slack downloadable media kit table of contents\" width=\"1650\" style=\"width: 1650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://slack.com/media-kit\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Regardless of how you present your kit, it needs to be designed for ease of access. Aim to create distinct sections for the content you’re including, and create a form of navigation that helps those making inquiries quickly find what they need.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Let’s go over some high-quality examples of media kits that you can use for inspiration when creating one for your business.&nbsp;</p> \n<h2>Media Kit Examples</h2> \n<h3>1. Hinge</h3> \n<p>Hinge, a dating app, has a straightforward and easy to navigate press kit that gives those doing media inquiries quick access to critical information, like internal press releases:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hinge%20image%201.jpg?width=2642&amp;name=hinge%20image%201.jpg\" alt=\"press kit example: hinge media kit\" width=\"2642\" style=\"width: 2642px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://hinge.co/press/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>As well as external news articles, employee profiles, business background, and image downloads (logo, screenshots, etc.).</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hinge%20image%202.png?width=2752&amp;name=hinge%20image%202.png\" alt=\"press kit example: hinge media kit downloadables\" width=\"2752\" style=\"width: 2752px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://hinge.co/press/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h3>2. Spotify</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://downloads.ctfassets.net/ziwa9xqm84y1/4FeDT9GwCmVOj2k0vyqr5O/f2adf8dc6bd540a310af13ab77812da1/Media_Kit_Q1_2020_-_US.pdf\">Spotify </a>has a unique media kit, namely one that supports one of its key features — Streaming Intelligence. Media and other parties can read through the kit, understand the specifics of the tool, how it works, performance stats, as well as partnerships with notable sources that support its effectiveness.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Spotify shows us that general press kits are great for your business to have, but are also relevant for things like product launches or specific business tools.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>3. Delta Airlines</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://docs.google.com/document/d/1JH0wBgARtMmTUDTNjWa3v5i1dc5UXPCDk5jd-tBRsGA/edit#heading=h.ox66b43gonaq\">Delta Airlines</a>’ press kit is hosted on its website and contains all of the elements you’d expect from one. As it is such a large company, each section of the press kit is on a different site page that users navigate to by clicking a hyperlink.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/delta%20image%201.jpg?width=2502&amp;name=delta%20image%201.jpg\" alt=\"media kit example: delta press kit table of contents\" width=\"2502\" style=\"width: 2502px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://news.delta.com/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>If you click on a link for, say, Awards and Recognitions, you land on a page that features noteworthy recognitions about Delta and the service it offers.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/delta%202.jpg?width=409&amp;name=delta%202.jpg\" alt=\"media kit example: delta press kit statistics\" width=\"409\" style=\"width: 409px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 13px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://news.delta.com/delta-worlds-most-awarded-airline\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Now you know the <em>what </em>and the <em>how </em>of creating a media kit to garner beneficial coverage for your brand. <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/business-templates/media-kit\">Click here to download our free media kit template and get started.</a></p> \n<p>And go ahead, give yourself a pat on the back when that Features story comes out. You won't see your name on the byline, but we both know who the <em>real</em> hero is here.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" Forsey","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/0adc0556-31bd-4bf1-924b-6a0e48a4bedb.png":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Media%20Kit_Evernote-min.png?width=1205&name=Media%20Kit_Evernote-min.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn44@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-26-50-408_648e9bf7f2486016.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Media%20Kit_Kickstarter-min.png?width=2138&name=Media%20Kit_Kickstarter-min.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn60@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-26-54-531_377be23a3cf64496.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Media%20Kit_TheF2%20Influencer%20Campaigns%20MLS-min.png?width=1318&name=Media%20Kit_TheF2%20Influencer%20Campaigns%20MLS-min.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn97@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-26-56-997_773fdee1a0272fc9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/briogeo.png?width=1388&name=briogeo.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn40@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-26-51-033_1d9743a3deefff09.webp","https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/HkoNrtUC4K3mBp4EB3E9XjtDt0rxF9XvAI3jHPHpVBNd8KLmbSTOaAMxdjuKs7_8SOaeSlxyN3PoIjhGfMUbsLwWgoLm0YSNjiCo3_pimDHDQ4nQ-st0Dszh1DE1E4RECkDWh1Ec":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn7@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-26-51-970_d4ef8108887960be.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/slack%20website.jpg?width=1480&name=slack%20website.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn77@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-26-56-173_53edf4e2a1fb40a8.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/slack%20image%202.jpeg?width=1650&name=slack%20image%202.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn79@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-26-56-483_deaf719c6d56a86f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hinge%20image%201.jpg?width=2642&name=hinge%20image%201.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn72@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-26-53-666_ad49f6dfc211d33d.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hinge%20image%202.png?width=2752&name=hinge%20image%202.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn86@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-26-53-544_671e2c04a9159892.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/delta%20image%201.jpg?width=2502&name=delta%20image%201.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn32@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-26-56-295_511ffd558be8f1db.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/delta%202.jpg?width=409&name=delta%202.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn9@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-26-56-163_1a137050696295c1.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/95327e1a-c0a4-4b45-8031-37c8afb9bc1e.png":null,"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmedia-kit-examples&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn64@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-26-56-916_e4f18f292a5341e3.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647246408211},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:26:48","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:26:48","title":"How to Do Market Research: A Guide and Template","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/market-research-buyers-journey-guide","description":"<p>Today's consumers have a lot of power. They can research your product or service and make purchase decisions entirely on their own.</p> \n<p>Moreover, rather than talking to one of your sales reps, they're more likely to ask for referrals from members of their networks or read online reviews.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>With this in mind, have you adapted your marketing strategy to complement the way today's consumers research, shop, and buy?</p> \n<p>To do just that, you must have a deep understanding of who your buyers are, your specific market, and what influences the purchase decisions and behavior of your target audience members.</p> \n<p>Enter: Market Research.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=6ba52ce7-bb69-4b63-965b-4ea21ba905da&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"→ Download Now: Market Research Templates [Free Kit]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/6ba52ce7-bb69-4b63-965b-4ea21ba905da.png\" align=\"middle\" /></a></p> \n<p>Whether you're new to market research, this guide will provide you with a blueprint for conducting a thorough study of your market, target audience, competition, and more.</p> \n<p></p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>What is market research?</h2> \n<p>Market research is the process of gathering information about your target market and customers to verify the success of a new product, help your team iterate on an existing product, or understand brand perception to ensure your team is effectively communicating your company's value effectively.</p> \n<p>Market research can answer various questions about the state of an industry, but it's hardly a crystal ball that marketers can rely on for insights on their customers. Market researchers investigate several areas of the market, and it can take weeks or even months to paint an accurate picture of the business landscape.</p> \n<p>However, researching just one of those areas can make you more intuitive to who your buyers are and how to deliver value that no other business is offering them right now.</p> \n<p>Certainly you can make sound judgment calls based on your experience in the industry and your existing customers. However, keep in mind that market research offers benefits beyond those strategies. There are two things to consider:&nbsp;</p> \n<ol> \n <li><strong>Your competitors also have experienced individuals in the industry and a customer base.</strong><span>&nbsp;</span>It's very possible that your immediate resources are, in many ways, equal to those of your competition's immediate resources. Seeking a larger sample size for answers can provide a better edge.&nbsp;</li> \n <li><strong>Your customers don't represent the attitudes of an entire market.</strong><span>&nbsp;</span>They represent the attitudes of the part of the market that is already drawn to your brand.&nbsp;</li> \n</ol> \n<p>The market research services market is growing rapidly, which signifies a strong interest in market research as we enter 2022. The market is expected to grow from roughly <a href=\"https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2021/11/18/2337641/0/en/The-Market-Research-Services-Market-Adapts-To-Digital-Consumerism-With-The-Impact-Of-COVID-As-Per-The-Business-Research-Company-s-Market-Research-Services-Global-Market-Report-2021.html#:~:text=The%20global%20market%20research%20services%20market%20is%20expected%20to%20grow,(CAGR)%20of%205.3%25.\">$75 billion in 2021 to $90.79 billion in 2025</a> at a compound annual growth rate of 5%.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>Why do market research?</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/market-research-definition\">Market research</a> allows you to meet your buyer where they are. As our world (both digital and analog) becomes louder and demands more and more of our attention, this proves invaluable. By understanding your buyer's problems, pain points, and desired solutions, you can aptly craft your product or service to naturally appeal to them.</p> \n<p>Market research also provides insight into a <em>wide</em> variety of things that impact your bottom line, including:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Where your target audience and current customers conduct their product or service research</li> \n <li>Which of your competitors your target audience looks to for information, options, or purchases</li> \n <li>What's trending in your industry and in the eyes of your buyer</li> \n <li>Who makes up your market and what their challenges are</li> \n <li>What influences purchases and conversions among your target audience&nbsp;</li> \n <li>Consumer attitudes about a particular topic, pain, product, or brand</li> \n <li>Whether there's demand for the business initiatives you're investing in</li> \n <li>Unaddressed or underserved customer needs that can be flipped into selling opportunity</li> \n <li>Attitudes about pricing for a particular product or service</li> \n</ul> \n<div> \n <div> \n  <div> \n   <p>Ultimately, market research allows you to get information from a larger sample size of your target audience, eliminating bias and assumptions so that you can get to the heart of consumer attitudes. As a result, you can make better business decisions from knowing the bigger picture.</p> \n  </div> \n </div> \n</div> \n<p></p> \n<p>As you begin honing in on your market research, you'll likely hear about primary and secondary market research. The easiest way to think about primary and secondary research is to envision to umbrellas sitting beneath market research: one for primary market research and one for secondary market research.</p> \n<p>Beneath these two umbrellas sits a number of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/market-research-buyers-journey-guide#types-of-market-research\">different types of market research, which we'll highlight below</a>. Defining which of the two umbrellas your market research fits beneath isn't necessarily crucial, although some marketers prefer to make the distinction.</p> \n<p>So, in case you encounter a marketer who wants to define your types of market research as primary or secondary — or if you're one of them — let's cover the definitions of the two categories next. Then, we'll look at the different <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/market-research-buyers-journey-guide#types-of-market-research\">types of market research in the following section</a>.&nbsp;</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Primary vs. Secondary Research</h2> \n<p>To give you an idea of how extensive market research can get, consider that it can either be<span>&nbsp;</span><strong>qualitative</strong><span>&nbsp;</span>or<span>&nbsp;</span><strong>quantitative</strong><span>&nbsp;</span>in nature — depending on the studies you conduct and what you're trying to learn about your industry.</p> \n<p>Qualitative research is concerned with public opinion, and explores how the market feels about the products currently available in that market. Quantitative research is concerned with data, and looks for relevant trends in the information that's gathered from public records.</p> \n<p>There are two main types of market research that your business can conduct to collect actionable information on your products, including primary research and secondary research. Let's dive into those two types, now.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>Primary Research</h3> \n<p>Primary research is the pursuit of first-hand information about your market and the customers within your market. It's&nbsp;useful when <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/customer-segmentation\">segmenting</a> your market and establishing your buyer personas. Primary market research tends to fall into one of two buckets: exploratory and specific research.</p> \n<h4>Exploratory Primary Research</h4> \n<p>This kind of primary market research is less concerned with measurable customer trends and more about potential problems that would be worth tackling as a team. It normally takes place as a first step — before any specific research has been performed — and may involve open-ended interviews or surveys with small numbers of people.</p> \n<h4>Specific Primary Research</h4> \n<p>Specific primary market research often follows exploratory research and is used to dive into issues or opportunities the business has already identified as important. In specific research, the business can take a smaller or more precise segment of their audience and ask questions aimed at solving a suspected problem.</p> \n<h3>Secondary Research</h3> \n<p>Secondary research is all the data and public records you have at your disposal to draw conclusions from (e.g. trend reports, market statistics, industry content, and sales data you already have on your business). Secondary research is particularly useful for <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/competitive-analysis-kit\">analyzing your competitors</a>. The main buckets your secondary market research will fall into include:</p> \n<h4><strong>Public Sources</strong></h4> \n<p>These sources are your first and most-accessible layer of material when conducting secondary market research. They're often free to find and review — lots of bang for your buck here.</p> \n<p>Government statistics are one of the most common types of public sources according to <a href=\"https://www.entrepreneur.com/encyclopedia/secondary-market-research\">Entrepreneur.</a> Two U.S. examples of public market data are the <a href=\"https://www.census.gov/\">U.S. Census Bureau</a> and the <a href=\"https://www.bls.gov/\">Bureau of Labor &amp; Statistics</a>, both of which offer helpful information on the state of various industries nationwide.</p> \n<h4><strong>Commercial Sources</strong></h4> \n<p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">These sources often come in the form of market reports, consisting of industry insight compiled by a research agency like <a href=\"https://www.pewresearch.org/\">Pew</a>, <a href=\"https://www.gartner.com/en\">Gartner</a>, or <a href=\"https://go.forrester.com/\">Forrester</a>. Because this info is so portable and distributable, it typically costs money to download and obtain.</span></p> \n<h4><strong>Internal Sources</strong></h4> \n<p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Internal sources deserve more credit for supporting market research than they generally get. Why? This is the market data your organization already has! </span></p> \n<p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Average revenue per sale, customer retention rates, and other historical data on the health of old and new accounts can all help you draw conclusions on what your buyers might want right now.</span></p> \n<p>Now that we've covered these overarching market research categories, let's get more specific and look at the various types of market research you might choose to conduct.&nbsp;</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>1. Interviews</h3> \n<p>Interviews allow for face-to-face discussions (in-person and virtual) so you can allow for a natural flow or conversation and watch your interviewee's body language while doing so.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Your interviewees can answer questions about themselves to help you design your buyer personas. These buyer personas describe your ideal customer's age, family size, budget, job title, the challenges they face at work, and similar aspects of their lifestyle. Having this buyer profile in hand can shape your entire marketing strategy, from the features you add to your product to the content you publish on your website.</p> \n<h3>2. Focus Groups</h3> \n<p>Focus groups provide you with a handful of carefully-selected people that you can have test out your product, watch a demo, provide feedback, and/or answer specific questions.</p> \n<p>This type of market research can give you ideas for product differentiation, or the qualities of your product that make it unique in the marketplace. Consider asking your focus group questions about (and showing them examples of) your services, and ultimately use the group's feedback to make these services better.</p> \n<h3>3. Product/Service Use Research</h3> \n<p>Product or service use research offers insight into how and why your audience uses your product or service, and specific features of that item. This type of market research also gives you an idea of the product or service's <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/usability-testing\">usability</a> for your target audience.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>In a <a href=\"https://www.uxmatters.com/mt/archives/2020/08/user-fountains-2020-usability-testing-industry-report.php\">2020 report</a>, respondents rated usability testing most highly in terms of usefulness for discovering user insights (rating it 8.7 out of 10). By comparison, digital analytics was rated 7.7, and user surveys 6.4.</p> \n<h3>4. Observation-Based Research</h3> \n<p>Observation-based research allows you to sit back and watch the ways in which your target audience members go about using your product or service, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/qualitative-research-methods\">what works well in terms of UX</a>, what roadblocks they hit, and which aspects of it could be easier for them to use and apply.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>5. Buyer Persona Research</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/buyer-persona-research\">Buyer persona research</a> gives you a realistic look at who makes up your target audience, what their challenges are, why they want your product or service, what they need from your business and brand, and more.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>6. Market Segmentation Research</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/customers/how-to-segment-and-nurture-your-customers-with-hubspot\">Market segmentation</a> research allows you to categorize your target audience into different groups (or segments) based on specific and defining characteristics — this way, you can determine effective ways to meet their needs, understand their pain points and expectations, learn about their goals, and more.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>7. Pricing Research</h3> \n<p>Pricing research gives you an idea of what similar products or services in your market sell for, what your target audience expects to pay — and is willing to pay — for whatever it is you sell, and what's a fair price for you to list your product or service at. All of this information will help you define your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/pricing-strategy\">pricing strategy</a>.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>8. Competitive Analysis</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/competitive-analysis-kit\">Competitive analyses</a> are valuable because they give you a deep understanding of the competition in your market and industry. You can learn about what's doing well in your industry, what your target audience is already going for in terms of products like yours, which of your competitors should you work to keep up with and surpass, and how you can clearly <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/competitor-analysis-guide\">separate yourself from the competition</a>.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>9. Customer Satisfaction and Loyalty Research</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/what-is-customer-satisfaction\">Customer satisfaction</a> and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/customer-loyalty\">loyalty</a> research give you a look into how you can get current customers to return for more business and what will motivate them to do so (e.g. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/customer-loyalty-program\">loyalty programs</a>, rewards, remarkable customer service). This research will help you discover the most-effective ways to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/customer-delight\">promote delight among your customers</a>.</p> \n<h3>10. Brand Awareness Research</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/brand-awareness\">Brand awareness</a> research tells you about what your target audience knows about and recognizes from your brand. It tells you about the associations your audience members make when they think about your business and what they believe you're all about.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>11. Campaign Research</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/marketing-campaigns\">Campaign</a> research entails looking into your past campaigns and analyzing their success among your target audience and current customers. It requires experimentation and then a deep dive into what reached and resonated with your audience so you can keep those elements in mind for your future campaigns and hone in on the aspects of what you do that matters most to those people.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Now that you know about the categories and types of market research, let's review how you can <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/market-research-buyers-journey-guide\">conduct your market research</a>.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p>Here's how to do market research step-by-step. </p> \n<div> \n <div> \n  <h3>1. Define your buyer persona.</h3> \n </div> \n <div> \n  <div> \n   <p>Before you dive into <em>how</em> customers in your industry make buying decisions, you must first understand <em>who</em> they are.</p> \n   <p>This is where your buyer personas come in handy. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/buyer-persona-definition-under-100-sr\">Buyer personas</a> — sometimes referred to as marketing personas — are fictional, generalized representations of your ideal customers.</p> \n   <p><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/make-my-persona?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase\"><em>Use a free tool to create a buyer persona that your entire company can use to market, sell, and serve better.</em></a></p> \n   <p><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/make-my-persona?hubs_post-cta=image\"><img alt=\"How to do market research defining your buyer persona\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/define-your-buyer-persona.png?width=1500&amp;name=define-your-buyer-persona.png\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 1500px;\" width=\"1500\" /></a></p> \n   <p>They help you visualize your audience, streamline your communications, and inform your strategy. Some key characteristics you should be keen on including in your buyer persona are:</p> \n   <ul> \n    <li>Age</li> \n    <li>Gender</li> \n    <li>Location</li> \n    <li>Job title(s)</li> \n    <li>Job titles</li> \n    <li>Family size</li> \n    <li>Income</li> \n    <li>Major challenges</li> \n   </ul> \n   <p>The idea is to use your persona as a guideline for&nbsp; how to effectively reach and learn about the real audience members in your industry. Also, you may find that your business lends itself to more than one persona — that's fine! You just need to be&nbsp; thoughtful about each specific persona when you're optimizing and planning your content and campaigns.</p> \n   <p>To get started with creating your personas, check out these <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/persona-templates\">free templates</a>, as well as <a href=\"http://makemypersona.com/\">this helpful tool.</a>&nbsp;</p> \n  </div> \n </div> \n</div> \n<div> \n <div> \n  <h3>2. Identify a persona group to engage.</h3> \n </div> \n <div> \n  <p>Now that you know who your buyer personas are, use that information to help you identify a group to engage to conduct your market research with — this should be a representative sample of your target customers so you can better understand their actual characteristics, challenges, and buying habits.</p> \n  <p>The group you identify to engage should also be made of people who recently made a purchase or purposefully decided not to make one. Here are some more guidelines and tips to help you get the right participants for your research.&nbsp;</p> \n  <h4>How to Identify the Right People to Engage for Market Research</h4> \n  <p>When choosing who to engage for your market research, start by focusing on people who have the characteristics that apply to your buyer persona. You should also:</p> Aim for 10 participants per buyer persona. \n  <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">We recommend focusing on one persona, but if you feel it's necessary to research multiple personas, be sure to recruit a separate sample group for each one.</span></p> \n  <h6><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">Select people who have recently interacted with you.</span></h6> \n  <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\">You may want to focus on people that have completed an evaluation within the past six months — or up to a year if you have a longer sales cycle or niche market. You'll be asking very detailed questions so it's important that their experience is fresh.</span></p> \n  <h6>Gather a mix of participants.</h6> \n  <p style=\"font-weight: normal;\"><span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem;\">You want to recruit people who have purchased your product, purchased a competitor's product, and decided not to purchase anything at all. While your customers will be the easiest to find and recruit, sourcing information from those who aren't customers (yet!) will help you develop a balanced view of your market.&nbsp;</span></p> Here are some more details on how to select this mix of participants: \n  <ul> \n   <li><strong>Pull a list of customers who made a recent purchase. </strong><span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; font-weight: 400;\">As we mentioned before, this is usually the easiest set of buyers to recruit. If you're using a CRM system, you can run a report of deals that closed within the past six months and filter it for the characteristics you're looking for. Otherwise, you can work with your sales team to get a list of appropriate accounts from them.</span></li> \n   <li><span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Pull a list of customers who were in an active evaluation, but didn't make a purchase.</strong> You should get a mix of buyers who either purchased from a competitor or decided not to make a purchase. Again, you can get this list from your CRM or from whatever system your Sales team uses to track deals.</span></li> \n   <li><span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Call for participants on social media.</strong> Try reaching out to the folks that follow you on social media, but decided not to buy from you. There's a chance that some of them will be willing to talk to you and tell you why they ultimately decided not to buy your product.</span></li> \n   <li><span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Leverage your own network.</strong> Get the word out to your coworkers, former colleagues, and LinkedIn connections that you're conducting a study. Even if your direct connections don't qualify, some of them will likely have a coworker, friend, or family member who does.</span></li> \n   <li><span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Choose an incentive.</strong> </span><span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; font-weight: 400;\">Time is precious, so you'll need to think about how you will motivate someone to spend 30-45 minutes on you and your study. On a tight budget? You can reward participants for free by giving them exclusive access to content. Another option? Send a simple handwritten 'thank you' note once the study is complete.</span>&nbsp;</li> \n  </ul> \n </div> \n</div> \n<div> \n <div> \n  <h3>3. Prepare research questions for your market research participants.</h3> \n </div> \n <div> \n  <div> \n   <p>The best way to make sure you get the most out of your conversations is to be prepared. You should always create a discussion guide — whether it's for a focus group, online survey, or a phone interview — to make sure you cover all of the top-of-mind questions and use your time wisely.</p> \n   <p>(Note: This is not intended to be a script. The discussions should be natural and conversational, so we encourage you to go out of order or probe into certain areas as you see fit.)</p> \n   <p>Your discussion guide should be in an outline format, with a time allotment and open-ended questions for each section.</p> \n   <p><em>Wait, all open-ended questions? </em></p> \n   <p>Yes — this is a golden rule of market research. You never want to \"lead the witness\" by asking yes and no questions, as that puts you at risk of unintentionally swaying their thoughts by leading with your own hypothesis. Asking open-ended questions also helps you avoid one-word answers (which aren't very helpful for you).</p> \n   <h4>Example Outline of a 30-Minute Survey&nbsp;</h4> \n   <p>Here's a general outline for a 30-minute survey for one B2B buyer. You can use these as talking points for an in-person interview, or as questions posed on a digital form to administer as a survey to your target customers.</p> \n   <h5>Background Information (5 Minutes)</h5> \n   <p>Ask the buyer to give you a little background information (their title, how long they've been with the company, and so on). Then, ask a fun/easy question to warm things up (first concert attended, favorite restaurant in town, last vacation, etc.).</p> \n   <p>Remember, you want to get to know your buyers in pretty specific ways. You might be able to capture basic information such as age, location, and job title from your contact list, there are some personal and professional challenges you can really only learn by asking.</p> \n   <p>Here are some other key background questions to ask your target audience:</p> \n   <ul> \n    <li>Describe how your team is structured.</li> \n    <li>Tell me about your personal job responsibilities.</li> \n    <li>What are the team's goals and how do you measure them?</li> \n    <li>What has been your biggest challenge in the past year?</li> \n   </ul> \n   <p>Now, make a transition to acknowledge the specific purchase or interaction they made that led to you including them in the study. The next three <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/what-is-the-buyers-journey\">stages of the buyer's journey</a> will focus specifically on that purchase.</p> \n   <h5>Awareness (5 Minutes)</h5> \n   <p>Here, you want to understand how they first realized they had a problem that needed to be solved without getting into whether or not they knew about your brand yet.</p> \n   <ul> \n    <li>Think back to when you first realized you needed a [name the product/service category, but not yours specifically]. What challenges were you facing at the time?</li> \n    <li>How did you know that something in this category could help you?</li> \n    <li>How familiar were you with different options on the market?</li> \n   </ul> \n   <h4>Consideration (10 Minutes)</h4> \n   <p>Now you want to get very specific about how and where the buyer researched potential solutions. Plan to interject to ask for more details.</p> \n   <ul> \n    <li>What was the first thing you did to research potential solutions? How helpful was this source?</li> \n    <li>Where did you go to find more information?</li> \n   </ul> \n   <p>If they don't come up organically, ask about search engines, websites visited, people consulted, and so on. Probe, as appropriate, with some of the following questions:</p> \n   <ul> \n    <li>How did you find that source?</li> \n    <li>How did you use vendor websites?</li> \n    <li>What words specifically did you search on Google?</li> \n    <li>How helpful was it? How could it be better?</li> \n    <li>Who provided the most (and least) helpful information? What did that look like?</li> \n    <li>Tell me about your experiences with the sales people from each vendor.</li> \n   </ul> \n   <h5>Decision (10 Minutes)</h5> \n   <ul> \n    <li>Which of the sources you described above was the most influential in driving your decision?</li> \n    <li>What, if any, criteria did you establish to compare the alternatives?</li> \n    <li>What vendors made it to the short list and what were the pros/cons of each?</li> \n    <li>Who else was involved in the final decision? What role did each of these people play?</li> \n    <li>What factors ultimately influenced your final purchasing decision?</li> \n   </ul> \n   <h5>Closing</h5> \n   <p>Here, you want to wrap up and understand what could have been better for the buyer.</p> \n   <ul> \n    <li>Ask them what their ideal buying process would look like. How would it differ from what they experienced?</li> \n    <li>Allow time for further questions on their end.</li> \n    <li>Don't forget to thank them for their time and confirm their address to send a thank-you note or incentive.</li> \n   </ul> \n  </div> \n </div> \n</div> \n<div> \n <div> \n  <h3>4. List your primary competitors.</h3> \n </div> \n <div> \n  <div> \n   <p>List your primary competitors — keep in mind listing the competition isn't always as simple as Company X versus Company Y.</p> \n   <p>Sometimes, a <em>division</em> of a company might compete with your main product or service, even though that company's brand might put more effort in another area.</p> \n   <p>For example. Apple is known for its laptops and mobile devices but Apple Music competes with Spotify over its music streaming service.</p> \n   <p>From a content standpoint, you might compete with a blog, YouTube channel, or similar publication for inbound website visitors — even though their products don't overlap with yours at all.</p> \n   <p>And a toothpaste company might compete with magazines like Health.com or Prevention on certain <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/blog-topic-generator\">blog topics</a> related to health and hygiene even though the magazines don't actually sell oral care products.</p> \n   <h4>Identifying Industry Competitors</h4> \n   <p>To identify competitors whose products or services overlap with yours, determine which industry or industries you're pursuing. Start high-level, using terms like education, construction, media &amp; entertainment, food service, healthcare, retail, financial services, telecommunications, and agriculture.</p> \n   <p>The list goes on, but find an industry term that you identify with, and use it to create a list of companies that also belong to this industry. You can build your list the following ways:</p> \n   <ul> \n    <li><strong>Review your industry quadrant on G2 Crowd:</strong>&nbsp;In certain industries, this is your best first step in secondary market research. <a href=\"https://www.g2crowd.com/categories/\">G2 Crowd</a> aggregates user ratings and social data to create \"quadrants,\" where you can see companies plotted as contenders, leaders, niche, and high performers in their respective industries. G2 Crowd specializes in digital content, IT services, HR, ecommerce, and related business services.</li> \n    <li><strong>Download a market report:</strong>&nbsp;Companies like Forrester and Gartner offer both free and gated market forecasts every year on the vendors who are leading their industry. On Forrester's website, for example, you can select \"Latest Research\" from the navigation bar and browse <a href=\"https://go.forrester.com/\">Forrester's</a> latest material using a variety of criteria to narrow your search. These reports are good assets to save on your computer.</li> \n    <li><strong>Search using social media:</strong>&nbsp;Believe it or not, social networks make great company directories if you use the search bar correctly. On LinkedIn, for example, select the search bar and enter the name of the industry you're pursuing. Then, under \"More,\" select \"Companies\" to narrow your results to just the businesses that include this or a similar industry term on their LinkedIn profile.</li> \n   </ul> \n   <h4>Identifying Content Competitors</h4> \n   <p>Search engines are your best friends in this area of secondary market research. To find the online publications with which you compete, take the overarching industry term you identified in the section above, and come up with a handful of more specific industry terms your company identifies with.</p> \n   <p>A catering business, for example, might generally be a \"food service\" company, but also consider itself a vendor in \"event catering,\" \"cake catering,\" \"baked goods,\" and more.</p> \n   <p>Once you have this list, do the following:</p> \n   <ul> \n    <li><strong>Google it:</strong>&nbsp;Don't underestimate the value in seeing which websites come up when you run a search on Google for the industry terms that describe your company. You might find a mix of product developers, blogs, magazines, and more.</li> \n    <li><strong>Compare your search results against your buyer persona:</strong>&nbsp;Remember the buyer persona you created during the <em>primary research</em> stage, earlier in this article? Use it to examine how likely a publication you found through Google could steal website traffic from you. If the content the website publishes seems like the stuff your buyer persona would want to see, it's a potential competitor, and should be added to your list of competitors.</li> \n   </ul> \n   <p>After a series of similar Google searches for the industry terms you identify with, look for repetition in the website domains that have come up.</p> \n   <p>Examine the first two or three results pages for each search you conducted. These websites are clearly respected for the content they create in your industry, and should be watched carefully as you build your own library of videos, reports, web pages, and blog posts.</p> \n  </div> \n </div> \n</div> \n<div> \n <div> \n  <h3>5. Summarize your findings.</h3> \n </div> \n <p>Feeling overwhelmed by the notes you took? We suggest looking for common themes that will help you tell a story and create a list of action items.</p> \n <p>To make the process easier, try using your favorite presentation software to make a report, as it will make it easy to add in quotes, diagrams, or call clips.</p> \n <p>Feel free to add your own flair, but the following outline should help you craft a clear summary:</p> \n <ul> \n  <li><strong>Background: </strong>Your goals and why you conducted this study.</li> \n  <li><strong>Participants: </strong>Who you talked to. A table works well so you can break groups down by persona and customer/prospect.</li> \n  <li><strong><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/executive-summary-examples\">Executive Summary</a>:</strong>&nbsp;What were the most interesting things you learned? What do you plan to do about it?</li> \n  <li><strong>Awareness:</strong> Describe the common triggers that lead someone to enter into an evaluation. (Quotes can be very powerful.)</li> \n  <li><strong>Consideration:</strong>&nbsp;Provide the main themes you uncovered, as well as the detailed sources buyers use when conducting their evaluation.</li> \n  <li><strong>Decision:</strong>&nbsp;Paint the picture of how a decision is <em>really</em> made by including the people at the center of influence and any product features or information that can make or break a deal.</li> \n  <li><strong>Action Plan:</strong>&nbsp;Your analysis probably uncovered a few campaigns you can run to get your brand in front of buyers earlier and/or more effectively. Provide your list of priorities, a timeline, and the impact it will have on your business.</li> \n </ul> Lastly, let's review a resource that can help you compile everything we just discussed in a simple yet effective way (plus, it's free!). \n <br> <a></a> <h2>Market Research Report Template</h2> <p>Within a market research kit, there are a number of critical pieces of information for your business's success. Let's take a look at what those different kit elements are next.&nbsp;</p> <p><em>Pro Tip</em>: Upon downloading <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/market-research-kit\">HubSpot's <em>free</em> Market Research Kit</a>, you'll receive editable templates for each of the given parts of the kit as well as instructions on how to use the templates and kit, and a mock presentation that you can edit and customize.&nbsp;</p> <p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/market-research-kit?hubs_post-cta=image&amp;_ga=2.130465743.1110463319.1643300632-1761376280.1643300632\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202021-03-29%20at%202.23.58%20PM.png?width=596&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202021-03-29%20at%202.23.58%20PM.png\" alt=\"market research kit and templates from HubSpot\" width=\"596\" style=\"width: 596px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></a></p> <p style=\"text-align: left;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/market-research-kit?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase\"><em>Download HubSpot's free, editable market research report template here.&nbsp;</em></a><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/market-research-kit\"></a></p> <h3>1. Five Forces Analysis Template</h3> <p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/market-research-kit?hubs_post-cta=image&amp;_ga=2.130465743.1110463319.1643300632-1761376280.1643300632\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-09-14%20at%2011.04.21%20PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-09-14%20at%2011.04.21%20PM.png\" alt=\"five forces analysis template\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></a></p> <p>Use <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/porters-five-forces\">Porter's Five Forces Model</a> to understand an industry by analyzing five different criteria and how high the power, threat, or rivalry in each area is — here are the five criteria:&nbsp;</p> \n  <ul> \n   <li>Competitive rivalry</li> \n   <li>Threat of new entrants</li> \n   <li>Threat of substitution</li> \n   <li>Buyer power</li> \n   <li>Supplier power</li> \n  </ul> <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/market-research-kit?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase\"><em>Download a free, editable Five Forces Analysis template here.&nbsp;</em></a> <br> <h3>2. SWOT Analysis Template</h3> \n   <div> \n    <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/market-research-kit?hubs_post-cta=image&amp;_ga=2.130465743.1110463319.1643300632-1761376280.1643300632\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/SWOT%20Analysis%20Template,%20Blog%20Image-1.jpg?width=1500&amp;name=SWOT%20Analysis%20Template,%20Blog%20Image-1.jpg\" alt=\"free editable swot analysis template\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></a> \n   </div> \n   <div>\n     &nbsp; \n   </div> \n   <div>\n     &nbsp;A \n    <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/swot-analysis\">SWOT (Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, Threats) analysis</a> looks at your internal strengths and weaknesses, and your external opportunities and threats within the market. \n   </div> \n   <div>\n     A SWOT analysis highlights direct areas of opportunity your company can continue, build, focus on, and work to overcome. \n   </div> \n   <div>\n     &nbsp; \n   </div> \n   <div style=\"text-align: center;\"> \n    <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/market-research-kit?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase\"><em>Download a free, editable SWOT Analysis template here.&nbsp;</em></a> \n   </div> <h3>3. Market Survey Template</h3> <p>Both market surveys and focus groups (<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/market-research-buyers-journey-guide#focus-groups\">which we'll cover in the next section</a>) help you uncover important information about your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/buyer-persona-research\">buyer personas</a>, target audience, current customers, market, competition, and more (e.g. demand for your product or service, potential pricing, impressions of your branding, etc.).</p> <p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/surveys\">Surveys</a> should contain a variety of question types, like multiple choice, rankings, and open-ended responses. Ask quantitative and short-answer questions to save you time and to more easily draw conclusions. (Save longer questions that will warrant more detailed responses for your focus groups.)</p> <p>Here are some categories of questions you should ask via survey:&nbsp;</p> \n   <ul> \n    <li>Demographic questions</li> \n    <li>Business questions</li> \n    <li>Competitor questions</li> \n    <li>Industry questions</li> \n    <li>Brand questions</li> \n    <li>Product questions</li> \n   </ul> \n   <div> \n    <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/market-research-kit?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase\"><em>Download a free, editable Market Survey template here.&nbsp;</em></a> \n   </div> <a></a> <h3>4. Focus Group Template</h3> <p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-run-a-focus-group\">Focus groups</a> are an opportunity to collect in-depth, qualitative data from your real customers or members of your target audience. You should ask your focus group participants open-ended questions. While doing so, keep these tips top of mind:</p> \n   <ul> \n    <li>Set a limit for the number of questions you're asking (after all, they're open-ended).&nbsp;</li> \n    <li>Provide participants with a prototype or demonstration.</li> \n    <li>Ask participants how they feel about your price.</li> \n    <li>Ask participants about your competition.</li> \n    <li>Offer participants time at the end of the session for final comments, questions, or concerns.</li> \n   </ul> \n   <div> \n    <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/market-research-kit?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase\"><em>Download a free, editable Focus Group template here.&nbsp;</em></a> \n   </div> <a></a> <h2><strong>Market Research Examples&nbsp;</strong></h2> <h3>1. Disney uses kid-centric focus groups to test new characters and ideas.</h3> <p>The Walt Disney Company can spend millions crafting what its Animation Studio team believes is a worthwhile story, but it wisely focuses on its intended audience — children — when testing how well a character or topic performs.&nbsp;</p> <p>A few times each year, Disney executives meet with preschoolers and kindergartners in <a href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324050304578412771510068366\"><span>kid-centric focus groups</span></a> to get their opinions and insights on TV episodes, Disney characters, and more.&nbsp;</p> <p>Why is this an effective market research strategy? Because children are ultimately the audience Disney hopes to delight — so collecting their feedback is invaluable to iterating on their existing content and ensuring it continues to meet its audiences' preferences.</p> <h3>2. KFC tested its meatless product in select markets before launching nationwide.</h3> <p>In 2019, KFC began developing and testing a new meatless version of its chicken. Rather than instantly rolling the product out nationwide, however, it started small: In <a href=\"https://abcnews.go.com/US/kfcs-plant-based-fried-chicken/story?id=65196504\"><span>select stores in the Atlanta, Georgia area</span></a>.&nbsp;</p> <p>This is an easy, effective example of conducting market research to determine how well a new product sells on a smaller scale before dedicating too many resources to it. If the meatless chicken flopped in Georgia, KFC would need to change the product before re-launching it to the market.</p> <h3>3. Yamaha conducted a survey to determine whether they should use knobs or sliding faders on the Montage keyboard.</h3> <p>When Yamaha, a Japanese-based corporation that produces a variety of products ranging from motorcycles to golf cars to musical instruments, began developing its new Montage keyboard, the team was unsure whether to use knobs or sliding faders on the product.</p> <p>So <a href=\"https://www.qualtrics.com/customers/yamaha/\"><span>Yamaha used Qualtrics to send a survey</span></a> to their customers, and received 400 responses in a few hours.&nbsp;</p> <p>Using survey feedback helped Yamaha ensure it was designing a product that exactly fit its audiences' preferences.</p> <h3>4. The Body Shop used social listening to determine how they should re-position brand campaigns to respond to what their customers cared most about.</h3> <p>The Body Shop has long been known for offering ethically sourced and natural products, and proudly touts \"sustainability\" as a core value.&nbsp;</p> <p>To dive deeper into the sustainability sub-topics that meant the most to their audiences, the team at <a href=\"https://www.brandwatch.com/case-studies/the-body-shop/view/\"><span>The Body Shop tracked conversations</span></a> and ultimately found their audiences cared a lot about refills.&nbsp;</p> <p>Using this information helped the Body Shop team feel confident when relaunching their <a href=\"https://www.thebodyshop.com/en-us/about-us/brand-values/sustainability/refill-program/a/a00048\"><span>Refill Program across 400 stores globally in 2021</span></a>, and another 400 in 2022. Market research proved they were on the right track with their refill concept, and demonstrated increased efforts were needed to show Body Shop customers that the Body Shop cared about their customers' values.&nbsp;</p> </br></br>\n</div> \n<h2>Conduct Market Research to Grow Better</h2> \n<p>Conducting market research can be a very eye-opening experience. Even if you think you know your buyers pretty well, completing the study will likely uncover new channels and messaging tips to help improve your interactions.</p> \n<p><em style=\"color: inherit; font-size: 1.125rem; font-weight: 400;\">Editor's note: This post was originally published in March 2016 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=560aa80b-9e0b-4615-851c-f23e4f49b62f&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/560aa80b-9e0b-4615-851c-f23e4f49b62f.png\" /></a></p> \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmarket-research-buyers-journey-guide&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\"
