Bretous)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/2c7242e4-ad54-4f63-8627-a15aa6a2ea50.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn60@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-26-48-399_50ccf56f10c400b5.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/TikTok%20Trends%20B2B%20and%20B2C%20Marketers%20Should%20Watch%20in%202022-1.jpeg?width=250&name=TikTok%20Trends%20B2B%20and%20B2C%20Marketers%20Should%20Watch%20in%202022-1.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn97@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-26-57-118_3d1146286eb2a07c.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/TikTok%20Trends%20B2B%20and%20B2C%20Marketers%20Should%20Watch%20in%202022-4.jpeg?width=250&name=TikTok%20Trends%20B2B%20and%20B2C%20Marketers%20Should%20Watch%20in%202022-4.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn57@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-26-55-617_c6e8a2971d2c22ba.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/TikTok%20Trends%20B2B%20and%20B2C%20Marketers%20Should%20Watch%20in%202022-2.jpeg?width=250&name=TikTok%20Trends%20B2B%20and%20B2C%20Marketers%20Should%20Watch%20in%202022-2.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn22@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-26-49-465_36c6c63bc8ef1413.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/TikTok%20Trends%20B2B%20and%20B2C%20Marketers%20Should%20Watch%20in%202022-3.jpeg?width=300&name=TikTok%20Trends%20B2B%20and%20B2C%20Marketers%20Should%20Watch%20in%202022-3.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn30@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-26-55-486_02778552e412373d.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/TikTok%20Trends%20B2B%20and%20B2C%20Marketers%20Should%20Watch%20in%202022.jpeg?width=300&name=TikTok%20Trends%20B2B%20and%20B2C%20Marketers%20Should%20Watch%20in%202022.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn2@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-26-50-541_732dd4e77ae02bad.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/7a03a7b4-d90f-4c86-b845-fae9305669ea.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn66@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-26-50-089_4634eb1b7855c84c.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ftiktok-trends&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647246408205},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:26:48","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:26:48","title":"How to Be an Amazing Mentor in 10 Ways, according to HubSpot Managers","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/mentor-tips-positive-impact","description":"<p>Take a minute to think about the best mentor you've ever had. It could be your manager, a colleague, a parent, a friend, a coach, a college professor.</p> \n<p>Then, you reach a point in your life where you have the chance to do the same for someone else. It can be both exciting, and a little confusing.</p> \n<a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"→ Click here to download leadership lessons from HubSpot founder, Dharmesh  Shah [Free Guide].\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84.png\"></a> \n<p>In this article, you’ll get tips from both mentors and mentees on what it takes to foster this successful relationship.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2>What does it mean to be a mentor?</h2> \n<p>At its core, being a mentor is being a trusted advisor. It all boils down to making yourself available to support and advise someone when they need it, delivering that support in a way that makes sense to them, and always keeping that person's best interests in mind.</p> \n<p>So, what value does a mentor bring? It depends on who you ask.</p> \n<p>For <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/vrnda-levalley\">Vrnda LeValley,</a> customer training manager at HubSpot, it’s a shift in perspective.</p> \n<p>\"My mentor provides a perspective that isn’t riddled with the same self-doubt and stereotype sensitivities that I desperately want to avoid and handicap me,\" she says, \"and a broader view of the implications of action versus inaction because they have a better vantage point from their upstream position within the company.\"</p> \n<p>She adds that her mentor has been able to step in and correct narratives that muddy her ability to make the most strategic decisions.</p> \n<p>For Legal Specialist at HubSpot <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/ronjay77\">Jason Perry,</a> one of the benefits of mentorship is the opportunity to extend your network.</p> \n<p>\"I most value the trust and confidence they extend to me by granting me access and recommending me to their broader networks,\" he said.</p> \n<p>Beyond that, there’s a certain freedom that comes with having a mentor.</p> \n<p>\"I think it allows for an open space to be vulnerable with someone who is more senior in their career but does not have direct control over your career growth,\" said <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/chloewashington\">Chloe Washington</a>, chief of staff to the CMO at HubSpot. \"You can be more transparent and ask questions you may not feel comfortable asking your manager or another co-worker.\"</p> \n<p>With that said, the mentorship doesn’t just benefit the mentee, it’s a two-sided relationship.</p> \n<p>\"I am constantly inspired by what my mentees are doing, their ambition, and their goals,\" Washington said. \"It motivates me as I continue along my career journey. It also allows me to form relationships with people that I may have not otherwise been able to speak with as much or as often.\"</p> \n<div>\n <iframe style=\"border: none; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\" src=\"https://listen.hubspot.com/embed/v2/smallPlayer/f0d5558d\" width=\"600\" height=\"337.5\"></iframe>  \n</div> \n<p></p> \n<h3>1. Understand what you want out of the relationship.</h3> \n<p>As we’ve mentioned, mentorship isn’t a one-way relationship. This means that just like the mentee, you should know the type of relationship you’re seeking and what you want to gain.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/charlene-strain-813a5a104\">Charlene Strain</a>, marketing manager at HubSpot, serves as a mentor and suggests asking yourself these questions to get started:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Do you view it as a two-way street, player-coach relationship where you learn from them as much as they learn from you or something else?</li> \n <li>How can you sharpen your area of expertise?</li> \n <li>Do they have connections or gaps of knowledge for you as well?</li> \n <li>How does taking on a mentorship role strengthen you as a leader in your personal and professional life?</li> \n</ul> Knowing these answers will help you frame your mentorship strategy and start with clear intentions.\n<br> \n<h3>2. Set expectations together in the very beginning.</h3> \n<p>Once you know what you want out of the relationship as a mentor, setting expectations is the next natural step.</p> \n<p>Every mentor-mentee relationship is unique. So, when you first start out, discuss expectations with your mentee and determine if you’re ready for that commitment.</p> \n<p>\"Everyone works and receives feedback differently, so it's important to understand if the relationship is a fit for both parties [based] on what they're looking for,\" said Strain.</p> \n<p>Here’s what Strain recommends discussing:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Is there a time limit on when the mentorship ends?</li> \n <li>How often should you meet, and why?</li> \n <li>What resources can the mentor provide for the mentee to do some work on their own?</li> \n <li>What metrics are being used to measure success?</li> \n <li>How hands-on should the mentor be?</li> \n</ul> \n<p>You should come to these answers as a duo and it’s OK if it takes a little bit to figure it out. The time you put in at the beginning will pay off in the long term.</p> \n<p>Some expectations are pretty straightforward, Perry says: professionalism, punctuality, clear communication, and organization. However, some expectations will be shaped by the mentee.</p> \n<p>\"A mentee should be able to tell me as the mentor exactly what they'd like me to do for them, whether it 's to provide information, make an introduction, write a recommendation or provide advice,\" says Perry. \"The relationship is theirs to shape and build and that starts with a clear, direct ask of some sort.\"</p> \n<p>When Washington works with mentees, her first session focuses on goal setting, setting up a meeting cadence, and discussing ground rules.</p> \n<p>\"For example, if there is a big topic to discuss, I request that they give me a heads up a few days before so that I can come fully prepared to discuss my point of view and not waste their time formulating my thoughts on the fly,\" she said.</p> \n<p>From there, she creates a running agenda doc to keep track of notes and have a place they can refer back to once the mentorship ends.</p> \n<h3>3. Take a genuine interest in your mentee as a person.</h3> \n<p>A mentor/mentee relationship is a very personal one.</p> \n<p>You can give mediocre advice without really knowing a person, but to stand out as an amazing mentor, you're really going to have to get to know your mentee on a personal level.</p> \n<p>You probably have some of the more career-oriented questions down: what their working style is, their dream job, goals for their current job, and so on and so forth. But what about the stuff that makes them ... <em>them? </em></p> \n<p>Getting to know your mentee on a deeper level will help you build a strong relationship, and it'll also help you understand who they are as a person and how they interact with others, and so on.</p> \n<p>One great way to get to know someone?<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/active-listening-guide\"> </a><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/active-listening-guide\">Become an active listener</a>. This is easier said than done: It means making a conscious effort to really, truly pay attention to what your mentee is saying, instead of thinking about what you're going to say next.</p> \n<p>\"Two<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/mentor-traits\"> traits that are helpful for someone to be a successful mentor</a> are good listening skills and the ability to connect like-minded people,\" said Strain. \"Our professional lives are not in a silo, they're a web. So, anyway I can truly listen to a mentee's goals, their journey, and where they see themselves will help me connect them with other people or businesses with the same mission.\"</p> \n<p>You might worry that you need to come up with something helpful right away, when in fact, the best thing you can do for your mentee is to listen closely to what they're saying, ask open questions to dig deeper and act as a sounding board.</p> \n<h3>4. Build trust.</h3> \n<p>In the last section, we stressed the vulnerability that comes with mentorship. To continue fostering a safe environment in which your mentee can share their concerns and challenges, you need to build trust.</p> \n<p>That can happen in a few different ways. For Solutions Engineer at HubSpot<a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/sagaille\"> Jeremy Sagaille</a>, it’s transparency.</p> \n<p>\"I feel like I can really be myself in front of my mentor and I don't feel like I have to do the typical corporate political BS,\" he said, \"which is something that I've definitely had to tiptoe through in the past and haven't done well with.\"</p> \n<p>For LeValley, it’s the ability to see beyond the circumstance to assess the core issues, challenges, and opportunities.</p> \n<p>\"Those can get cloudy when you are on the road to a destination you have never visited before,\" she says. \"It makes all the difference when avoiding pitfalls and finding solid shortcuts.\"</p> \n<p>She adds that truth-telling is another valuable trait in a mentor.</p> \n<p>\"Many people haven’t been given the hard messages required for growth, due to lack of investment or lack of courage from those around them,\" she says. \"Personally, the best thing my mentor told me was to check in with my growth mindset and read a book. Not what I wanted to hear but it was 100% what I needed to hear.\"</p> \n<p>Once you build trust with your mentee, your relationship will be able to go that much deeper.</p> \n<h3>5. Know when to give advice.</h3> \n<p>When you're mentoring someone, you might feel pressured to give them advice straight away. But not all feedback is helpful feedback, and knowing the difference is key.</p> \n<p>A good mentor knows when to hit 'pause' during a conversation, says <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/rebeccacorliss\">Rebecca Corliss</a>, former director of marketing at HubSpot.</p> \n<p>\"If you don't have the right information, experience, or emotional state to react to a scenario properly, hit 'pause,\" she said. \"That will give you a chance to get more information, talk to your resources, and come back with a clear and valuable response.\"</p> \n<p>Here’s what that might look like in a real conversation.</p> \n<p><em>\"Thanks for sharing this with me. I'm going to take some time and give this some serious thought before we continue. It's important to me that I'm giving you the best possible solution. Why don't we continue talking about it [tomorrow/next week/next time we meet]? I'll book some time.\"</em></p> \n<h3>6. Don’t assume anything about your mentee – ask.</h3> \n<p>Biases cloud our judgment whether we realize it or not. While we can work to uncover and dismantle them, some are so ingrained that they peak out without us realizing it.</p> \n<p>To combat this issue with your mentee, breakthrough common assumptions by asking questions and digging deeper. This is especially important if you're mentoring someone who's in the early stages of their career</p> \n<p>Say you're mentoring someone who's having trouble getting through to their manager. Instead of launching into a story about a time you had communication issues with a manager of yours, spend time asking questions that draw out the important details of their problem.</p> \n<p>\"Your job is to facilitate advancement and movement, not just chat,\" says LeValley. \"Your words can change their lives so you must choose them carefully.\"</p> \n<p>Only once you've gotten an honest background on a problem can you share helpful, relevant feedback – without making decisions <em>for</em> your mentee.</p> \n<h3>7. Share your journey.</h3> \n<p>Being open to sharing your own mistakes and failures is one of the best gifts a mentor can give.</p> \n<p>Not only is it helpful information for problem-solving purposes, but it also builds trust and strengthens the relationship.</p> \n<p>\"Junior employees don't always feel comfortable owning up to a mistake or admitting that they're struggling in a certain area,\" says former Managing Director at HubSpot<a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/emmajsnider\"> </a><a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/emmajsnider\">Emma Brudner</a>. \"If you cop to your failures and struggles, you make it OK for them to chime in and help them share with you.\"</p> \n<p>Sagaille says that before his mentor, he often thought the struggles he faced were unique. However, he was reassured by his mentor, who had experience in his exact role.</p> \n<p>\"I'm just excited that I have a window into the future a little bit because she's dealt with similar issues and she's had some setbacks because of those issues,\" he says, \"so, she's able to steer me in the direction so I can avoid those pitfalls.\"</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/lesliezye\">Leslie Ye</a>, content designer at HubSpot, suggests reflecting on the roadblocks you faced when you were in your mentee’s stage in life or career.</p> \n<p>\"Hearing how someone else approached a challenge is always helpful for someone going through it for the first time,\" she says. \"Even if you don't solve problems the same way as your mentee, it's always useful to hear multiple perspectives.\"</p> \n<p>Perry echoes this sentiment.</p> \n<p>\"Take time to tap into your own story,\" he says, \"Especially for Black mentors, it's important to relate and establish an interpersonal bond that fosters real talk – be a true resource in all facets.\"</p> \n<p>He adds that adversity of any kind our response to them is a foundational way to create relatability. Strain agrees, pointing to her non-traditional tech background before transitioning to the B2B Saas space.</p> \n<p>\"I'm extremely transparent about my own journey with a mentee. As I climb up the ladder as a Black woman in tech, it's important for me to continue reaching back down and helping others up as well,\" she says. \"If it wasn't for some of my own incredible mentors throughout my career, I wouldn't be a mentor now as well.\"</p> \n<h3>8. Celebrate their achievements.</h3> \n<p>Because people often look for or call upon a mentor to help them with tough situations, many mentorship conversations revolve around the stressful stuff.</p> \n<p>When you take the time to highlight and even celebrate your mentee's successes and achievements, you're also building your mentee's confidence and keeping them motivated.</p> \n<p>\"I've worked in a lot of places in the past that were very reserved with positive feedback and very lavish with constructive or negative feedback,\" said Sagaille. \"So I think that's something my mentor does really, really well – it's a nice balance.\"</p> \n<p>Some mentees also seek approval from their mentors. Acknowledging their success is a way to satisfy that psychological need for recognition.</p> \n<p>If you’re wondering <em>how </em>to celebrate their achievements, consider asking them what their love languages are. Those aren’t just helpful for personal relationships, they also work for professional ones as well.</p> \n<p>For instance, you may want to congratulate your mentee on a win by sending them a gift. However, if they value words of affirmation more, that’s the better way to go.</p> \n<h3>9. Seek out resources to help your mentee grow.</h3> \n<p>Great mentors look for situations – and some even create situations – to help their mentees get closer to their goals.</p> \n<p>It can be anything from connecting them with someone with experience in their dream job to recommending a conference they might be interested in. Take note of the areas in which your mentee wants to grow, and always be looking for opportunities to point them in the right direction.</p> \n<p>If you work at the same company as your mentee and have some involvement in their experience, Corliss suggests introducing new projects to them over time as a way to build a strong foundation.</p> \n<p>\"First, start with something that gives context. This could be something that requires research and is genuinely valuable,\" she says. \"Then, handoff something small that you normally do for your intern or mentee to own. This will help your mentee learn how to develop ownership over something, including how to execute and reach a goal on his or her own. Then, build upon that foundation.\"</p> \n<h3>10. Be sure you have the bandwidth.</h3> \n<p>LeValley believes mentorship is best when it’s approached as a calling instead of a task. With that in mind, it’s important to consider if you have the bandwidth to take it on.</p> \n<p>\"Be honest with yourself about what extent you are willing to give of your time and expertise,\" Strain says. \"This will help you manage your own workload and personal life easier without guilt or stretching yourself too thin.\"</p> \n<p>Washington echoes this sentiment and adds that it’s OK to bow out if you realize you don’t have the bandwidth.</p> \n<p>\"The relationship needs to be mutually beneficial and if you feel like you would be burdened by taking on the relationship, then be respectful to your prospective mentee and tell them that you’re not able to take on the relationship,\" she says. \"It’s better to be upfront than to waste anyone’s time.\"</p> \n<p>At the end of the day, being a great mentor takes practice and patience. The more you work with a given mentee, the more you'll learn a lot about them: their communication style, how they process feedback, how they go about pursuing their goals.</p> \n<p>The best part? It will likely be as rewarding an experience for you as it will be for your mentees.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's Note: This post was originally published in Jan. 2016 and has been updated for comprehensiveness. </em></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=5174aed9-1caa-4a36-b2d6-84c4d96c25fb&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5174aed9-1caa-4a36-b2d6-84c4d96c25fb.png\"></a></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmentor-tips-positive-impact&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 28 Feb 2022 12:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84.png","linkMd5":"8062f5ce2ddfcb1333f21fa686de0223","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn55@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-26-48-399_a76d18c90cdcfa92.webp","destWidth":660,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":7430,"destBytes":10618,"author":"mbretous@hubspot.com (Martina Bretous)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4e634041-e1ce-4a85-8e65-aea12fc10b84.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn55@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-26-48-399_a76d18c90cdcfa92.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/5174aed9-1caa-4a36-b2d6-84c4d96c25fb.png":null,"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmentor-tips-positive-impact&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn10@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-26-50-699_739f35be8e732354.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647246408218},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:26:48","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:26:48","title":"How to Build a Detailed Business Plan That Stands Out [Free Template]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/business-plan-template","description":"<p>While starting a company may seem easier now than ever before, entrepreneurs have an uphill battle from the moment they start a business. And without a clear, actionable business plan for selling, marketing, finances, and operations, you're almost destined to face significant challenges.</p>  \n<p>This is why crafting a <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/business-plan-template?hubs_post-cta=body&amp;__hstc=45788219.a88006fb12c47b02d3536e8c93c7f945.1626194230804.1626194230804.1626194230804.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1626194230805&amp;__hsfp=3989423374&amp;hubs_post=blog.hubspot.com/marketing/business-plan-template\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\">business plan</a> is an essential step in the entrepreneurial process.</p> \n<p>In this post, we'll walk you through the process of filling out your <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/business-templates/one-page-business-plan?hubs_post-cta=imagesir&amp;__hstc=45788219.a88006fb12c47b02d3536e8c93c7f945.1626194230804.1626194230804.1626194230804.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1626194230805&amp;__hsfp=3989423374\">business plan template, like this free, editable version</a>:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/business-templates/one-page-business-plan?hubs_post-cta=image&amp;_ga=2.69988182.792103557.1646248667-409851849.1646248667\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/One-Page%20Business%20Plan%20Template.jpg?width=600&amp;name=One-Page%20Business%20Plan%20Template.jpg\" alt=\"free editable One-Page Business Plan PDF  Template\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></a></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/business-plan-template?hubs_post-cta=imagesir\"><em>Download a free, editable one-page business plan template.</em></a></p> \n<p>We know that when looking at a blank page on a laptop screen, the idea of writing your business plan can seem impossible. However, it's a mandatory step to take if you want to turn your business dreams into a reality.</p> \n<p>That's why we've crafted a business plan template for you to download and use to build your new company. <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/business-plan-template?hubs_post-cta=body&amp;__hstc=45788219.a88006fb12c47b02d3536e8c93c7f945.1626194230804.1626194230804.1626194230804.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1626194230805&amp;__hsfp=3989423374\">You can download it here for free</a>. It contains prompts for all of the essential parts of a business plan, all of which are elaborated on, below.</p> \n<p>This way, you'll be able to show them how organized and well-thought-out your business idea is, and provide them with answers to whatever questions they may have.</p> \n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\">Featured Resource: <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/business-plan-template?hubs_post-cta=body\">Free Business Plan Template</a></h3> \n<h2>Building a Successful Business Plan</h2> \n<p>In the next section, we'll cover the <a href=\"https://www.growthink.com/businessplan/help-center/key-components-business-plan-part-ii\">components of a business plan</a>, such as an executive summary and company description. But before we get to that, let's talk about key elements that should serve as building blocks for your plan.</p> \n<p>For some entrepreneurs, the thought of writing a business plan sounds like a chore — a necessary means to an end. But that's a bad take.</p> \n<p>A solid business plan is a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/why-business-plan-important\">blueprint for success</a>. It's key to securing financing, presenting your business, outlining your financial projections, and turning that nugget of a business idea into a reality.</p> \n<p>At the core, your business plan should answer two questions: why your business and why now?</p> \n<p>Investors want to know why your business is entering the market, i.e. what problem it's solving and how it's different from what's currently out there. They also want to know why now is the right time for your type of product or service.</p> \n<p>At a minimum, your plan should:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Be more realistic than idealistic: </strong>Too often, business plans focus too much on how things could be instead of how they are. While having a vision is important, your plan needs to be rooted in research and data.</li> \n <li><strong>Legitimize your business idea</strong>: If an idea fails on paper, it's a signal to go back to the drawing board. In doing so, you avoid losing precious time or money chasing an unrealistic idea.</li> \n <li><strong>Position your business for funding:</strong> To get your business off the ground, chances are you'll need financial backing. Even with a solid business idea, investors, lenders, and banks still need convincing. An effective business plan will outline how much money you need, where it's going, what targets you will hit, and how you plan to repay any debts.</li> \n <li><strong>Lay the foundation:</strong> Investors focus on risk – if anything looks shaky, it could be a dealbreaker. Ideally, your business plan will lay down the foundation for how you'll operate your business — from operational needs to financial projections and goals.</li> \n <li><strong>Communicate your needs:</strong> It's nearly impossible to communicate your needs if you don't know what they are first. Of course, a business’ needs are always changing — but your plan should give you a well-rounded view of how your business will work in the short and long term.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>So back to the question of why and why now – consider three things:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Your industry </strong>– How does your product or service fit within your industry? Are you targeting a specific niche? Where do you see the industry going in the next five to 10 years?</li> \n</ul> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/target-audience\"><strong>Your target audience </strong></a>– Who are you targeting? What challenges are they facing? How will your product or service help them in their daily lives?</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/unique-selling-proposition\"><strong>Your unique selling proposition</strong></a><strong> (USP) </strong>– What sets you apart from your competitors? Is it your product/service features? Your company values? Price?</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Once you know the answers to these questions, you'll be equipped to answer the question: why your business and why now.</p> \n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\">Featured Resource: <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/business-plan-template?hubs_post-cta=body\">Free Business Plan Template</a></h3>  \n<h3>1. Cover Page</h3> \n<p>Your business plan should be prefaced with an eye-catching cover page. This means including a high-resolution image of your company logo, followed by your company's name, address, and phone number.</p> \n<p>Since this business plan will likely change hands and be seen by multiple investors, you should also provide your own name, role in the business, and email address on the cover page.</p> \n<p>At the bottom of this page, you can also add a confidentiality statement to protect against the disclosure of your business details.</p> \n<p>The statement can read as follows: \"<em>This document contains confidential and proprietary information created by [your company name]. When receiving this document, you agree to keep its content confidential and may only reproduce and/or share it with express written permission of [your company name]</em>.\"</p> \n<p>Remember to keep your cover page simple and concise — and save the important details for other sections.</p> \n<p><strong>Why it matters: </strong>First impressions are everything, and a clean cover page is the first step in the right direction.</p> \n<p><strong>Example of a Cover Page</strong></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/k8btRjGJKYsvYZZaky97fQJJmc7xyb2hrYgN2RrYH7YAIfTiYppqyFYYuOCVyh6wI3O-1s-FakM2vuNdeoN8Jzq2U9zrrPoVZbaxMEYnA4KVCQhhy7jWKnsEPTfc4V91rlvUxIPQ\" width=\"550\" alt=\"Business Plan Template: Cover Page\" style=\"margin-right: auto; margin-left: auto; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; font-size: 11px; font-family: AvenirNext, 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; color: #000000; width: 550px;\"></p> \n<h3>2. Executive Summary</h3> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/executive-summary-examples?__hstc=45788219.a88006fb12c47b02d3536e8c93c7f945.1626194230804.1626194230804.1626194230804.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1626194230805&amp;__hsfp=3989423374\">executive summary</a> of your business plan provides a one- to two-page overview of your business and highlights the most crucial pieces of your plan, such as your short-term and long-term goals.</p> \n<p>The executive summary is essentially a boiled-down version of your entire business plan, so remember to keep this section to the point and filled only with essential information.</p> \n<p>Typically, this brief section includes:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>A mission statement.</li> \n <li>The company's history and leadership model.</li> \n <li>An overview of competitive advantage(s).</li> \n <li>Financial projections.</li> \n <li>Company goals.</li> \n <li>An ask from potential investors.</li> \n</ul> \n<p><strong>Why it matters:</strong> The executive summary is known as the make-or-break section of a business plan. It influences whether investors turn the page or not — so effectively summarizing your business and the problem it hopes to solve is a must.</p> \n<p>Think of the Summary as a written elevator pitch (with more detail). While your business plan provides the nitty-gritty details, your Summary describes — in a compelling but matter-of-fact language — the highlights of your plan. If it's too vague, complicated, or fuzzy, you may need to scrap it and start again.</p> \n<p><strong>Example of an Executive Summary Introduction</strong></p> \n<p><em>\"The future looks bright for North Side Chicago, particularly the Rock Hill Neighborhood. A number of high-end commercial and residential developments are well on their way, along with two new condo developments in nearby neighborhoods.</em></p> \n<p><em>While the completion of these developments will increase the population within the neighborhood and stimulate the economy, the area lacks an upscale restaurant where residents and visitors can enjoy fine food and drink. Jay Street Lounge and Restaurant will provide such a place.\"</em></p> \n<h3>3. Company &amp; Business Description</h3> \n<p>In this section, provide a more thorough description of what your company is and why it exists.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/1hHCPipsTYKN2hKZtSGM3tzx8fDbCtVJcdQDJrOuQR3iPd6kRmYD64otOq6lkZ7Jio1MiQnFJVhF_fNKCdGxQTS3cjfxvF2-n9sp9Rt5v3Vf7W5UF6b_RAp-_jHkAu8A5dru9GPV\" width=\"450\" style=\"width: 450px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" alt=\"Business Plan Template: Business Description\"></p> \n<p>The bulk of the writing in this section should be about your company's purpose – covering what the business will be selling, identifying the target market, and laying out a path to success.</p> \n<p>In this portion of your business plan, you can also elaborate on your company's:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Mission statement</li> \n <li>Core values</li> \n <li>Team and organizational structure</li> \n</ul> \n<p><strong>Why it matters: </strong>Investors look for great structures and teams in addition to great ideas. This section gives an overview of your businesses' ethos. It's the perfect opportunity to set your business apart from the competition — such as your team's expertise, your unique work culture, and your competitive advantage.</p> \n<p><strong>Example of a Values/Mission Statement</strong></p> \n<p><em>\"Jay Street Lounge and Restaurant will be the go-to place for people to get a drink or bite in an elegant, upscale atmosphere. The mission is to be North Side's leading restaurant, with the best tasting food and the highest quality service.\"</em></p> \n<h3>3. Product &amp; Services Line</h3> \n<p>Here's where you'll cover the makeup of your business's product and/or services line. You should provide each product or service's name, its purpose, and a description of how it works (if appropriate). If you own any patents, copyrights, or trademarks, it's essential to include this info too.</p> \n<p>Next, add some color to your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/sales-strategy\">sales strategy</a> by outlining your pricing model and mark-up amounts.</p> \n<p>If you're selling tangible products, you should also explain production and costs, and how you expect these factors to change as you scale.</p> \n<p><strong>Why it matters: </strong>This section contains the real meat of your business plan. It sets the stage for the problem you hope to solve, your solution, and how your said solution fits in the market.</p> \n<p>There's no one-size-fits-all formula for this section. For instance, one plan may delve into its ability to market in a more cost-effective way than the competition, whereas another plan focuses on its key products and their unique features and benefits.</p> \n<p>Regardless of your angle, it's critical to convey how your offerings will differ from the competition.</p> \n<p><strong>Example of a Product/Service Offering</strong></p> \n<p><em>\"The menu at Jay Street Lounge and Restaurant will focus on Moroccan cuisine. The stars of the menu (our specialties) are the Moroccan dishes, such as eggplant zaalouk, seafood bastilla, tagine, and chickpea stew. For those who enjoy American dishes, there will also be a variety of options, from burger sliders and flatbread pizza to grilled steak and salads.</em></p> \n<p><em>The food at Jay Street will have premium pricing to match its upscale atmosphere. During the summer months, the restaurant will have extra seating on the patio where clients can enjoy a special summer menu. We will be open on all days of the week.\"</em></p> \n<h3>4. Market Analysis</h3> \n<p>The market analysis section is where you'll provide details about the audience to which you're marketing your business. This should encompass the size of your total addressable market, your market's demographics and psychographics, and location analysis for your business' operating space.<img src=\"https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/n6dfNVcYzMAFLHsNEMUbrCtXIsqdjmiKOGRDF6CveYLUp-4PV6lQEFZQnYNl8qEzwS0bD6R1CsUnQoy3SMgtOBqpKFtm1pXN-J0smQbQ31DX7SgOYq43X76ml_dZoi4tMchD1Ix8\" width=\"450\" style=\"width: 450px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" alt=\"Business Plan Template: Market Analysis\"></p> \n<p>It helps to reference your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/market-research-buyers-journey-guide\">market research</a> documentation in this section, like a Porter's Five Forces Analysis or a SWOT Analysis (<a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/market-research-kit?__hstc=45788219.a88006fb12c47b02d3536e8c93c7f945.1626194230804.1626194230804.1626194230804.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1626194230805&amp;__hsfp=3989423374\">templates for those are available here</a>). You can also include them in your appendix.</p> \n<p>If your company already has buyer personas, you should include them here as well. If not, you can create them right now using the <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/make-my-persona?__hstc=45788219.a88006fb12c47b02d3536e8c93c7f945.1626194230804.1626194230804.1626194230804.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1626194230805&amp;__hsfp=3989423374\">Make My Persona Tool</a>.</p> \n<p><strong>Why it matters: </strong>Having an awesome product is, well, awesome — but it isn't enough. Just as important, there must be a market for it.</p> \n<p>This section allows you to dig deeper into your market, which segments you want to target, and why. The \"why\" here is important, since targeting the right segment is critical for the success and growth of your business.</p> \n<p>It's easy to get lost (or overwhelmed) in a sea of endless data. For your business plan, narrow your focus by answering the following questions:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>What is my market? In other words, who are my customers?</li> \n <li>What segments of the market do I want to target?</li> \n <li>What's the size of my target market?</li> \n <li>Is my market likely to grow?</li> \n <li>How can I increase my market share over time?</li> \n</ul> \n<p><strong>Example of a Market Analysis</strong></p> \n<p><em>\"Jay Street Lounge and Restaurant will target locals who live and work within the Rock Hill Neighborhood and the greater North Side Chicago area. We will also target the tourists who flock to the many tourist attractions and colleges on the North Side.</em></p> \n<p><em>We will specifically focus on young to middle-aged adults with an income of $40,000 to $80,000 who are looking for an upscale experience. The general demographics of our target market are women between 20 to 50 years old.</em></p> \n<p><em>A unique and varied Moroccan-American menu, along with our unique upscale atmosphere, differentiates us from competitors in the area. Jay Street will also set itself apart through its commitment to high-quality food, service, design, and atmosphere.\"</em></p> \n<h3>5. Marketing Plan</h3> \n<p>Unlike the market analysis section, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/marketing-plan-template-generator\">your marketing plan</a> section should be an explanation of the tactical approach to reaching your aforementioned target audience. List your advertising channels, organic marketing methods, messaging, budget, and any relevant promotional tactics.</p> \n<p>If your company has a fully fleshed-out marketing plan, you can attach it in the appendix of your business plan. If not, <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/marketing-plan-template?__hstc=45788219.a88006fb12c47b02d3536e8c93c7f945.1626194230804.1626194230804.1626194230804.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1626194230805&amp;__hsfp=3989423374\">download this free marketing plan template</a> to outline your strategy.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=e9d2eacb-6b01-423a-bf7a-19d42ba77eaa&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"→ Download Now: Free Business Plan Template\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/e9d2eacb-6b01-423a-bf7a-19d42ba77eaa.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p><strong>Why it matters: </strong>Marketing is what puts your product in front of your customers. It's not just advertising — it's an investment in your business.</p> \n<p>Throwing money into random marketing channels is a haphazard approach, which is why it's essential to do the legwork to create a solid marketing plan.</p> \n<p>Here's some good news — by this point, you should have a solid understanding of your target market. Now, it's time to determine how you'll reach them.</p> \n<p><strong>Example of a Marketing Plan Overview</strong></p> \n<p><em>\"Our marketing strategy will focus on three main initiatives:</em></p> \n<ul> \n <li><em>Social media marketing. We will grow and expand our Facebook and Instagram following through targeted social media ads.</em></li> \n <li><em>Website initiatives. Our website will attract potential visitors by offering updated menus and a calendar of events.</em></li> \n <li><em>Promotional events. Jay Street will have one special theme night per week to attract new clients.\"</em></li> \n</ul> \n<h3>6. Sales Plan</h3> \n<p>It doesn't matter if your sales department is an office full of business development representatives (BDR) or a dozen stores with your products on their shelves.</p> \n<p>The point is: All <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/ultimate-guide-creating-sales-plan\">sales plans</a> are different, so you should clearly outline yours here. Common talking points include your:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Sales team structure, and why this structure was chosen.</li> \n <li>Sales channels.</li> \n <li>Sales tools, software, and resources.</li> \n <li>Prospecting strategy.</li> \n <li>Sales goals and budget.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Like with your marketing plan, it might make sense to attach your completed sales plan to the appendix of your business plan. You can <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/sales-plan-template?__hstc=45788219.a88006fb12c47b02d3536e8c93c7f945.1626194230804.1626194230804.1626194230804.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1626194230805&amp;__hsfp=3989423374\">download a template for building your sales plan here</a>.</p> \n<p><strong>Why it matters:</strong> Among other things, investors are interested in the scalability of your business — which is why growth strategies are a critical part of your business plan.</p> \n<p>Your sales plan should describe your plan to attract customers, retain them (if applicable), and, ultimately, grow your business. Be sure to outline what you plan to do given your existing resources and what results you expect from your work.</p> \n<p><strong>Example of a Sales Plan Overview</strong></p> \n<p><em>\"The most important goal is to ensure financial success for Jay Street Lounge and Restaurant. We believe we can achieve this by offering excellent food, entertainment, and service to our clients.</em></p> \n<p><em>We are not a low-cost dining option in the area. Instead, the food will have premium pricing to match its upscale feel. The strategy is to give Jay Street a perception of elegance through its food, entertainment, and excellent service.\"</em></p> \n<h3>7. Legal Notes</h3> \n<p>Your investors may want to know the legal structure of your business, as that could directly impact the risk of their investments. For example, if you're looking for business partners to engage in a non-corporation or LLC partnership, this means they could be on the line for more than their actual investment.</p> \n<p>Because this clarification is often needed, explain if you are and/or plan to become a sole proprietor, partnership, corporation, LLC, or other.</p> \n<p>You should also outline the steps you have taken (or will need to take) to operate legally. This includes licenses, permits, registrations, and insurance.</p> \n<p>The last thing your investor wants to hear after they've sent you a big chunk of change is that you're operating without proper approval from the local, state, or federal government.</p> \n<p><strong>Why it matters:</strong> The last thing your investor wants to hear after they've sent you a big chunk of change is that you're operating without proper approval from the local, state, or federal government.</p> \n<p><strong>Example of Legal Notes</strong></p> \n<p><em>\"Jay Street Lounge and Restaurant is up-to-date on all restaurant licenses and health permits. Our business name and logo are registered trademarks, presenting the possibility of expanding locally.\"</em></p> \n<h3>8. Financial Considerations</h3> \n<p>Ultimately, investors want to know two things:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>When they will earn their money back.</li> \n <li>When they will start seeing returns on their initial investment.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>That said, be clear, calculated, and convincing in this section. It should cover:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Startup costs.</li> \n <li>Sales forecasts for the next several months/quarters.</li> \n <li>Break-even analysis for time and dollars.</li> \n <li>Projected profit and loss (P&amp;L) statement.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Facts and figures are key here, so be as specific as possible with each line item and projection. In addition, explain the \"why\" behind each of these sections.</p> \n<p>However, keep in mind that information overload is a risk, especially when it comes to data. So, if you have pages upon pages of charts and spreadsheets for this section, distill them into a page or two and include the rest of the sheets in the appendix. This section should only focus on key data points.</p> \n<p><strong>Why it matters:</strong> One of the most important aspects of becoming \"investor ready\" is knowing your numbers. More importantly, you need to <em>understand</em> how those numbers will enhance your business.</p> \n<p>While it's easy to write a number down on paper, it's more important to understand (and communicate) why you need capital, where it's going, and that your evaluation makes sense.</p> \n<p><strong>Example of Financial Projections</strong></p> \n<p><em>\"Based on our knowledge and experience in the restaurant industry, we have come up with projections for the business.</em></p> \n<p><em>Starting with an expenditure of $400,000 in year 1, we forecast sales of $1,500,000 and $2,800,000 for years two and three. We expect to achieve a net profit of 15% by year three.\"</em></p> \n<h3>9. Appendix</h3> \n<p>A detailed and well-developed business plan can range anywhere from 20 to 50 pages, with some even reaching upward of 80.</p> \n<p>In many cases, the appendix is the longest section. Why? Because it includes the supportive materials mentioned in previous sections. To avoid disrupting the flow of the business plan with visuals, charts, and spreadsheets, business owners usually add them in the last section, i.e. the appendix.</p> \n<p>Aside from what we've already mentioned – marketing plan, sales plan, department budgets, financial documents – you may also want to attach the following in the appendix:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Marketing materials</li> \n <li>Market research data</li> \n <li>Licensing documentation</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/branding\">Branding assets</a></li> \n <li>Floor plans for your location</li> \n <li>Mockups of your product</li> \n <li>Renderings of your office space or location design</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Adding these pieces to the appendix enriches the reader's understanding of your business and proves you've put the work into your business plan without distracting from the main points throughout the plan.</p> \n<p><strong>Why it matters:</strong> An appendix helps the reader do their due diligence. It contains everything they need to support your business plan.</p> \n<p>Keep in mind, however, that an appendix is typically necessary only if you're seeking financing or looking to attract business partners.</p> \n<h2><strong>Use a Business Plan Template to Get Started</strong></h2> \n<p>Writing a business plan shouldn't be an insurmountable roadblock to starting a business. Unfortunately, for all too many, it is.</p> \n<p>That's why we recommend using our free business plan template. Pre-filled with detailed section prompts for all of the topics in this blog post, we're confident this template will get your business plan started in the right direction.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in June 2017 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=9ce704de-19f2-4fd0-8041-22dc3c021b87&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"Business Plan Template\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/9ce704de-19f2-4fd0-8041-22dc3c021b87.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 11 Mar 2022 12:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"9a3dca76c24ad4ee342cb3326466ecd1","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"AJ Beltis","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/One-Page%20Business%20Plan%20Template.jpg?width=600&name=One-Page%20Business%20Plan%20Template.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn92@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-26-55-060_6e13b8de1260093f.webp","https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/k8btRjGJKYsvYZZaky97fQJJmc7xyb2hrYgN2RrYH7YAIfTiYppqyFYYuOCVyh6wI3O-1s-FakM2vuNdeoN8Jzq2U9zrrPoVZbaxMEYnA4KVCQhhy7jWKnsEPTfc4V91rlvUxIPQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn65@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-26-55-402_1afba6d0d52f4b5a.webp","https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/1hHCPipsTYKN2hKZtSGM3tzx8fDbCtVJcdQDJrOuQR3iPd6kRmYD64otOq6lkZ7Jio1MiQnFJVhF_fNKCdGxQTS3cjfxvF2-n9sp9Rt5v3Vf7W5UF6b_RAp-_jHkAu8A5dru9GPV":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn20@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-26-52-951_1e26ac8c8379faeb.webp","https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/n6dfNVcYzMAFLHsNEMUbrCtXIsqdjmiKOGRDF6CveYLUp-4PV6lQEFZQnYNl8qEzwS0bD6R1CsUnQoy3SMgtOBqpKFtm1pXN-J0smQbQ31DX7SgOYq43X76ml_dZoi4tMchD1Ix8":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn40@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-26-53-457_125bc2585e57d9bd.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/e9d2eacb-6b01-423a-bf7a-19d42ba77eaa.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn59@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-26-48-381_8ff1ce58a24f6d9c.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/9ce704de-19f2-4fd0-8041-22dc3c021b87.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn65@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-26-49-525_ec9e2c896a128892.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbusiness-plan-template&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn46@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-26-53-874_3b0fda08f214b8e0.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647246408173},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:26:48","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:26:48","title":"23 Simple Email Marketing Tips to Improve Your Open and Clickthrough Rates [+HubSpot Blog Data]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/make-emails-more-clickable-list","description":"<p>Practicing good inbound marketing means sending emails to people who actually <em>want</em> to hear from you.</p> \n<p>But oftentimes, your emails still end up getting lost in your customers' inbox clutter -- or worse, their spam folder. And then, when someone actually opens your email, they don't actually click through.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=20aa1557-f54e-4dac-ad9d-52d0af5c68e3&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"Click here to download our free lookbook that's packed with our favorite email  newsletters.\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/20aa1557-f54e-4dac-ad9d-52d0af5c68e3.png\" /></a></p> \n<p>You might think to yourself, \"Ugh, I just can't win.\"</p> \n<p>Don't worry, I've got your back. Here are 23 tips that are perfect for small and growing businesses, but anyone can embrace <em>right now</em> to improve their emails' open rates, clickthrough rates, and lead generation potential.</p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>Email Marketing Tips for Small Businesses</h2> \n <ol> \n  <li>Do not buy email addresses.</li> \n  <li>Abide by CAN-SPAM rules.</li> \n  <li>Ensure your opt-in process complies with GDPR.</li> \n  <li>Email new contacts within 24 hours.</li> \n  <li>Send your emails from a real person, not your company.</li> \n  <li>Pre-set the preview text.</li> \n  <li>Write clear and clickable subject lines.</li> \n  <li>Keep your emails concise.</li> \n  <li>Include one call-to-action button per email.</li> \n  <li>Add alt text to your CTA image.</li> \n  <li>Hyperlink your emails' images.</li> \n  <li>Include noticeable text links.</li> \n  <li>Place at least one clickable item above the fold.</li> \n  <li>Add alt text to all of your images.</li> \n  <li>Avoid background images.</li> \n  <li>Add social sharing buttons.</li> \n  <li>Simplify sharing with ready-made tweets.</li> \n  <li>Add an email forwarding option.</li> \n  <li>Clean up the plain text version of your emails.</li> \n  <li>Optimize your emails for mobile users.</li> \n  <li>Preview and test your emails before sending them.</li> \n  <li>Don't be afraid to 'clean up' your contact list.</li> \n  <li>Monitor each email's performance.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<h3>1. Do not buy email addresses.</h3> \n<p>I know what you're thinking: In the early stages of an <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/email\">email marketing</a> newsletter, you want to do whatever it takes to kickstart the campaign and get eyeballs on your business. I get it. Whatever options you see online, however, you should resist the urge to <em>purchase</em> an email list.</p> \n<p>There are lots of ways to buy an email list, but none of them will actually benefit your campaign. Why? Since the owners of these email addresses didn't explicitly agree to receive content from you, there's no telling how interested they are -- or if they're even a fit for what you have to offer. A bought email list is also in violation of GDPR (we'll talk more about this in just a minute).</p> \n<p>Purchasing email lists is always a bad idea. Get more reasons why in <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/32892/why-purchasing-email-lists-is-always-a-bad-idea.aspx\">this blog post</a>.</p> \n<h3>2. Abide by CAN-SPAM rules.</h3> \n<p>CAN-SPAM (<strong>C</strong>ontrolling the <strong>A</strong>ssault of <strong>N</strong>on-<strong>S</strong>olicited <strong>P</strong>ornography <strong>A</strong>nd <strong>M</strong>arketing) is an act <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-can-spam-ht\">that was passed in 2003</a>. Essentially, it's a law that establishes the rules for commercial email and commercial messages, gives recipients the right to have a business stop emailing them, and outlines the penalties incurred for those who violate the law.</p> \n<p>In order to be CAN-SPAM compliant, it's important that your email messages follow these rules, which are <a href=\"https://www.ftc.gov/tips-advice/business-center/guidance/can-spam-act-compliance-guide-business\">available on the FTC's website</a>.</p> \n<p>A few highlights:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Include your valid physical postal address in every email you send out.</li> \n <li>Give recipients a clear and obvious way to opt out (i.e., unsubscribe) of every email you send. (<strong>HubSpot customers: </strong>Don't worry -- you can't save an email template unless it includes this element.)</li> \n <li>Use clear \"From,\" \"To,\" and \"Reply to\" language that accurately reflects who you are.</li> \n <li>Avoid \"no-reply\" or similar sender names, which prevent recipients from opting out of an email newsletter if they'd like to.</li> \n <li>Avoid selling or transferring any email addresses to another list.</li> \n</ul> \n<p><strong>Note:</strong><em> Because I am not a lawyer, please do not construe the contents of this article as official legal advice. <a href=\"https://www.ftc.gov/tips-advice/business-center/guidance/can-spam-act-compliance-guide-business\">Check out the FTC's website</a> for extensive advice on this subject, and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/30594/A-Marketer-s-Guide-to-Getting-Past-Email-Spam-Filters.aspx#sm.0000o5c3iom8gdkipdw2l236rj19q\">read this blog post</a> for more tips on improving email deliverability.</em></p> \n<div class=\"video-container-responsive\"> \n <iframe style=\"margin: 0px auto; display: block;\" src=\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/cm6Dnaqiyso\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe> \n</div> \n<h3>3. Ensure your opt-in process complies with GDPR.</h3> \n<p>You've probably heard of the <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/data-privacy/gdpr\">General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)</a>, a new law enacted across Europe in May 2018 to better protect internet users' personal data.</p> \n<p>We don't expect you to have this long piece of legislation memorized. However, if some of your email recipients live in Europe, there is one key guideline by which you should develop your email marketing campaigns:</p> \n<p>When your website users land on a page that solicits their personal information, tradition might tell you to include a pre-checked box that opts the user into an email campaign so they can receive updates and special offers related to your business. Today, having this box pre-checked is in violation of GDPR. <strong>So, to comply with GDPR, make sure your European users and customers are given the clear option to opt into your email newsletter themselves -- don't make the decision for them</strong>.</p> \n<p>This rule might sound like bad news for your email marketing campaign, but it can actually improve your open and clickthrough rates. Limiting your subscriber list to just those who specifically asked to join you will ensure only the most interested people are receiving your messages. This maximizes the chances that you'll convert readers to qualified leads as a result of an email send.</p> \n<h3>4. Email new contacts within 24 hours.</h3> \n<p>It's important to take advantage of the window of opportunity when your company or brand is at the top of your prospects' minds. You can really get a pulse of what future engagement will look like by what people do when you email then within 24 hours of their subscribing to your newsletter, signing up for an offer, and so on. Plus, it's a great opportunity for branding and setting expectations.</p> \n<p>If you don't have any automated email workflows set up, you're likely missing out on some major opportunities to nurture and engage your existing contacts.</p> \n<p>(<strong>HubSpot customers: </strong><a title=\"HubSpot's Workflows tool\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing-automation\">Use HubSpot's Workflows App</a> to create personalized, automated email workflows that can get triggered in a number of different ways: when a contact gets added to a list, submits a form on your website, clicks a link in an email, views a page on your blog, clicks on one of your AdWords ads, or becomes a marketing qualified lead.)</p> \n<h3>5. Send your emails from a real person, not your company.</h3> \n<p>When you send email from a real person, your email open rate increases. Plain and simple. This is because -- based on past tests we've conducted -- recipients are typically more likely to trust a personalized sender name and email address than a generic one. People are so inundated with spam nowadays, they often hesitate to open email from unfamiliar senders -- and they're more likely to trust a personalized sender name and email address than a generic one.</p> \n<p>At HubSpot, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/31634/A-B-Testing-in-Action-3-Real-Life-Marketing-Experiments.aspx\" title=\"we've found\">we found that </a>that emails sent from \"Maggie Georgieva, HubSpot\" perform better in terms of open <em>and </em>clickthrough rate than emails sent from just \"HubSpot.\" So, it may be best to do this ...</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Sender name: Paul Smith</li> \n <li>Sender email address: <a href=\"mailto:psmith@company.com\">psmith@company.com</a></li> \n</ul> \n<p>... instead of this:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Sender name: Marketing Team</li> \n <li>Sender email address: <a href=\"mailto:marketing@company.com\">marketing@company.com</a></li> \n</ul> \n<p>(<strong>HubSpot customers:</strong> <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/articles/kcs_article/email/how-do-i-personalize-the-from-name-and-address-in-an-email?_ga=1.205947027.1866822358.1456501228\">Click here</a> to learn how to personalize the \"From\" name and email address.)</p> \n<p><strong>Note:</strong> Our tests showed personalization works, but we've also found that a combination of a person's name and a company name together in the sender name works well, too. You've just got to <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/an-introduction-to-ab-testing\">A/B test what works best</a> for your particular company, brand, and industry as well as what's ideal based on to whom you're sending emails.</p> \n<h3>6. Pre-set the preview text.</h3> \n<p>Email clients like the iPhone Mail app, Gmail, and Outlook will display the first few lines of text from the body of your email alongside the subject line. In other words, it's a text preview of the content inside the email. The exact amount of text shown depends on the email client and user settings.</p> \n<p>Use it to provide a short, to-the-point synopsis of what you're offering -- and keep it to 50 characters or less.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/email-preview-text-in-inbox.png?width=690&amp;height=54&amp;name=email-preview-text-in-inbox.png\" alt=\"email-preview-text-in-inbox.png\" width=\"690\" height=\"54\" /></p> \n<p>When you don't set the preview text, the client will automatically pull from the body of your email, which not only looks messy, but is also a wasted opportunity to engage your audience. (<strong>HubSpot customers:</strong> <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/articles/KCS_Article/Email/What-is-the-Secondary-Content-Preview-Text-section-of-my-email\">Click here</a> to learn how to set the preview text of your emails.)</p> \n<h3>7. Write clear and clickable subject lines.</h3> \n<p>Speaking of the subject line ... your marketing emails have a lot to compete with in recipients' inboxes. The best way to stand out is to write compelling, \"can't-help-but-click-on-this\" subject lines.</p> \n<p>To entice readers to click, be sure your subject lines:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Are super clear and understandable.</li> \n <li>Are fewer than 50 characters so they don't get cut off, particularly by mobile devices.</li> \n <li>Use language and messaging that <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33491/Everything-Marketers-Need-to-Research-Create-Detailed-Buyer-Personas-Template.aspx\">your target buyer persona</a> is familiar with and excited about.</li> \n <li>Include verbs and action-oriented language to create a sense of urgency and excitement.</li> \n <li>Include an exclusive value proposition (like 20% off an item or a free ebook) so people know what they're getting.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/30594/A-Marketer-s-Guide-to-Getting-Past-Email-Spam-Filters.aspx#sm.0000o5c3iom8gdkipdw2l236rj19q\">Avoid spam triggers</a> like “Cash,” “Quote,” and “Save.\"</li> \n <li>Are timely, if applicable. (One of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-email-subject-lines-list\">my favorite subject lines</a> came from Warby Parker and read: \"Uh-oh, your prescription is expiring\".)</li> \n <li>Include their first names sometimes (it could <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/the-science-of-email-marketing\">increase clickthrough rates</a>), or even add something about their specific location. (You'll want to do this sparingly, like for your most important offers, rather than over-doing it and being repetitive or intrusive.)</li> \n</ul> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/improve-your-email-subject-line\">Read this blog post</a> for more tips on writing clickable, delightful subject lines.</p> \n<h3>8. Keep your emails concise.</h3> \n<p>Everyone's busy and their inbox is already full. Why add to the problem with a longwinded email? People generally like short, concise emails better than long ones because concise emails have an obvious focus. Plus, when your users are scanning through all their emails in a short amount of time, they're more likely to find the overall message before deciding to take any action.</p> \n<p>Another reason to keep your emails short? Too much copy is actually a red flag for spam filters, too.</p> \n<p>To keep your emails short and compelling, write your email like you were talking to someone in real life. If your email <em>has </em>to be on the long side, break it up into multiple paragraphs to provide visual breaks. This'll make skimming it much easier on your reader. (<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/32606/The-9-Must-Have-Components-of-Compelling-Email-Copy.aspx#sm.0000o5c3iom8gdkipdw2l236rj19q\">Read this blog post on how to write compelling emails</a> for more tips.)</p> \n<p>Here's a great example of a concise email:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/free-lattes-concise-email-language.png?width=647&amp;height=886&amp;name=free-lattes-concise-email-language.png\" alt=\"free-lattes-concise-email-language.png\" width=\"647\" height=\"886\" /></p> \n<h3>9. Include one call-to-action button per email.</h3> \n<p>Remember when I said a lot of your email recipients will scan your email without reading all the copy? That's why you want to have a clear call-to-action (CTA) button that's easy to spot for even the quickest of email scanners. Without a CTA button, you won't be calling on your recipients to take any action that actually benefits them -- and the growth of your business.</p> \n<p>You'll want to place your CTA in a location where it's easily visible and where it makes sense for someone to click on it. For example, you might put a CTA to download a free ebook in an email that describes new strategies for using your product.</p> \n<p>Once you've determined where you want to put your CTA, it's time to create the button itself. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/call-to-action-templates-free-download-ht\">Click here to download 50 free CTA button templates</a> to get you started. (<strong>HubSpot customers:</strong> Learn how to add CTA buttons to emails in HubSpot <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/cta-user-guide-v2/how-to-add-a-call-to-action-cta-to-an-email\">here</a>.)</p> \n<h3>10. Add alt text to your CTA image.</h3> \n<p>Many email clients block images -- including your CTA buttons -- by default. That means a good chunk of your audience may not see your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/call-to-action-optimization-ht\">beautiful, optimized CTA</a>. Instead, they see this:</p> \n<p><img style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-388144872-png/Screen_Shot_2013-11-21_at_10.02.52_AM.png\" alt=\"\" /></p> \n<p>When you set an image's alt text, though, you let recipients who can't view images in their email know exactly where to click to complete the action:</p> \n<p><img style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" title=\"This is what an image with alt-text looks like.\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-385628288-png/Screen_Shot_2013-11-21_at_9.58.55_AM.png\" alt=\"CTA image with alt-text in an email.\" /></p> \n<p>You can either edit the alt text in your email tool's rich text editor (just right-click the image and edit away), or you can manually enter it in the HTML editor of your email tool like this:</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: 'courier new', courier;\"><em>&lt;a href=\"<strong>HTTP://YOURLINKHERE.COM</strong>\"&gt;&lt;img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"<strong>YOUR CTA BUTTON IMAGE SOURCE HERE.JPG</strong>\" alt-text=\"<strong>YOUR ALT-TEXT GOES HERE</strong>\"/&gt;&lt;/a&gt;</em></span></p> \n<h3>11. Hyperlink your emails' images.</h3> \n<p>Your ultimate goal in email marketing is to get people to click through to a web page. One way to increase the clickthrough rate without littering the copy with links is to hyperlink the images in your email to the webpage that corresponds with the content of the image.</p> \n<p>If you're inviting readers to download an ebook, for example, and you have a picture of the ebook included in the email, don't just hyperlink the text next to the image telling people to \"download it here.\" Hyperlink the ebook's picture, too. People are drawn to images much more commonly than text, and you want to give your email subscribers as many options to get your ebook as you can.</p> \n<p>You can simply click on the image and then use your email tool's \"Insert/Edit Link\" option, or you can link an image in the HTML editor using the following code:</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-family: 'courier new', courier; font-size: 16px;\"><em>&lt;a href=\"<strong>HTTP://YOURLINKHERE.COM</strong>\"&gt;&lt;img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"<strong>YOUR IMAGE SOURCE HERE.JPG</strong>\"/&gt;&lt;/a&gt;</em></span></p> \n<h3>12. Include noticeable text links.</h3> \n<p>In general, it's a good idea to link to your featured offer in multiple places in addition to the clear and focused call-to-action button. In addition to your main CTAs and images, consider including a noticeable text link (or two) when applicable, as having more links increases the opportunity for engagement.</p> \n<h3>13. Place at least one clickable item above the fold.</h3> \n<p>One way to make your emails more clickable? Place one or more of your clickable elements -- whether it's a CTA button, a text link, or a clickable image -- near the beginning of your email.</p> \n<p>This is especially useful for mobile users. Mobile tends to require a lot of scrolling, and sometimes squinting, pinching, and zooming. Giving a recipient something actionable that is seen upon opening can lead to more clicks in this environment.</p> \n<h3>14. Add alt text to all of your images.</h3> \n<p>Again, a lot of email clients out there block images by default. (<a href=\"https://www.campaignmonitor.com/dev-resources/will-it-work/image-blocking/\">Here's the full list</a> from Campaign Monitor.) In those cases, images won't load unless the recipient clicks a button to show them or change their default settings.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-add-alt-text-to-email-images-ht\">Adding alt text to your email images</a> helps recipients understand your message -- even if they can't see the images right away. (<strong>HubSpot customers:</strong> <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/articles/kcs_article/cos-pages-editor/how-do-i-add-alt-text-to-my-image\">Click here</a> to learn how to add alt text to your email images in HubSpot.)</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/add-alt-text.png?width=690&amp;height=301&amp;name=add-alt-text.png\" alt=\"add-alt-text.png\" width=\"690\" height=\"301\" /></p> \n<p>You might consider making the language in your alt text actionable, such as \"Click here to download the ultimate content creation kit.\" Actionable alt text will essentially turn every linked image into another CTA. So, even if someone doesn't see the snazzy GIF of my latest offer (or if they hover their mouse over an image that <em>does </em>show up), the alt text will beckon them to click.</p> \n<h3>15. Avoid background images.</h3> \n<p>This is especially important if your target buyers tend to use Outlook as an email client.</p> \n<p>Microsoft Outlook doesn't recognize background images, period. Given that <a href=\"https://emailclientmarketshare.com/\">Outlook is the fifth most-used email client</a> with 7% of the market share -- and that's in total; your industry might have a lot more -- it's best to avoid using background images altogether.</p> \n<p>Instead, use a background color and use images in other ways in your email, like Harry's did in their email below:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/harrys-email-example.png?width=580&amp;height=1630&amp;name=harrys-email-example.png\" alt=\"harrys-email-example.png\" width=\"580\" height=\"1630\" /></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em>Image Credit: <a href=\"http://beautiful-email-newsletters.com/emails/harrys-our-most-popular-gift-is/\">Beautiful Email Newsletters</a></em></span></p> \n<h3>16. Add social sharing buttons.</h3> \n<p>Increasing the number of people who see your link will increase the number of people who click on it. So, be sure to extend the life of your email by <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/29544/The-Ultimate-Cheat-Sheet-for-Creating-Social-Media-Buttons.aspx\">adding social sharing buttons</a>.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/29544/The-Ultimate-Cheat-Sheet-for-Creating-Social-Media-Buttons.aspx\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" title=\"Social Sharing Buttons\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-388230117-png/linkedin-share-button-above.png?width=300&amp;name=linkedin-share-button-above.png\" alt=\"Social Sharing Buttons\" width=\"300\" /></a></p> \n<p>Many email tools will come with templates that have built-in social sharing buttons that make it easy -- just fill in the destination URL and you're good to go. If you don't have built-in capabilities, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/29544/The-Ultimate-Cheat-Sheet-for-Creating-Social-Media-Buttons.aspx\">here is a cheat sheet for easily creating your own social sharing buttons</a>.</p> \n<p><strong>Important Note:</strong> If you want to increase clicks, you want to add <em>sharing</em> buttons, not <em>follow</em> buttons. The former will allow your email recipients to pass along the offer URL in your email to their followers. The latter will prompt them to Like, follow, or add your company social media channels.</p> \n<h3>17. Simplify sharing with ready-made tweets.</h3> \n<p>People are far more likely to take an action if you make it really, really easy for them. For recipients out there who are too lazy to tweet the wonderful content you sent them via email, you can make it easy for them by creating what we call a \"lazy tweet.\"</p> \n<p>One simple way to do this? Using ClickToTweet, a free custom tweet link generator. First, <a href=\"https://clicktotweet.com/basic\">go to ClickToTweet's basic tweet generator</a>. Then, type in your tweet, desired (<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-are-utm-tracking-codes-ht\">trackable</a>) destination URL, and hashtags:</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 669px;\" title=\"click-to-tweet-example.png\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/click-to-tweet-example.png?width=669&amp;name=click-to-tweet-example.png\" alt=\"click-to-tweet-example.png\" width=\"669\"><br>Click \"Generate New Link,\" and then grab that link. Then you can link it to your Twitter sharing button. Or, if you're <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/contacts-user-guide-v2/how-lists-help-you-segment-your-contacts\">segmenting your list by attributes</a> such as \"has Twitter\" or \"topic of recent conversion: social media\" (you'll need marketing intelligence software <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/email\">like HubSpot</a> for this), you can even include it in your main email copy, like this:</br></img></p> \n<h3><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" title=\"Premade tweet copy example\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-388186477-png/Screen_Shot_2013-11-21_at_10.28.40_AM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen_Shot_2013-11-21_at_10.28.40_AM.png\" alt=\"Premade tweet copy example\" width=\"600\" /></h3> \n<h3>18. Add an email forwarding option.</h3> \n<p>Another way to extend the clicks on your email beyond its shelf life is to prompt your audience to forward the offer. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/why-people-forward-emails-data\">The folks at Litmus found that</a> <strong>the most forwarded emails were 13X more likely than the typical email to include “Share With Your Network” calls-to-action. </strong>By including forward-to-a-friend (or social sharing links, as we discussed above), you put it in recipients' minds to share.</p> \n<p>You can add a little post-script to the end of your email copy, such as \"Not responsible for your company's social media? Feel free to forward this ebook to a friend or colleague using social media marketing.\" Link the call-to-action to a pre-made email, complete with subject and body text. That way, all someone has to do is enter their associates' email addresses and hit \"Send.\"</p> \n<p>You can highlight text or an image and add the URL via your email tool's rich text editor and then enter a mailto:? link. Here's what this looks like:</p> \n<span style=\"font-size: 16px;\"><em><span style=\"font-family: 'trebuchet ms', geneva;\">mailto:?subject=Your%20subject%20here%20&amp;body=Your%20email%20body%20text%20here.</span></em></span> \n<p>You can also create this in your HTML editor.
