Here's how to attach a mailto:? link to text:</p> \n<span style=\"font-size: 16px;\"><em><span style=\"font-family: 'trebuchet ms', geneva;\">&lt;a href=\"mailto:?subject=<strong>Your%20subject%20here%20&amp;body=Your%20email%20body%20text%20here</strong>.\"&gt;</span></em></span> \n<span style=\"font-size: 16px;\"><em><span style=\"font-family: 'trebuchet ms', geneva;\">forward this ebook&lt;/a&gt;.</span></em></span> \n<p>And here's how to attach your mailto:? link to an image, such as a sleek call-to-action button that says \"Email This Offer\":</p> \n<span style=\"font-size: 16px;\"><em><span style=\"font-family: 'trebuchet ms', geneva;\">&lt;a href=\"mailto:?subject=<strong>Your%20subject%20here%20&amp;body=Your%20email%20body%20text%20here.</strong>\"&gt;&lt;img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"<strong>YOUR IMAGE SOURCE HERE.JPG</strong>\" alt-text=\"<strong>YOUR ALT-TEXT GOES HERE</strong>\"/&gt;&lt;/a&gt;</span></em></span> \n<p>Just make sure you use the \"%20\" tag to separate words! Otherwise, your message willreadlikethis (not too appealing, right?).</p> \n<h3>19. Clean up the plain-text version of your emails.</h3> \n<p>Not every recipient is going to see the beautiful, HTML, rich-text version of your email. Some clients don't support HTML-rich emails, while other times, a person may simply choose to only view messages in plain text.</p> \n<p>When you don't optimize the plain-text version of your email, this is what happens when someone views it:</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" title=\"Plain-text email done wrong.\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-388686490-png/Screen_Shot_2013-11-20_at_2.12.38_PM.png?width=403&amp;name=Screen_Shot_2013-11-20_at_2.12.38_PM.png\" alt=\"Plain-text email done wrong.\" width=\"403\" /></p> \n<p>Scary, isn't it? I don't think many people are going to bother to read through this garbled mess.</p> \n<p>So, cut out the extra text, replace long tracking URLs with shortened ones, and keep the body simple. Taking the five extra minutes to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/32643/Why-Marketers-Must-Optimize-Emails-for-HTML-AND-Plain-Text-Infographic.aspx\">optimize your email's plain-text version</a> could help you reach more of your target segment and keep you out of the spam folder.</p> \n<p><strong>Note:</strong> When you're cleaning up your plain-text emails, don't change the actual copy much at all or you'll risk it getting marked as spam.</p> \n<h3>20. Optimize your emails for mobile users.</h3> \n<p>In <a href=\"https://litmus.com/blog/mobile-rises-to-56-market-share-longest-sustained-growth-in-2016\">Litmus' analysis of over a billion email opens</a>, they reported that <strong>56% of opened emails were opened on mobile devices in April 2016. </strong>This figure represents an 8% increase in mobile opens in the past year.</p> \n<p>\"This represents a peak for mobile market share,\" they wrote, \"and the longest sustained growth we’ve seen after the holiday season.\"</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">&nbsp;</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/mobile-email-opens-litmus.png?width=690&amp;height=420&amp;name=mobile-email-opens-litmus.png\" alt=\"mobile-email-opens-litmus.png\" width=\"690\" height=\"420\"> <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em>Image Credit: <a href=\"https://litmus.com/blog/mobile-rises-to-56-market-share-longest-sustained-growth-in-2016\">Litmus</a></em></span></p> <p>As more and more people use their mobile devices to read email and surf the web, it's more important than ever that marketers design their emails with mobile users in mind. Otherwise, their user base will be significantly affected.</p> <p>How? Here's a visual example of what happens when images aren't optimized for mobile (first) versus when images are optimized for mobile (second):</p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/email-not-optimized-for-mobile.png?width=300&amp;name=email-not-optimized-for-mobile.png\" alt=\"email-not-optimized-for-mobile.png\" width=\"300\" style=\"width: 300px;\"> <img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/email-optimized-for-mobile.png?width=300&amp;name=email-optimized-for-mobile.png\" alt=\"email-optimized-for-mobile.png\" width=\"300\" title=\"email-optimized-for-mobile.png\" style=\"width: 300px; height: 628px;\" /></img></p> <p>Isn't the second image a much better user experience?</p> <p>Here are a few ways to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/optimize-email-mobile-list\">optimize your emails for mobile devices</a>:</p> \n <ul> \n  <li><strong>Reduce your images' file sizes</strong> to make up for mobile devices' generally slower download speeds. (HubSpot customers don't need to worry about it -- images uploaded to HubSpot's software are automatically compressed. Otherwise, tools like <a href=\"https://tinypng.com/\">TinyPNG</a> will help you reduce file size.)</li> \n  <li><strong>Ensure the CTA buttons and links are larger than 45-57 pixels </strong>for the best user experience. Why? <a href=\"http://touchlab.mit.edu/publications/2003_009.pdf\">According to an MIT study</a>, the average size of an adult index finger is 1.6-2 cm, which translates to 45-57 pixels on a mobile device.</li> \n  <li><strong>Invest in responsive email templates.</strong> Creating your own responsive template may be beyond your particular skill set or bandwidth. Sometimes, the most economical solution is to just license or buy email templates from the people who do it best.</li> \n </ul> <p><strong>HubSpot customers:</strong> HubSpot's default email templates are all optimized for mobile using responsive design. To access these templates, create a new email and look for the responsive option in the \"folders\" drop-down in the top left.</p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/responsive-email-1.png?width=287&amp;height=159&amp;name=responsive-email-1.png\" alt=\"responsive-email-1.png\" width=\"287\" height=\"159\" /></p> <h3>21. Preview and test your emails before sending them.</h3> <p>When you're finally ready to hit \"Send\" on your email, make a habit of double-checking one last time whether your emails look as good as you think they do. If your <a href=\"https://ecommerce-platforms.com/articles/email-marketing-services\">email marketing tool</a> lets you, go ahead and preview what your email looks like in different email clients and devices that are popular with your audience.</p> <p>(<strong>HubSpot customers:</strong> You can preview what your emails look like in 30+ email clients right in the HubSpot Email App, as well as preview what your emails will look like on any device -- including desktop, tablet, or mobile devices. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/customers/how-to-preview-your-emails-in-30-different-inboxes\">Click here to learn how</a>.)</p> <p>You should also send out a test version of your email before you send out the real deal to ensure it's working properly for everyone on your email list. Start incorporating these as final steps in your email review process. (<strong>HubSpot customers:</strong> <a href=\"https://help.hubspot.com/articles/KCS_Article/Email/How-do-I-send-a-test-email\">Learn how to test your emails here</a>.)</p> <h3>22. Don't be afraid to 'clean up' your contact list.</h3> <p>It's tempting to keep every subscriber you win on an email campaign until they personally choose to opt out. But just because they haven't opted out of an email newsletter doesn't mean they're still interested, and subscribers who have become inactive can kill your emails' open and clickthrough rates.</p> <p>To make sure you're only sending emails to the people who want to read them, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/26404/4-tips-to-keep-your-email-list-squeaky-clean.aspx\">clean up your email list</a> so that it excludes recipients who haven't opened a certain amount of emails in the campaign's recent history. This makes sure your emails' open and clickthrough rates reflect only your most interested readers, allowing you to collect more effective data on what is and isn't working in each email you send.</p> <p>On top of that, a good&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.zerobounce.net/\">email list cleaning service</a> removes other email addresses that pose a risk to your inbox placement. “Invalid, abuse, and temporary emails will affect your sender reputation, so it’s best to weed them out,” says Liviu Tanase, CEO of ZeroBounce. “Your desire to grow your list is only natural, but you can’t afford to expand it at all costs. Emailing only valid and active addresses allows you to connect with people who care about your brand, and that’s what every email marketer wants,” Tanase adds.</p> <p>(<strong>HubSpot customers:</strong> Lists that add and remove members based on their email behavior are called smart or \"active\" lists. Learn how to create them in <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/lists-user-guide/how-to-create-a-list-of-your-contacts\">HubSpot Academy</a>.)</p> <h3>23. Monitor each email's performance.</h3> <p>What's working in your email campaign this month might not work quite as well next month, and it's imperative that you check in on your emails' open and clickthrough rates for opportunities to improve your copy (to do this, of course, you'll need a tool to <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/email\">track your email analytics</a>).</p> <p>If after a month of email sends, for instance, you find 10 messages are getting double the engagement as the other 20, analyze them. What did you do differently in the higher performers? Was it the imagery? The subject line? Maybe you have more than one audience segment and one of them just isn't as interested in your current email content.</p> <p>Use your email performance data to run A/B tests that are designed to show you what your email recipients really want out of your newsletters, and steer into the trends that you see to make your email campaigns more desirable.</p> <p>Email marketing can be tough at times -- I'm right there with you. But by sending compelling offers to the right target segments and paying attention to the little details that go into an email, you can increase the opens clicks in your emails and generate more leads. (And <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/metrics-email-marketers-should-be-tracking#sm.0000o5c3iom8gdkipdw2l236rj19q\">learn more about which email marketing metrics to track -- and how -- here</a>.)</p> <p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=05a9885a-6173-4c64-8598-99503d911640&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/05a9885a-6173-4c64-8598-99503d911640.png\" /></a></p> \n <div> \n  <a class=\"close\"> </a> \n  <a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=ea1cee44-acd0-476e-a42f-ca2180e4b351&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/ea1cee44-acd0-476e-a42f-ca2180e4b351.png\" /></a> \n </div> <img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmake-emails-more-clickable-list&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \" /></img>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 07 Mar 2022 12:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/20aa1557-f54e-4dac-ad9d-52d0af5c68e3.png","linkMd5":"c9cf64ccbbd234edafa90760a4338aa5","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn4@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-26-48-407_ed945f30b09d582a.webp","destWidth":809,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":8050,"destBytes":13524,"author":"lkolowich@hubspot.com (Lindsay Kolowich Cox)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/20aa1557-f54e-4dac-ad9d-52d0af5c68e3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn4@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-26-48-407_ed945f30b09d582a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/email-preview-text-in-inbox.png?width=690&height=54&name=email-preview-text-in-inbox.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn54@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-26-56-370_f71730c32ccad83a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/free-lattes-concise-email-language.png?width=647&height=886&name=free-lattes-concise-email-language.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn6@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-26-53-275_613a50a59925c17b.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-388144872-png/Screen_Shot_2013-11-21_at_10.02.52_AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn62@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-26-53-599_0b5076ba8381d74f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-385628288-png/Screen_Shot_2013-11-21_at_9.58.55_AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn61@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-26-50-351_f446ccab9eb2e150.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/add-alt-text.png?width=690&height=301&name=add-alt-text.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn30@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-26-56-354_fa5b0b3c82c3da6a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/harrys-email-example.png?width=580&height=1630&name=harrys-email-example.png":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-388230117-png/linkedin-share-button-above.png?width=300&name=linkedin-share-button-above.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn8@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-26-52-797_cd5e74fcb0a708b0.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/click-to-tweet-example.png?width=669&name=click-to-tweet-example.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn48@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-26-56-879_b394e1df059ed559.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-388186477-png/Screen_Shot_2013-11-21_at_10.28.40_AM.png?width=600&name=Screen_Shot_2013-11-21_at_10.28.40_AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn48@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-26-56-084_9ed319b2ff98e4ae.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-388686490-png/Screen_Shot_2013-11-20_at_2.12.38_PM.png?width=403&name=Screen_Shot_2013-11-20_at_2.12.38_PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn17@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-26-56-326_8c47850277fa6a01.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/mobile-email-opens-litmus.png?width=690&height=420&name=mobile-email-opens-litmus.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn72@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-26-56-841_28302fbbe185f0bd.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/email-not-optimized-for-mobile.png?width=300&name=email-not-optimized-for-mobile.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn11@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-26-53-583_c91eae38987c421b.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/email-optimized-for-mobile.png?width=300&name=email-optimized-for-mobile.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn5@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-26-54-781_8786a3aa8d75df9f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/responsive-email-1.png?width=287&height=159&name=responsive-email-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn53@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-26-55-637_2bbf6b92b8cb2c74.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/05a9885a-6173-4c64-8598-99503d911640.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn35@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-26-50-841_6b1134a74c88a32e.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/ea1cee44-acd0-476e-a42f-ca2180e4b351.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn46@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-26-56-391_d1a1c517b04c5587.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmake-emails-more-clickable-list&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn80@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-26-55-009_808fba5a5191e82e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647246408209},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:26:48","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:26:48","title":"The Ultimate Guide to Writing a Cover Letter","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/cover-letter","description":"<p>Nowadays, companies have a computerized system that puts resumes through an online scanner which will automatically reject some applicants and push other applicants through depending on their qualifications.</p> \n<p>So, What does this mean for you as a job seeker? Well, the cover letter attached to your application is more important than ever.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=3f347702-d7e9-4e59-9fe4-be4cd7bad191&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"→ Click here to access 5 free cover letter templates [Free Download]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3f347702-d7e9-4e59-9fe4-be4cd7bad191.png\"></a></p> \n<p>We've crafted this ultimate guide to cover letters. You'll find out how to write one that gets read, what to include, and browse tons of templates to gain inspiration.</p> \n<p>You can dive straight in, or jump to the section you'd like to read.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p> \n<h2>How long should a cover letter be?</h2> \n<p>OK, so you're all fired up and ready to craft the cover letter of the hiring manager's dream. But how do you manage the fine balance between in-depth and overwhelming?</p> \n<p>A good cover letter is long enough to communicate why the recruiter should pick you but not long enough to bore them.</p> \n<p>One page is usually enough to cover everything you'll need to include, without losing the recruiter's attention. Let's go into those items in more detail:</p> \n<h3>Your Name and Address</h3> \n<p>Kick-off your cover letter by adding your name and address to the document.</p> \n<p>This step is pretty self-explanatory, but it allows the recruiter to easily connect your cover letter to your resume (especially if they're being printed).</p> \n<p>Your name and address also make it easier for the recruiter to get in touch with a job offer. And that's the aim of our letter, right?</p> \n<h3>Their Name and Address</h3> \n<p>Similarly, you should add the name and address of the company or person you're writing to.</p> \n<p>This shows you've done your research and allows the hiring manager to receive your letter if it's sent to a generic company email address.</p> \n<h3>The Date of Writing</h3> \n<p>Make it easier for the hiring manager to file your application by including the date on your cover letter.</p> \n<p>Even if you're not successful this time around, the company might store your letter and refer back to it when they're hiring for another position.</p> \n<h3>Why You're Writing the Letter</h3> \n<p>We know that the aim of a cover letter is to persuade the hiring manager you're the best fit for their job.</p> \n<p>Before you get to the good stuff, be sure to highlight the role you're applying for, as that can get lost.</p> \n<p>Something like this will usually do the trick:</p> \n<p><em>\"I'm writing to discuss the content strategist role at HubSpot.\"</em></p> \n<h3>Why You're a Perfect Fit for the Job</h3> \n<p>The next section of a cover letter structure is the fun part. It's where you'll convince the hiring manager they should hire you.</p> \n<p>In this section, answer these questions:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Why should this company hire you?</li> \n <li>What skills do you have that will help complete the job better than anyone else?</li> \n <li>What makes you a good employee?</li> \n <li>What qualifications do you have that are relevant to the role?</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Once you've answered these, the recruiter will have a solid understanding of who you are, and (hopefully) be convinced to bring you on for an interview.</p> \n<h3>What You Can Offer the Company</h3> \n<p>Have you ever heard the advice to \"always sell yourself in a job application\"? That concept can be applied to cover letters as well.</p> \n<p>Businesses measure success in terms of results. The company looking for a new employee will want to know what they bring to the table and how you fit into their business goals. New candidates are rarely brought on board solely for the<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/soft-skills\"> </a><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/soft-skills?_ga=2.185839593.1527963336.1644028103-1253290474.1644028103\">soft skills listed in their resume</a>.</p> \n<p>That's why this part of your cover letter structure is arguably the most important.</p> \n<p>In two paragraphs or less, show the business what you can do — and provide examples of how you've done it before.</p> \n<p>Not only does this give you the opportunity to show off your skills, but the company can picture the success you'll bring to their business by hiring you.</p> \n<h3>Your Availability</h3> \n<p>In the marketing world, we're always told the importance a call-to-action can make.</p> \n<p>Great cover letters end with a brief section on the candidate's earliest start date.</p> \n<h2>How to Format a Cover Letter</h2> \n<h3>How to Address a Cover Letter</h3> \n<p>Earlier, we mentioned the importance of addressing the hiring manager by their name and address. This proves you've done your research and ensures the cover letter lands in the right place.</p> \n<p>Personalized letters will always outperform generic ones, so including the first name of the recruiter can go a long way.</p> \n<p>But in a world where privacy is held close to our chest, you might need to do a bit of digging before finding the hiring manager's name.</p> \n<p>Luckily, you can use the power of the internet to do this.</p> \n<h4><strong>How to Find a Hiring Manager's Name</strong></h4> \n<p>Head over to LinkedIn and find the company's profile page.</p> \n<p>You can do this by entering their name into the search bar or searching for a link to their LinkedIn page on their company website.</p> \n<p>Then, click the number of employees to see all employees who are on LinkedIn:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img alt=\"how to look up employer details to format cover letter\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Writing%20a%20Cover%20Letter.jpeg?width=600&amp;name=The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Writing%20a%20Cover%20Letter.jpeg\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 600px;\" title=\"\" width=\"600\"></p> \n<p>You'll then see a list of all employees along with their titles. Simply work your way through this list to find the most relevant contact.</p> \n<p>Keep in mind that some employees do not have LinkedIn profiles, so you may not find them using this tactic. If you're unable to track down the hiring manager's name, a simple \"Dear Hiring Manager\" will work.</p> \n<h3>How to Open a Cover Letter</h3> \n<p>After you've addressed the cover letter to the most relevant person, you'll want to:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Introduce yourself.</li> \n <li>List the role you're interested in.</li> \n <li>Explain your interest.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Here's an example:</p> \n<p>\"<em>Dear Hiring Manager, </em></p> \n<p><em>As an avid reader of the HubSpot Blog for the past five years, I am thrilled to submit my application for the content strategist role. I believe that my five years of experience working for B2B SaaS companies have equipped me with the skills needed to thrive in this role.\"</em></p> \n<p>In the next two paragraphs, highlight your relevant experience and include key details from each role.</p> \n<h3>How to Close a Cover Letter</h3> \n<p>Once you've covered</p> \n<p>Here are some great options:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Looking forward to hearing from you</li> \n <li>Sincerely</li> \n <li>Best Regards</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Then, sign the cover letter with your full name.</p> \n<h3>Should you include salary requirements?</h3> \n<p>The cover letter should focus on why you are a good fit for the role. Discussing salary requirements doesn’t fit at this stage of your application.</p> \n<p>Instead, it’s best to wait until you speak to a recruiter or someone from HR to discuss your expectations.</p> \n<h2>Are cover letters necessary?</h2> \n<p>Today, in many industries, cover letters are listed as optional. The question is, should you include one if it's optional?</p> \n<p>The answer isn’t exactly clear-cut.</p> \n<p>Some research would suggest that cover letters may not hold the same weight as they once did. However, a cover letter can help you stand out among the competition.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"Are cover letters necessary job seekers believe getting a job will be harder than in previous years\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Writing%20a%20Cover%20Letter-1.jpeg?width=500&amp;name=The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Writing%20a%20Cover%20Letter-1.jpeg\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 500px;\" title=\"\" width=\"500\"></p> \n<p>In a 2021 Job Seeker Nation Report by JobVite, <a href=\"https://www.jobvite.com/lp/2021-job-seeker-nation-report/\">69% of surveyed workers</a> believed getting a job will be much harder or somewhat harder than in previous years. With this in mind, adding a cover letter to your application is a great way to stand out.</p> \n<p>Writing a cover letter will allow you to:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Communicate with the hiring manager.</li> \n <li>Rely on more than just bullet-pointed lists in your resume.</li> \n <li>Build your personal brand.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>In short: Cover letters aren't absolutely necessary, but they do have stark advantages. If there's an option to upload one when applying for any job, do it — even if it's not required.</p> \n<h2>How to Write a Cover Letter</h2> \n<p>Writing a cover letter can be tricky. Even the best writers can struggle with communicating their skills in the right manner, but these tips will help you create a job-winning document.</p> \n<p>The structure of your cover letter is arguably the most important thing about writing one.</p> \n<p>Not only does a good structure help you to organize your points effectively, but it can help a hiring manager to quickly review the details you're sharing.</p> \n<h5 style=\"color: #666666; font-size: 18px;\"><span style=\"color: #425b76; font-weight: normal; font-style: italic;\">Featured Resource:<a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/cover-letter-templates?hubs_post-cta=header\"> </a><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/cover-letter-templates?hubs_post-cta=header\">5 Free Cover Letter Templates</a></span></h5> \n<p><img alt=\"Cover-Letter-Templates\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Writing%20a%20Cover%20Letter.png?width=250&amp;name=The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Writing%20a%20Cover%20Letter.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 250px;\" title=\"\" width=\"250\"></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/cover-letter-templates?hubs_post-cta=imagebottom\">Download these free cover letter templates</a> to write a stand-out cover letter.</p> \n<h2>7 Tips for Writing Great Cover Letters</h2> \n<p>So, you've crafted a cover letter and you're almost ready to hit send.</p> \n<p>Before attaching to your resume and hoping for the best, use these seven tips to make sure your cover letter is as great as can be.</p> \n<h3>1. Keep it succinct.</h3> \n<p>Earlier, we mentioned how the best cover letters strike the perfect balance in their length.</p> \n<p>Our best tip for writing cover letters is to avoid adding fluff that fails to add value. Every line should highlight why you're the best fit for the role.</p> \n<p>In addition, cut the jargon and corporate-speak that hiring managers have heard before.</p> \n<p>Yes, professionalism is important, but be harsh and critical when editing your cover letter. If a sentence doesn't add value, get rid of it.</p> \n<h3>2. Tailor it for the company and position you're applying for.</h3> \n<p>The one-size-fits-all approach doesn't fit well with cover letters.</p> \n<p>You're applying for different roles at various companies, but don't let a change in name and address be the only updates you make.</p> \n<p>Remember that a cover letter should explain why you should be hired for a specific role instead of anyone else. It's highly unlikely that multiple companies will hire for exactly the same position, so take some time to personalize your cover letter for every position you're applying for.</p> \n<h3>3. Don't repeat what's on your resume.</h3> \n<p>Although cover letters are submitted along with resumes, be wary of making them carbon copies of one another.</p> \n<p>Instead, use the documents to compliment each other by:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Including new skills.</li> \n <li>Elaborating on how your qualifications would help you in the role.</li> \n <li>Sharing how specific experience gives you an advantage over other candidates.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>If you need to include the same thing in both documents, add \"as listed in my resume …\" rather than copy and pasting the same content.</p> \n<h3>4. Include data-backed examples.</h3> \n<p>When referencing experience from your resume, use your cover letter as an opportunity to explain in detail — with examples.</p> \n<p>Examples allow the company to picture the success you could bring if they hired you, rather than the person next in their resume pile. But, data-backed examples give an extra edge.</p> \n<p>Let's use an example. Which of these options is more impressive?</p> \n<ol start=\"1\"> \n <li>I increased leads for the company.</li> \n <li>I increased leads by 35% in one month through a single blog post, which became the company's highest lead driver.</li> \n</ol> \n<p>It's option B, right? That's because it's descriptive and shows results.</p> \n<h3>5. Tell a story.</h3> \n<p>Following on from the previous step, you could elaborate on your data-backed examples by telling a story.</p> \n<p>Storytelling helps with relatability and gives a hint of your personality in a cover letter. It also makes the recruiter remember your cover letter amongst a sea of other one-page documents in their review pile.</p> \n<p>However, this cover letter tip comes with a warning: Don't overdo it and make sure it's relevant.</p> \n<h3>6. Get a second pair of eyes on it.</h3> \n<p>Even the best writers make mistakes, but they can leave a negative first impression.</p> \n<p>That's why our sixth cover letter tip is to get a second pair of eyes on it.</p> \n<p>Email it to a friend or ask a family member to glance over it before you hit \"send.\" Ask them to highlight any spelling mistakes or suggestions to improve how you're communicating with the person reading it.</p> \n<p>You never get a second chance to make a first impression. Seeing as though a cover letter is one of the first documents a recruiter sees, try to make it perfect.</p> \n<h3>7. Be unique.</h3> \n<p>Finally, make your cover letter unique.</p> \n<p>If you're applying for a creative role, experiment with colors, subheadings, and layouts.</p> \n<p>If you're applying for more of a traditional role, be wary. Not everyone is a fan of bright, bold cover letters, but you can scope your limits by getting a feel of their company culture.</p> \n<p>Are they strict and professional, or does the company like to have fun? (You can usually get a feel of this from their website or social media profiles.)</p> \n<p>Testing the level of uniqueness can be a case of trial and error. If you're not getting great reactions from your cover letter, revise and try again.</p> \n<h2>Cover Letter Examples</h2> \n<p>We understand that inspiration can go a long way. That's why we've created a one-stop-shop for<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-cover-letter-examples\"> </a><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-cover-letter-examples\">cover letter examples</a>, which are available to view here.</p> \n<p>You're also free to browse our collection of<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-write-cover-letter-template\"> </a><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-write-cover-letter-template\">cover letter samples</a> for extra inspiration on formatting your cover letter and learning from those who've helped to land dream jobs.</p> \n<p>Now you're fully equipped to write a cover letter that will help you get your foot in the door.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in September 2018 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=fad76600-17bb-4e20-b22b-bef5020bec74&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"Professional Cover Letter Templates\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/fad76600-17bb-4e20-b22b-bef5020bec74.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcover-letter&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 25 Feb 2022 12:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3f347702-d7e9-4e59-9fe4-be4cd7bad191.png","linkMd5":"e8752d3e42b0a804666741cce5407e4b","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn12@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-26-48-586_95f569c610ab9f5a.webp","destWidth":620,"destHeight":60,"sourceBytes":5960,"destBytes":9302,"author":"joetting@hubspot.com (Jami Oetting)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3f347702-d7e9-4e59-9fe4-be4cd7bad191.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn12@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-26-48-586_95f569c610ab9f5a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Writing%20a%20Cover%20Letter.jpeg?width=600&name=The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Writing%20a%20Cover%20Letter.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn13@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-26-56-933_4d7f07e9858f4c59.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Writing%20a%20Cover%20Letter-1.jpeg?width=500&name=The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Writing%20a%20Cover%20Letter-1.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn36@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-26-53-641_041e76b7f47d241f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Writing%20a%20Cover%20Letter.png?width=250&name=The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Writing%20a%20Cover%20Letter.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn26@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-26-56-309_8322f899eb21dab1.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/fad76600-17bb-4e20-b22b-bef5020bec74.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn52@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-26-52-252_2eba16820dbd98dd.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcover-letter&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn99@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-26-52-849_7c11e437143638b6.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647246408220},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:26:48","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:26:48","title":"5 Reasons Why Brands Lose Followers on Instagram [HubSpot Blog Data]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/losing-followers-instagram","description":"<p>According to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/hubspot-blog-social-media-marketing-report\">HubSpot Blog Research</a>, 14% of <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/instagram-marketing\">Instagram marketers</a> report losing followers from 2020 to 2021.</p> \n<p>If you’re a part of that 14%, you may be panicking trying to figure out what’s causing the decline.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=9294dd33-9827-4b39-8fc2-b7fbece7fdb9&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Data: Instagram Engagement Report [2022 Version]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/9294dd33-9827-4b39-8fc2-b7fbece7fdb9.png\"></a></p> \n<p>Don’t fret – we’ve got you covered. Below, we’re covering the top reasons why brands lose followers on Instagram and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/gain-instagram-followers\">how to regain them</a>.</p> \n<h2>Why am I losing so many followers on Instagram?</h2> \n<h3>1. You’re not posting often enough or posting too much.</h3> \n<p>When <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/hubspot-blog-social-media-marketing-report\">we surveyed Instagram marketers</a>, 40% said that not posting enough is the number one reason why brands lose followers.</p> \n<p>Meanwhile, 33% said posting too much can have the same impact.</p> \n<p>When it comes to posting, it’s all about striking the right balance. You want to post enough to make sure you’re reaching your target audience and not disappearing in a sea of posts.</p> \n<p>However, you don’t want to post too much that your audience is getting flooded with your posts all over their timeline.</p> \n<p>Here are a few guidelines: First, post at least once a day on the platform – whether it’s on Instagram Stories, Reels, or in-feed. If you have to choose, Stories is probably the best option as marketers surveyed say it’s the second-best way to gain followers behind going live.</p> \n<p>Second, share an in-feed post two to three times a week. You can increase this cadence based on how your audience responds but you probably shouldn’t lower it.</p> \n<h3>2. You’re being too sales-y.</h3> \n<p>The second most popular reason why your brand is losing followers is that your content is too focused on selling, according to 39% of Instagram marketers surveyed.</p> \n<p>Our survey found that content centered around a brand’s products/services is leveraged by 39% of IG marketers and has the second-highest ROI.</p> \n<p>However, if it’s the only type of content you post, you might alienate your audience.</p> \n<p>Again, balance is the keyword here.</p> \n<p>In addition to posts that highlight your products and/or services, you should also post content that:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Reflects your brand values.</li> \n <li>Invites conversation.</li> \n <li>Builds community.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Another effective content strategy? Make your audience laugh.</p> \n<p>Our survey revealed that funny content is the most effective for getting followers, shares, and engagement on Instagram.</p> \n<h3>3. You had bot followers.</h3> \n<p>If you <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/buy-instagram-followers\">purchased bot followers</a>, you’ll be in for a rude awakening when they all disappear and your follower list tanks.</p> \n<p>39% of Instagram marketers surveyed say this is the third most popular reason why brands lose followers.</p> \n<p>While it’s tempting to buy bots to give the semblance of a strong follower base, this practice will only hurt you in the long run.</p> \n<p>Instead, focus on building a follower list organically through a consistent posting schedule, sharing valuable content, following trends, and listening to your data.</p> \n<p>It doesn’t have to take long either. Only 1% of marketers we surveyed say it took over a year to grow their followers by 1K. Most marketers (65%) said it took anywhere from one to six months.</p> \n<p>And 13% actually did it in less than a month.</p> \n<p>This is all to say that see this loss in followers as an opportunity to rebuild your Instagram page and get more reliable data on your audience.</p> \n<div>\n <iframe style=\"border: none; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\" src=\"https://listen.hubspot.com/embed/v2/smallPlayer/d40176e3\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\"></iframe>  \n</div> \n<h3>4. You don’t have a consistent aesthetic and voice.</h3> \n<p>One thing audiences love is consistency.</p> \n<p>Consistency in your branding and your creative assets is key in building strong brand recognition. In addition, consistency also helps build a visually appealing profile.</p> \n<p>If a user visits your profile and every post looks like it was created by a different brand, they’ll have a hard time understanding what your brand is all about and choose to unfollow you.</p> \n<p>Personally, if I’m scrolling and I notice a brand I don’t recognize on my timeline, I’ll visit their profile and if I don’t recognize their last few posts, I’ll likely unfollow them. I imagine many users behave the same way.</p> \n<p>With this in mind, figure out what your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/agency/develop-brand-identity\">brand identity </a>and visual aesthetic are early on in your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/branding\">branding</a> process.</p> \n<p>From there, you can leverage tools like Canva to build a visual profile that stays consistent across all platforms.</p> \n<h3>5. Your audience has evolved and you’re not keeping up.</h3> \n<p>It would be so easy to market to our audiences if their interests and behaviors always stayed the same.</p> \n<p>Unfortunately, that isn’t the case.</p> \n<p>This requires marketers to stay on top of what attracts and retains their audiences. One of the most effective ways to do this is by relying on your data. What is it telling you?</p> \n<p>Say you’re HubSpot and our feed consists of customer success stories, product highlights, company values, and industry trends.</p> \n<p>Perhaps content surrounding industry trends used to perform very well but you’ve noticed a slow decline over the past six months. Perhaps your audience is not as interested in this content or the format in which it’s being presented.</p> \n<p>Maybe if you used to leverage images, you should consider switching to video.</p> \n<p>Your Instagram strategy should be steered by what your data is telling you. If you don’t use it, you will quickly lose touch with your audience and slowly see your follower list decrease.</p> \n<p>Losing Instagram followers can be a scary reality to face. However, once you identify the reason behind the decline, you can address it and regain them.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=b1268983-9da6-4d67-9d3a-cfef2d9f3cff&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"Improve your website with effective technical SEO. Start by conducting this  audit.&nbsp;&nbsp;\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b1268983-9da6-4d67-9d3a-cfef2d9f3cff.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Flosing-followers-instagram&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 07 Mar 2022 12:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/9294dd33-9827-4b39-8fc2-b7fbece7fdb9.png","linkMd5":"40d80c00a36ea0267778a0f3442a7f5e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn99@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-26-48-650_7e54748a32aeb250.webp","destWidth":500,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":5814,"destBytes":7884,"author":"mbretous@hubspot.com (Martina Bretous)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/9294dd33-9827-4b39-8fc2-b7fbece7fdb9.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn99@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-26-48-650_7e54748a32aeb250.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b1268983-9da6-4d67-9d3a-cfef2d9f3cff.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn92@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-26-49-811_a4245cc995397db3.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Flosing-followers-instagram&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn72@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-26-52-350_d945164818aae1ca.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647246408205},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:26:48","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:26:48","title":"How Conversion Funnels Create a Better Customer Journey + How to Optimize Yours","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/conversion-funnel","description":"<p>Conversion funnels are a fundamental concept in sales. Personally, I like to visualize the funnel as that big scary slide you wanted to try as a kid. You saw your friends whizzing down, which sparked your interest. You watched how much fun they were having, doing your research. And then the benefits of having fun outweighed your fear, so you climbed up and flew down.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Customers take a similar journey through your company's conversion funnel when evaluating whether or not to buy from you. You have to pique their interest, build trust, and encourage them to take action.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=12501f7c-8e26-4e3c-9642-7afbe078156a&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download Now: Free Customer Journey Map Templates\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/12501f7c-8e26-4e3c-9642-7afbe078156a.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<p>In this post, I'll explain what conversion funnels are and how they impact your customer journey. Then, you'll learn how to optimize your funnel to increase the number of people who make it to your conversion point at the bottom.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>All leads begin at the top of the funnel. As they learn more about your business, they move down and get closer to purchasing your product or service. This conversion process is called a funnel because companies often have more leads than they do customers, making the top of the funnel a larger pool of people than the bottom.</p> \n<p>Understanding how people flow through your conversion funnel is essential to being an effective marketer or salesperson because it helps you engage leads, answer questions about your business, and address concerns. It also lets you organize leads into categories and create <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/customer-touchpoints\">customer touchpoints</a> that can entice each group to convert.</p> \n<p>That's why every funnel should be designed for how your customers buy, not how you sell. The focus is on providing such a great experience within the customer journey that you convince them to convert.</p> \n<p>Before diving into the details of how to analyze and optimize your funnel, we need to talk about an important aspect of this process: the customer journey.</p> \n<h3>Customer Journey</h3> \n<p>The customer journey complements the conversion funnel, but it's not the same thing. Unlike the generalized, linear conversion funnel, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/customer-journey-map\">customer journey maps</a> show the individual and circuitous paths people take from the moment they discover your brand to the time they make a purchase.</p> \n<p>Let's say you're a food blogger who sells cookbooks. Here's how your customers' journeys can differ.</p> \n<ul> \n <li> <p><strong>Customer A</strong> sees and clicks on your banner ad, visits your blog, reads an article, signs up for your newsletter, gets a discount email, and purchases a cookbook.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><strong>Customer B</strong> sees your cookbook in a bookshop, buys it, makes the recipes, visits your blog, and subscribes to your newsletter.</p> </li> \n</ul> \n<p>The outcomes for Customer A and B are essentially the same, but the journeys and touchpoints are different. So if you know the different ways people enter your funnel, you can optimize for those entry points. That way, you can meet potential buyers where they are and entice them to convert.</p> \n<p>That said, most funnels have similar points that ultimately lead to conversion. Let’s take a closer look at each stage of this process.</p> \n<h2>Conversion Funnel Stages</h2> \n<p>The top-middle-bottom funnel is a classic model used by sales teams, which focuses on sparking interest, informing potential customers, convincing them to purchase, and building loyalty so they become repeat buyers.</p> \n<p>Traditional Conversion Funnel Stages</p> \n<ul> \n <li> <p><strong>Top of the funnel (TOFU)</strong>: This is the awareness phase. A potential customer enters the TOFU when they engage with your brand, oftentimes through your website, an ad, an email, or social media.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><strong>Middle of the funnel (MOFU)</strong>: This is the consideration phase. The potential customer knows about your brand and engages with it in order to learn more. They may sign up for your email newsletter, follow you on social media, or download guides and templates.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><strong>Bottom of the funnel (BOFU)</strong>: This is the conversion phase. A prospect is here right before they purchase, which means you've given them good information and relevant touchpoints. Help them convert by making it easy to purchase, offering a trial, outlining pricing, or sending a discount for their abandoned shopping cart.</p> </li> \n</ul> \n<p>Let’s see what this looks like visually in the examples below.</p> \n<h3>Conversion Funnel Examples</h3> \n<p>HubSpot started off with the traditional conversion funnel structure, using marketing efforts to serve as the top of the funnel. Those leads were then passed further down the funnel to the sales team.</p> \n<p>While some conversion funnels are simple, others can be incredibly complex. There are several conversion models you can use to suit your business needs, ranging from a simple three-stage funnel for smaller operations to complex, multi-stage sales funnels for enterprise-level companies. Let’s explore some of the most common models.</p> \n<h4>Three-Stage Marketing Funnel</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Basic%20Funnel.jpg?width=650&amp;name=Basic%20Funnel.jpg\" alt=\"Conversion funnel example basic\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" width=\"650\"></p> \n<ul> \n <li> <p><strong>Awareness</strong>: Get visitors to your website. Attract them with quality blog posts or through social media.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><strong>Consideration</strong>: Use that great content to entice your new visitors to sign up for your newsletter.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><strong>Conversion</strong>: Now that prospects are familiar with your brand, persuade them to make a purchase by offering a discount code for first-time buyers.</p> </li> \n</ul> \n<h4>AIDA Funnel</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/AIDA%20Funnel.jpg?width=650&amp;name=AIDA%20Funnel.jpg\" alt=\"Conversion funnel example AIDA\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" width=\"650\">Sometimes called a “purchase funnel,” the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/aida-model\">AIDA model</a> expands on the basic three-stage structure.</p> \n<ul> \n <li> <p><strong>Attention</strong>: In addition to blog posts and social media, you can use targeted ads to draw visitors to your website.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><strong>Interest</strong>: Pique the prospect’s interest in your product by showcasing the goods. Use case studies to show how your product has helped other businesses. Have notable press mentions? You’ll want to showcase those as well.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><strong>Desire</strong>: Your prospects like you, now you must make them want you. Gain their trust and create an emotional connection. Continue to serve them content that helps them visualize how your product would fit into their lives and why they need it.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><strong>Action</strong>: Now’s your chance to get them to convert. One way is to offer a free ebook, trial, or tool that’s only accessible if they fill out a form with their contact information. If your goal is to get them to purchase a product, you could give them a promotional offer to persuade them to buy.</p> </li> \n</ul> \n<p>The detail of your funnel depends on your sales process — the longer your sales cycle, the more complex your funnel. If you have a short sales cycle, your funnel tends to be simpler.</p> \n<p>Think about how long it takes to sell $2,000 B2B software versus a $20 t-shirt. The software purchase usually requires months of sales calls, marketing materials, FAQs, and demos. Each of those is a specific point in your conversion funnel. But potential buyers may only need five minutes to figure out that the t-shirt is the right color and fit before purchasing. The touchpoints required here are taking it off the rack and trying it on.</p> \n<p>To figure out how complex your funnel is, you can look at the data and perform an analysis. This will help you flush out each part of your customer journey to create a unique visual representation of your funnel.</p> \n<h2>Conversion Funnel Analysis</h2> \n<p>Funnels are full of barriers and friction. Analyzing your funnel helps you visualize the flow of potential customers across each point.</p> \n<p>You can see key traffic sources and high-exit pages to get a feel for how people end up in each stage of the funnel.</p> \n<p>It's also a way to discover barriers that cause people to leave a page before they convert. If you see a high drop-off rate on one page, for example, you'll know to prioritize that as you work toward optimizing your funnel.</p> \n<p>To understand your funnel, follow these steps for in-depth analysis:</p> \n<h3>1. Look for high-traffic pages with high drop-off and conversion rates.</h3> \n<p>High-traffic pages hold a plethora of useful information. Not only are these the pages people see the most, but they're also where people decide to stay or go. Look at the pages where people drop off (aka leave) and where they convert (take your intended action). Some metrics to collect are:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/cost-per-acquisition\">Cost Per Acquisition</a> (CPA)</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/how-to-calculate-customer-lifetime-value\">Customer Lifetime Value</a> (CLV)</li> \n <li>Drop-Off Rate</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-increase-conversion-rate\">Conversion Rate</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/definition-marketing-qualified-lead-mql-under-100-sr\">Number of Marketing Qualified Leads</a> (MQLs)</li> \n <li>MQLs to Customer Conversion Rate</li> \n <li>Conversion Rate Per Channel (i.e., social, email, and paid search)</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>2. Discover where your best customers come from.</h3> \n<p>Not all leads are the same. Some people drop off near the top of the funnel while others make it all the way down. That's why tracking leads is so important. When you know where your high-quality leads come from, you can analyze that touchpoint or channel to see what you're doing right. Ask yourself:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>How is this touchpoint different from other touchpoints?</li> \n <li>What information is resonating with people?</li> \n <li>What are the barriers or friction (if any)?</li> \n <li>How many steps do people have to go through before converting?</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Identifying what you're doing right in your funnel is just as important as figuring out what you're doing wrong. If you need help digging into the data, check out these <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/sales-funnel-software\">sales funnel tools</a> or look into heatmap and session recording tools for information on how people navigate your pages.</p> \n<h3>3. Create an optimization plan.</h3> \n<p>After you figure out where people are dropping off and converting, it's time to make an optimization plan. This should include the goals you want to focus on (i.e., more leads, newsletter signups, demos, or software purchases).</p> \n<p>Goals let you determine what you want from each touchpoint within your funnel so you can measure whether it's working or not.</p> \n<p>After your funnel analysis, you'll have a list of priority touchpoints that need to be optimized. Make sure to focus on the areas with the biggest drop-off rates first.</p> \n<h2>Conversion Funnel Optimization</h2> \n<p>Every part of your conversion funnel can be optimized to increase the number of people who turn into customers. Think of conversation funnel optimization as finding out what motivates, blocks, and persuades people so you can give them the best experience possible on their unique journey.</p> \n<p>To optimize effectively, you need to think about how to give each customer what they want at each phase of the funnel. Using the phases outlined above, here's what to consider at each step along the customer journey.</p> \n<h3>1. TOFU: Awareness</h3> \n<p>Issues at the top of your funnel? Take a look at how you attract new leads. Compare every channel that brings in customers (i.e., social media, search engines, your blog, and paid ads) to see which attracts the most people.</p> \n<p>If you're unsure how customers found you, send out a survey to ask. Look for trends in how people find new brands and put more effort into your best channels. Just make sure you're attracting the people in your target audience.</p> \n<h3>2. MOFU: Consideration</h3> \n<p>Potential customers made it to the middle of your funnel, but it's your job to keep them moving toward the bottom.</p> \n<p>If you're having trouble with this phase, look at how people learn about your business and engage with your site. Is it easy for people to navigate your site? Or sign up for your email list? Do you have relevant, rich content? Do you offer pricing and product information? Is it easy to get questions answered?</p> \n<p>Depending on your barriers, consider these ideas for improvement:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Product videos and photos</li> \n <li>FAQ page</li> \n <li>Whitepapers, case studies, or blog posts</li> \n <li>Filters and search options</li> \n <li>Newsletter capture</li> \n <li>Discounts</li> \n <li>Check pages for loading speed and broken elements</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>3. BOFU: Conversion</h3> \n<p>As the final stop for potential buyers, this is the phase to turn them into customers. You should remove as much friction as possible and encourage people to take the final steps to convert.</p> \n<p>Some ways to optimize this final part of your funnel is to make sure product or service pages are fully built out with interesting descriptions, videos, and photos. Consider your checkout process to see if people have issues with payments or abandoned carts. Make it simple for people to compare pricing and clearly outline all product features. You can also send specific BOFU emails or create ads to remind people of their desire to convert.</p> \n<p>Think your job is done once a customer converts? Wrong. While you may have pulled a customer through your conversion funnel, there are plenty of opportunities to re-engage them. Not only is <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/customer-satisfaction?\">customer retention</a> essential for growing your business, but it's <a href=\"https://www.outboundengine.com/blog/customer-retention-marketing-vs-customer-acquisition-marketing/\">five times more expensive</a> to acquire a new customer than to retain a current customer.</p> \n<p>So, once your customers make it through the funnel, invite them to sign up for a new webinar series, download additional templates, send promotions, join a loyalty club, or follow you on social media.</p> \n<h2>Conversion Funnels Shouldn’t Be Business Models</h2> \n<p>While conversion funnels are very effective for demonstrating the customer journey for a one-time purchase, they are not a substitute for creating a holistic business model. Relying on a funnel as your business model creates a lack of alignment between each stage of the customer experience.</p> \n<p>HubSpot transitioned to thinking of the customer journey as less of a funnel and more of a <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/flywheel?\">flywheel</a> — building more momentum as customers move through it.</p> \n<div class=\"hs-embed-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; width: 100%; height: auto; padding: 0px; max-width: 560px; max-height: 316.089px; min-width: 256px; display: block; margin: auto;\">\n <div class=\"hs-embed-content-wrapper\">\n  <div style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.5%; margin: 0px;\">\n   <iframe width=\"200\" height=\"113\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/_aA_Slv9oC0?feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen style=\"position: absolute; top: 0px; left: 0px; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\"></iframe>\n  </div>\n </div>\n</div> \n<p>With the flywheel model, the momentum of your happy customers is used to drive referrals and repeat sales. It’s not a linear beginning and end, but rather a continuous cycle that allows you to generate more business.</p> \n<h2>Tailor Your Funnel to the Customer</h2> \n<p>While the customer journey is more complex than my slide analogy, understanding how conversion funnels work can improve this flow. It can help you optimize your funnel, attract more leads, convert them to customers, and boost your bottom line. But all that requires reducing as much friction as possible.</p> \n<p>Find what makes sense for your particular sales cycle and use your existing content and channels to stay in touch. Make sure customers value your business and want to come back because you never know who they'll introduce to the top of that funnel.</p> \n<p><em>This article was originally published May 5, 2021, and has been updated for </em>comprehensiveness<em>.</em></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=dfcc1cf6-fca7-455f-9c43-26ff2fba10ed&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"Apply for a job, keep track of important information, and prepare for an  interview with the help of this free job seekers kit.\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/dfcc1cf6-fca7-455f-9c43-26ff2fba10ed.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fconversion-funnel&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 24 Feb 2022 12:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/12501f7c-8e26-4e3c-9642-7afbe078156a.png","linkMd5":"83e04b24e363b27bf4e6bba7237d86b4","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn27@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-26-48-382_29667f68bce7df45.webp","destWidth":494,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":3880,"destBytes":7698,"author":"Katrina Kirsch","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/12501f7c-8e26-4e3c-9642-7afbe078156a.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn27@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-26-48-382_29667f68bce7df45.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Basic%20Funnel.jpg?width=650&name=Basic%20Funnel.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn63@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-26-55-850_7733d454dae1373d.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/AIDA%20Funnel.jpg?width=650&name=AIDA%20Funnel.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn8@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-26-50-158_6acde0ddef916607.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/dfcc1cf6-fca7-455f-9c43-26ff2fba10ed.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn38@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-26-54-869_a6a20c230b966a35.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fconversion-funnel&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn3@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-26-55-870_a4b1fa676610a4d6.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647246408224},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:26:48","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:26:48","title":"How to Manage YouTube Comments","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-comments","description":"<p>The YouTube section can be a fun place to engage your audience and continue the conversation. However, it can also be a source of negativity.</p>  \n<p>At its best, it can build community and at its worst, it can harm your brand and distract viewers from your content.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=b33cfd44-133a-49e3-a943-086c5679d485&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"→ Free Templates: How to Use YouTube for Business [Download Now]\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/b33cfd44-133a-49e3-a943-086c5679d485.png\"></a></p> \n<p>With this in mind, it’s important to know how to manage your comments. Discover how to delete and disable comments plus troubleshoot a common problem.</p> \n<h2>How to Turn on Comments on YouTube</h2> \n<p>When it comes to comments on a video-level, there are four main settings you can have:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Allow all comments</strong> – This allows user comments to be immediately visible.</li> \n <li><strong>Hold all comments for review – </strong>This requires you to approve every comment before it will show in the comment section. It will stay in the review tab for up to 60 days</li> \n <li><strong>Hold some comments for review – </strong>If some comments are flagged as potentially inappropriate by YouTube’s system, they will be hidden and held for review. You can also create a blocked words list that will hold comments containing or closely matching these terms.</li> \n <li><strong>Turn off comments – </strong>This prevents any user from leaving comments under your video.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>When you start a channel on YouTube, the default comment setting is to hold inappropriate comments for review and allow all other comments to show immediately under the video.</p> \n<p>If you had changed your settings and now want videos on your channel to display comments, you can do so by following these steps:</p> \n<ol start=\"1\"> \n <li> <h3>Access your Studio dashboard and click on \"Settings.\"</h3> <img alt=\"how to turn on comments on YouTube step 1\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Manage%20YouTube%20Comments.jpeg?width=250&amp;name=How%20to%20Manage%20YouTube%20Comments.jpeg\" title=\"\" width=\"250\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 250px;\"></li> \n <li> <h3>Select \"Upload defaults.\"</h3> <img alt=\"how to turn on comments on YouTube step 2\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Manage%20YouTube%20Comments-Feb-03-2022-05-25-26-74-AM.jpeg?width=250&amp;name=How%20to%20Manage%20YouTube%20Comments-Feb-03-2022-05-25-26-74-AM.jpeg\" title=\"\" width=\"250\" style=\"width: 250px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></li> \n <li> <h3>Navigate to the \"Advanced Settings\" tab.</h3> <img alt=\"how to turn on comments on YouTube step 3\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Manage%20YouTube%20Comments-1.jpeg?width=450&amp;name=How%20to%20Manage%20YouTube%20Comments-1.jpeg\" title=\"\" width=\"450\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 450px;\"></li> \n <li> <h3>Scroll down to the \"Comments\" section and select \"Allow all comments.\"</h3> <img alt=\"how to turn on comments on YouTube step 4\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Manage%20YouTube%20Comments-3.jpeg?width=450&amp;name=How%20to%20Manage%20YouTube%20Comments-3.jpeg\" title=\"\" width=\"450\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 450px;\"></li> \n <li> <h3>Scroll down to the \"Comments\" section.</h3> </li> \n</ol> \n<p><img alt=\"how to turn on comments on YouTube step 5\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Manage%20YouTube%20Comments.png?width=303&amp;name=How%20to%20Manage%20YouTube%20Comments.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; width: 303px; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" title=\"\" width=\"303\"></p> \n<h2>How to Delete YouTube Comments</h2> \n<p>When it comes to deleting YouTube comments, the rule of thumb is to use it with intention.</p> \n<p>It’s not sustainable or effective to delete every comment your brand disagrees with.</p> \n<p>You might ask, \"<em>Well, what if a comment says something false or damaging about our brand?</em>\" In this case, responding to the comment may be a more effective strategy. This way, you address the comment and can redirect viewers.</p> \n<p>To save time, focus on deleting comments that are hateful, explicit, or spammy.</p> \n<ol start=\"1\"> \n <li> <h3>Open YouTube Studio.</h3> </li> \n <li> <h3>Select \"Comments\" from the sidebar.</h3> </li> \n <li> <h3>Sift through your published comments.</h3> </li> \n <li> <h3>Tap \"More\" to see the option to remove the comment.</h3> </li> \n <li> <h3>Delete and return to the \"Comments\" dashboard.</h3> </li> \n</ol> \n<h2>How to Turn Off Comments on YouTube</h2> \n<p><img alt=\"youtube comment section turned off\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Manage%20YouTube%20Comments-Feb-03-2022-05-25-26-29-AM.jpeg\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" title=\"youtube comment section turned off\"></p> \n<p>There are two ways to turn off comments on YouTube: at the channel-level and at the video-level.</p> \n<p>Here’s how it works at the channel level:</p> \n<ol start=\"1\"> \n <li> <h3>Access your Studio dashboard and click on \"Settings.\"</h3> <img alt=\"how to turn off comments on youtube step 1\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Manage%20YouTube%20Comments.jpeg?width=250&amp;name=How%20to%20Manage%20YouTube%20Comments.jpeg\" title=\"\" width=\"250\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 250px;\"></li> \n <li> <h3>Select \"Upload defaults.\"</h3> <img alt=\"how to turn off comments on youtube step 2\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Manage%20YouTube%20Comments-1.jpeg?width=450&amp;name=How%20to%20Manage%20YouTube%20Comments-1.jpeg\" title=\"\" width=\"450\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 450px;\"></li> \n <li> <h3>Navigate to the \"Advanced Settings\" tab.</h3> </li> \n</ol> \n<p><img alt=\"how to turn off comments on youtube step 3\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Manage%20YouTube%20Comments-3.jpeg?width=450&amp;name=How%20to%20Manage%20YouTube%20Comments-3.jpeg\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 450px;\" title=\"\" width=\"450\"></p> \n<h3>4. Scroll down to the Comments section.</h3> \n<img alt=\"how to turn off comments on youtube step 4\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Manage%20YouTube%20Comments-Feb-03-2022-05-25-25-95-AM.jpeg?width=450&amp;name=How%20to%20Manage%20YouTube%20Comments-Feb-03-2022-05-25-25-95-AM.jpeg\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 450px;\" title=\"\" width=\"450\"> \n<h3>5. Select \"Disable comments\" and click \"Save.\"</h3> \n<p><img alt=\"how to turn off comments on youtube step 5\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Manage%20YouTube%20Comments-4.jpeg?width=450&amp;name=How%20to%20Manage%20YouTube%20Comments-4.jpeg\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 450px;\" title=\"\" width=\"450\"></p> \n<p>To turn off comments on a specific video, you can do this during the uploading process.</p> \n<ol start=\"1\"> \n <li> <h3>In the \"Details\" tab of the upload, scroll all the way down to \"Show more.\"</h3> <img alt=\"turn off comments on a specific video step 1\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Manage%20YouTube%20Comments-Feb-03-2022-05-25-26-98-AM.jpeg\" title=\"\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\"></li> \n <li> <h3>Under \"Comments and Ratings,\" choose \"Disable comments.\"</h3> </li> \n</ol> \n<p><img alt=\"turn off comments on a specific video step 2\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Manage%20YouTube%20Comments-2.jpeg?width=415&amp;name=How%20to%20Manage%20YouTube%20Comments-2.jpeg\" style=\"margin-left: auto; width: 415px; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" title=\"\" width=\"415\"></p> \n<p>Note that you can change this setting later after uploading your video.</p> \n<h2>Troubleshooting: Youtube Comments Not Loading</h2> \n<p>If your YouTube comments aren’t loading, there’s a good chance it’s your internet connection. If your connection is slow and unreliable, the comment section may not load properly.</p> \n<p>Another reason why your comments may not load is if you’re using a different viewport. While on the web app, YouTube comments load automatically when you scroll, on the mobile app, you must tap to see the comments section.</p> \n<p>Lastly, certain browser extensions may affect how elements load on a page. As such, test disabling your browser extensions if your comments are not loading.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=7e8681b3-9162-45a4-b6a1-f33ff244a78a&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \"
