\">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 02 Mar 2022 12:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/ed40e380-bf04-4fea-b0c3-257696630e08.png","linkMd5":"d5938863511e5e5025f9df1f42d22700","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn39@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-26-48-384_34bd683f552faea2.webp","destWidth":611,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":7061,"destBytes":9908,"author":"Brittany Garlin","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/ed40e380-bf04-4fea-b0c3-257696630e08.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn39@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-26-48-384_34bd683f552faea2.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Facebook-Sales-Funnel.png?width=1104&name=Facebook-Sales-Funnel.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn10@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-26-50-527_23fed7923acc4d96.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/ROAS-Formula.png?width=760&name=ROAS-Formula.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn13@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-26-49-384_b18e309465d1b081.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Facebook-Ad-Targeting.jpg?width=1600&name=Facebook-Ad-Targeting.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn45@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-26-57-111_a7027f0933833d23.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/4f0eef09-2c33-43c7-9dee-7dde3ae4071e.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn67@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-26-52-298_abc294f6e8ab83dc.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ffacebook-ads-incrementality&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn77@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-26-53-090_f01ad25c68735200.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647246408214},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:26:48","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:26:48","title":"Everything You Need to Know About Marketing Operations in One Place","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/marketing-operations","description":"<p>One of my favorite movies is \"<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/School_of_Rock\">School of Rock</a>,\" which also happens to be one of 2003's best films. In the movie, Jack Black poses as a substitute teacher at a private school, and, after noticing the students are musically talented, he turns the 10-year-olds into a fully-fledged rock band.</p>  \n<p>When assigning roles to the students, he approaches the class president and deems her band manager because she had the organizational skills needed to help the band run smoothly. \"Summer,\" he says, \"You're in charge of the whole thing.\"</p> \n<p>When I think about marketing operations, I think of this quote — without a team, businesses that depend on technology would have a less-than-seamless experience carrying out their duties. In this post, you’ll learn more about marketing operations and why these teams are essential to a business.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=34155d81-37a6-4910-a596-3a77b9e5a99f&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Access Now: The State of Marketing Ops Professionals\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/34155d81-37a6-4910-a596-3a77b9e5a99f.png\" align=\"middle\"></a></p> \n<a></a> \n<p></p> \n<p>The people involved in marketing operations build a foundation that reinforces and supports marketing efforts. It makes it easier to achieve goals by implementing systems to ensure marketers are best equipped to succeed at their jobs.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img alt=\"what is marketing operations\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Everything%20You%20Need%20to%20Know%20About%20Marketing%20Operations%20in%20One%20Place.png?width=624&amp;height=624&amp;name=Everything%20You%20Need%20to%20Know%20About%20Marketing%20Operations%20in%20One%20Place.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" title=\"\" width=\"624\" height=\"624\"></p> \n<a></a> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Why is marketing operations important?</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.b2bmarketing.net/en/resources/articles/our-survey-stats-revealed-93-b2b-marketers-says-marketing-operations-function\">93% of B2B marketers</a> say the marketing operation’s function is important or critical to delivering digital transformation. After all, without marketing operations, it would be tough for marketing teams to complete essential activities effectively because they enable other marketing departments to bring cohesion to campaigns and processes.</p> \n<p>For example, as technology is necessary to carry out most marketing tasks, a team to manage the complexity of that technology and ensure it works as it should is also necessary — <em>which is exactly what MOps is</em>.</p> \n<p>Here are some examples of situations that can be rectified by having a marketing operations team:</p> \n<table> \n <tbody> \n  <tr> \n   <td>Problem</td> \n   <td>MOps Solution</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td>Your investments in marketing technology don’t provide the solutions you thought they would.</td> \n   <td>MOps ensure that teams are enabled by technology solutions and eliminate tech debt.</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td>You want to streamline data reporting and metrics tracking to understand ROI.</td> \n   <td>MOps focus on processes and systems for data reporting to enable teams.</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td>Strategy execution is a timely process, and you want to lower the amount of time it takes from start to finish.</td> \n   <td>MOps helps team improve processes to become more efficient.</td> \n  </tr> \n </tbody> \n</table> \n<p>At HubSpot, the marketing ops team is responsible for supporting the systems and processes that enable the marketing team to perform optimally in their roles. This includes everything from permissions, conversational marketing, user data, forms, and email operations.</p> \n<p>An essential function of how well a marketing ops team works is proper management.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>As a point of reference, marketing operations is the process of strategizing and optimizing, while marketing ops management defines how that strategizing and optimizing will happen.</p> \n<p>Since marketing operations management aims to increase efficiency, ops teams often have a hand in content planning and campaign analysis.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Role of Marketing Operations</h3> \n<p>Marketing operations is a combination of different processes that contribute to marketing team success. The role of marketing ops encompasses:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Project management</li> \n <li>Strategic planning</li> \n <li>Organization benchmarking</li> \n <li>Workflow process development and documentation</li> \n <li>Customer, market, and competitive intelligence research</li> \n <li>Performance measurement</li> \n <li>Campaign analysis and reporting</li> \n <li>Data management</li> \n <li>Process development and implementation</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Much of the role of marketing operations comes down to strategic decision making for key <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/digital-strategy-guide\">marketing strategies</a>, and seeing those projects through to completion based on analyzed data.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Marketing Operations Strategy</h2> \n<p>Marketing ops team members need to have an expansive skillset. Some of the typical activities this department deals with are email operations, systems analysis, customer data and marketing, user operations, and lead rotation.</p> \n<p>All of these roles come together to align the process and platforms needed to carry out marketing tasks for the greater marketing team.</p> \n<p>When thinking about a marketing ops strategy, consider the problems the marketing ops team needs to solve, taking into account the needs of customers, stakeholders, and the employees of your company.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p></p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">1. Identify what you want your operations strategy to accomplish for stakeholders.</h3> \n<p>Firstly, you need to effectively communicate and involve your stakeholder(s) when trying to create your marketing operations strategy. By doing so, you can better align the team and work toward solving high-level needs and priorities that may not be explicitly clear beforehand.</p> \n<p>This is where the importance of internal <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/34212/how-to-create-a-service-level-agreement-sla-for-better-sales-marketing-alignment.aspx\">service level agreements (SLAs)</a> come in. These contracts establish a set of deliverables to another party that sets clear expectations and mitigates issues that may arise.</p> \n<p>For instance, key stakeholders might want to make email marketing a more valuable process. The marketing ops team would then be responsible for the processes and systems that support this endeavor, ensuring that:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>The organization has effective email marketing technology</li> \n <li>The marketing team is enabled to send emails and create improved content offers</li> \n <li>The sales team is enabled and empowered to source quality leads</li> \n <li>All parties have what they need and are communicating effectively during each step of the process</li> \n</ul> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">2. Figure out a measurable metric to determine the success of your strategy.</h3> \n<p>The next step in strategizing is to identify how the team would <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/customer-success-metrics\">measure the success</a> of the project. When you figure out a measurable metric, you'll be able to keep track of the strategy's success as your team works through the plan. The metric will remind your team of the goal you want to accomplish and what stakeholders want to see as a result of your plan.</p> \n<p>In this example, the team might conclude, \"Click-through rate and total number of clicks are how we want to measure the value that email marketing brings to the business. We will calculate the click-through rate by dividing the number of clicks in a month by the number of unique email recipient impressions in a month and multiply it by 100 for the percentage.\"</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">3. Define your goal(s) using the SMART format.</h3> \n<p>With your metrics identified, the next step in defining a marketing ops strategy is outlining significant <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-write-a-smart-goal-template\">SMART goals</a>. This format is important because it gives your team a better sense of direction and organization in strategy execution.</p> \n<p>An example of an effective SMART goal is, “We will increase total clicks from email by 25% in one year.” because it’s:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Specific</strong>: It’s not a broad goal; it’s focused on email marketing.</li> \n <li><strong>Measurable</strong>: It can be measured by a concrete metric (total clicks).</li> \n <li><strong>Attainable</strong>: It’s possible to see this level of change in the business.</li> \n <li><strong>Realistic</strong>: The team is capable of working toward 25% of improvement.</li> \n <li><strong>Time-bound</strong>: This goal has a set duration of one year.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">4. If needed, communicate how colleagues can take part in refining your strategy.</h3> \n<p>With the goal and metrics identified, your next step is to outline what this change would mean for affected colleagues, such as the team members who create and distribute email marketing messages.</p> \n<p>The team might conclude that \"Marketers can expect an easier email guideline process, a more effective format, and to receive a form to offer input about how to make that happen.\"</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">5. Determine actionable steps in your plan that will help you reach your goals.</h3> \n<p>Determining actionable steps will help your marketing ops team figure out what needs to be done, identify the resources required to see success, and stay organized as they work through their tasks.</p> \n<p>A marketing ops professional will need to run these steps by the stakeholders who actually influence the plan. For instance, they would be communicating steps to reach the previously stated SMART goal like:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Switching to a more efficient email technology provider.</li> \n <li>Ensuring that the data being used to measure these goals is clean and accurate.</li> \n <li>Enabling the marketing team to source more quality leads.</li> \n <li>Enabling the sales team with better templates or sales enablement resources.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>With these steps communicated, stakeholders can provide assistance or suggestions where it’s needed, and the marketing ops team can get closer to execution.</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: bold;\">6. Assign team members to specific tasks that will contribute to the completion of your goals.</h3> \n<p>Having that set in place, what's next for the marketing ops team is to assign team members specific tasks to help them achieve their goals. For instance, one team member might be in charge of redefining email marketing contact lists. Another might be in charge of auditing the current workflows in place for email marketing.</p> \n<p>As team members complete these tasks, they would check them off in a centralized space so the entire team can stay updated on the project’s status.</p> \n<p>Marketing operations teams are equally effective with their strategies and management capabilities as Summer's character in \"School of Rock.\" With her processes, the group was able to obtain their own rehearsal space and offer music classes.</p> \n<h2>Align and Optimize Your Marketing Operations</h2> \n<p>Marketing ops can come up with ways to increase customer satisfaction and ease the job of marketers. Their strategies make marketing activities and duties accessible to all, and because of that, are an essential part of a business.</p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=2f598dfb-38e3-4e7b-a962-57cf6aebd7d7&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; \" alt=\"New Call-to-action\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/2f598dfb-38e3-4e7b-a962-57cf6aebd7d7.png\"></a></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmarketing-operations&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 09 Mar 2022 12:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/34155d81-37a6-4910-a596-3a77b9e5a99f.png","linkMd5":"0aa7014dbe6c5f0e4050c8dfa3994b13","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn64@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-26-48-401_d4993499845f294a.webp","destWidth":492,"destHeight":59,"sourceBytes":5749,"destBytes":7772,"author":"Kayla Carmicheal","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/34155d81-37a6-4910-a596-3a77b9e5a99f.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn64@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-26-48-401_d4993499845f294a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Everything%20You%20Need%20to%20Know%20About%20Marketing%20Operations%20in%20One%20Place.png?width=624&height=624&name=Everything%20You%20Need%20to%20Know%20About%20Marketing%20Operations%20in%20One%20Place.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn52@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-26-49-724_dce62d7bc9c727c2.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/2f598dfb-38e3-4e7b-a962-57cf6aebd7d7.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn4@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-26-54-121_cbc16368967d0eb0.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmarketing-operations&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn25@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-26-56-673_585b9b3c5a2805b7.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647246408199},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:26:48","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:26:48","title":"SEO vs. PPC: When to Optimize and When to Pay for Traffic","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/tabid/6307/bid/1514/paid-search-vs-organic-search.aspx","description":"<p>If you're struggling to get the word out about your brand new business venture, you’re not alone. Like you, many business owners struggle to acquire customers in the beginning.Balancing the cost, maintenance, and results of a marketing campaign isn't easy. Most of the time, the solution to this problem is one of two marketing strategies: <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/blog-search-engine-optimization?__hstc=45788219.ca6fa96b1444ad1af0b0b1debe5f22a0.1621995985031.1621995985031.1621995985031.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1621995985031&amp;__hsfp=2831226065&amp;_ga=2.61221103.2124293733.1621995984-1118394532.1621995984\">search engine optimization (SEO)</a> or <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ppc?__hstc=45788219.ca6fa96b1444ad1af0b0b1debe5f22a0.1621995985031.1621995985031.1621995985031.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1621995985031&amp;__hsfp=2831226065&amp;_ga=2.61221103.2124293733.1621995984-1118394532.1621995984\">pay-per-click (PPC)</a> campaigns. But which method is suitable for you?</p> \n<a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=3d0bc27a-898d-40d5-aa46-8696ed81c4ee&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"Download Now: HubSpot's Annual State of Marketing Report\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/3d0bc27a-898d-40d5-aa46-8696ed81c4ee.png\" align=\"middle\"></a> \n<p>In this article, we've explored what you can expect to achieve from each of these acquisition strategies. We’ve also provided some pros and cons of SEO and PPC strategies along with descriptive statistics and real-life examples to help you decide whether your business is best suited for SEO or PPC — or both.</p> \n<h2>What is SEO?</h2> \n<p>Search engine optimization is the process of enhancing your website’s visibility to make it rank and gain organic traffic from search engines.</p> \n<p>Just as you turn to your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/top-search-engines?__hstc=45788219.ca6fa96b1444ad1af0b0b1debe5f22a0.1621995985031.1621995985031.1621995985031.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1621995985031&amp;__hsfp=2831226065&amp;_ga=2.61221103.2124293733.1621995984-1118394532.1621995984\">favorite search engines</a>, such as Google or Bing, to look up a new marketing acronym or where to get good pizza, so do your consumers. When you invest in SEO, you're increasing the likelihood of your target audience finding you when they make a Google search for keywords related to your product or service. In fact, 61% of marketers say that <a href=\"https://www.impactplus.com/blog/seo-statistics\">SEO is a top inbound marketing factor</a> for their business. But it's easier said than done.</p> \n<p>Here's an example of SEO in action.</p> \n<p>In the image below, Hubspot appears at the top of Google’s organic search engine results page (SERP) for the term “inbound marketing,” thanks to the SEO strategy we have in place.</p> \n<p><img alt=\"SEO example of HubSpot ranking for &quot;inbound&quot; marketing&quot;\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/SEO%20vs.%20PPC%20When%20to%20Optimize%20and%20When%20to%20Pay%20for%20Traffic.png?width=650&amp;name=SEO%20vs.%20PPC%20When%20to%20Optimize%20and%20When%20to%20Pay%20for%20Traffic.png\" title=\"\" width=\"650\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\"></p> \n<p>The order of the results that appear on the search engine results page isn't arbitrary. Each search engine takes into account several ranking factors that influence where a webpage gets placed. The goal of an SEO strategy is to create web pages and content that work with the ranking factors of the search engine in order to rise within the SERP rankings.</p> \n<h4>Are there other search engines besides Google?</h4> \n<p>Most SEO strategies center around Google instead of others like Bing and Yahoo! because it holds <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/216573/worldwide-market-share-of-search-engines/#:~:text=Global%20market%20share%20of%20search%20engines%202010%2D2021&amp;text=Ever%20since%20the%20introduction%20of,share%20as%20of%20June%202021.\">92.47%</a> of the search engine market share. Because of this, you’ll need to learn about <a href=\"https://backlinko.com/google-ranking-factors\">Google’s 200 ranking factors</a>, technical SEO, <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/lessons/link-building-tutorial?__hstc=45788219.ca6fa96b1444ad1af0b0b1debe5f22a0.1621995985031.1621995985031.1621995985031.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1621995985031&amp;__hsfp=2831226065&amp;_ga=2.31360252.2124293733.1621995984-1118394532.1621995984\">link building</a>, content creation, and so much more if you want to appear higher up on the search engine results page.</p> \n<h3>Pros of SEO</h3> \n<p>Here are some advantages of SEO:</p> \n<h4>1. SEO is cheaper in the long run.</h4> \n<p>Although SEO might cost time and money —to pay freelancers or agencies, and for SEO tools — it’s still cheaper than PPC in the long run.</p> \n<p>When you create content that ranks and drives traffic to your website, you no longer have to keep spending money to make your target customers see it. And when these customers decide to click on your link, it comes at zero cost, unlike a PPC campaign where you pay per click.</p> \n<p>Organic traffic is also very scalable and cost-effective.</p> \n<h4>2. You can target different funnel stages with SEO.</h4> \n<p>Not all of your audience is at the same stage of the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/sales-funnel?__hstc=45788219.ca6fa96b1444ad1af0b0b1debe5f22a0.1621995985031.1621995985031.1621995985031.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1621995985031&amp;__hsfp=2831226065\">sales funnel</a>.</p> \n<p>Some are just getting to know your brand at the top of the funnel. And others are already at the bottom of the funnel, ready to pull out their wallets.</p> \n<p>With SEO, you can create different content types (blog posts, guides, case studies) that meet each segment of your audience exactly where they are in the sales funnel. This gives your site a better shot at getting visitors to the next step in the funnel each time they browse your content.</p> \n<h4>3. Search traffic is more stable.</h4> \n<p>Once you rank on Google, you can begin to plan for and predict free traffic to your website as long as you keep optimizing it.</p> \n<p>Another advantage to keep in mind is that there is no off-and-on switch with SEO. With PPC marketing, your website stops appearing on search results once your marketing budget dries up. A great way to remember this difference is by thinking in terms of real estate: SEO is like owning your traffic whereas PPC is like renting it.</p> \n<h4>4. Organic listings build brand authority.</h4> \n<p>Appearing consistently on search results for keywords related to your products and services helps build trust and brand authority with your target audience.</p> \n<p>It also signifies to Google that you’re an expert on that topic or subject. This can lead to more backlinks from other trusted sites which is a ranking factor that search engines favor strongly.</p> \n<h3>Cons of SEO</h3> \n<p>Here are some reasons why you might not love SEO:</p> \n<h4>1. Search engine algorithms change.</h4> \n<p>Search engines, especially Google, have <a href=\"https://www.searchenginejournal.com/google-algorithm-history/\">changed their algorithms</a> many times over the years. These changes mean that you’ll have to keep a close eye on your marketing strategy and organic results.</p> \n<h4>2. You’ll need to optimize your website regularly.</h4> \n<p>Your job doesn’t end when you get your website to rank for target keywords for one month. Over time, you’ll have to regularly optimize your content and web pages so that your site continues to rank.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/historical-blog-seo-conversion-optimization\">Optimization</a> might include refreshing old articles and removing old/expired links.</p> \n<h4>3. SEO takes time to show results.</h4> \n<p>If your website or domain is new, it’s unlikely that you’ll enjoy immediate results from SEO. The reason is that several factors affect how Google ranks websites — many of which won't be established within the first few weeks or months of launching your site.</p> \n<h4>2. It requires high-level skills and expertise.</h4> \n<p>If you’re not hiring a professional, make sure you understand your audience's goals and meet them with quality content in order to optimize your site properly for the search engines.</p> \n<p>It’s undoubtedly time-consuming and overwhelming to run a business while taking <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/results?q=seo&amp;library=true&amp;_ga=2.11489021.830295185.1621993439-1955934222.1621993439&amp;__hstc=45788219.ca6fa96b1444ad1af0b0b1debe5f22a0.1621995985031.1621995985031.1621995985031.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1621995985031&amp;__hsfp=2831226065\">technical SEO</a>, writing, and link-building classes, but it can be done if you commit to using an SEO strategy to generate revenue.</p> \n<h2>What is PPC?</h2> \n<p>PPC, or <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ppc?_ga=2.11489021.830295185.1621993439-1955934222.1621993439\">pay-per-click</a>, is a form of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/search-engine-marketing\">search engine marketing</a> (SEM) where an advertiser pays a publisher (such as Google or Facebook) for each click someone makes on an ad. This model allows businesses to pay only when consumers interact with their ads. If you use PPC ads, you'll attract people who are interested in your offer and ready to convert.</p> \n<p>You may have noticed that some of the top search results are tagged with an \"Ad\" marker, like the HelloFresh search results here. <img alt=\"Example of PPC search result for &quot;hellofresh&quot;\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/SEO%20vs.%20PPC%20When%20to%20Optimize%20and%20When%20to%20Pay%20for%20Traffic-2.png?width=650&amp;name=SEO%20vs.%20PPC%20When%20to%20Optimize%20and%20When%20to%20Pay%20for%20Traffic-2.png\" title=\"\" width=\"650\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\"></p> \n<p>PPC ads always appear alongside organic search results. Some businesses run these search ads for specific marketing campaigns that have a definite start and end date. Others bid on their own brand name as part of their overall marketing strategy — like HelloFresh. Either way, this method is mainly associated with search engines as advertisers bid on keywords that are relevant to their target markets.</p> \n<p>The cost of PPC ads usually depends on your industry and the search volume of the keyword you’re targeting.</p> \n<p>PPC advertising can help your business stay competitive in a crowded market and quickly get in front of their target consumers if you don’t have the domain authority to get your site ranking organically on search engines.</p> \n<h3>Pros of PPC</h3> \n<h4>1. PPC offers quick results.</h4> \n<p>While it can take months to see results from your SEO strategy, it can take just a few hours to see results from your PPC campaign.</p> \n<h4>2. PPC ads appear above organic rankings.</h4> \n<p>When you run a PPC campaign for your target keyword, your website would appear first on the search engine result page. This ranking makes your audience notice you first before scrolling to see other results.</p> \n<h4>3. PPC allows you to pinpoint your target audience.</h4> \n<p>While setting up a PPC campaign, you get to choose who you want to target with your ads.</p> \n<p>Do you want people from a specific geographic area? Or people of a particular age? Marital status? Or interest? If so, then you should use PPC.</p> \n<h4>3. You can quickly run A/B tests on a PPC ad.</h4> \n<p>With a PPC campaign, you can run two different ads simultaneously to measure the one that converts better.</p> \n<p>All you’ll have to do is change some ad elements like the ad copy and allow them to run for a period. Depending on the performance, you can decide to either “kill” the Google ads or continue optimization to improve your results.</p> \n<h3>Cons of PPC</h3> \n<h4>1. PPC ads are expensive.</h4> \n<p>Without money, you cannot run a PPC campaign.</p> \n<p>You have to pay for every link that your audience clicks, meaning once your budget dries up, so does your traffic.</p> \n<p>Also, a PPC ad can get even more expensive (as high as $40) when you’re in a competitive industry like legal or insurance.</p> \n<h4>2. Lower profit margins.</h4> \n<p>While a PPC campaign might bring short-term wins, it’ll usually result in lower profit margins. Because PPC is a “pay to play” system, your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/what-does-cac-stand-for?_ga=2.243230795.830295185.1621993439-1955934222.1621993439\">customer acquisition costs</a> (CAC) would continue to get higher without a significant increase in the prices of your products and services.</p> \n<h4>3. PPC ads become stale after a while.</h4> \n<p>You have limited control over your paid ad because of the rule set by ad platforms like Google. As such, your copy might have similar wording to your competitors, which makes it easy for your audience to pass over quickly.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>SEO is also more effective for local searches and can grow your online presence for longer. Pay-per-click (PPC), on the other hand, is an acquisition strategy that requires you to spend ad money to get your content in front of an audience when they search for specific keywords online.</p> \n<h3>SEO vs. PPC: Which is better?</h3> \n<p>Asking which is better between SEO and PPC is like asking whether it’s better to eat with a fork or spoon — it depends.</p> \n<p>Serving pasta? Sure, I’d love a fork. Soup? I’d rather have a spoon.</p> \n<p>In the same way, different situations exist where SEO is better than PPC and vice versa.</p> \n<p>Let’s now look at some of these situations.</p> \n<h4>Use SEO if...</h4> \n<ul> \n <li>Your marketing budget is low.</li> \n <li>You want to build your brand authority.</li> \n <li>You’re looking to maximize your long-term return-on-investment (ROI).</li> \n <li>You want to create content that reaches your audience at different stages of the sales funnel.</li> \n</ul> \n<h4>Use PPC if...</h4> \n<p>You’d get better results with PPC in situations where:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>You want quick results.</li> \n <li>Your product is novel or first-of-its-kind.</li> \n <li>You’re promoting a time-sensitive offer, like a holiday sale.</li> \n <li>You want to direct your audience to a sales or landing page.</li> \n</ul> \n<h2>How to Make SEO and PPC Work For You</h2> \n<p>Instead of choosing between SEO or PPC, why not combine the two strategies and make them work for you?</p> \n<p>Here’s how you can get the best of both worlds.</p> \n<h3>1. Create retargeting ads.</h3> \n<p><img alt=\"Retargeting ads example featuring Birchbox\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/SEO%20vs.%20PPC%20When%20to%20Optimize%20and%20When%20to%20Pay%20for%20Traffic-1.png?width=650&amp;name=SEO%20vs.%20PPC%20When%20to%20Optimize%20and%20When%20to%20Pay%20for%20Traffic-1.png\" title=\"\" width=\"650\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://www.bluecorona.com/blog/how-remarketing-works/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Did someone visit your site, probably the pricing or check-out page, without buying?</p> \n<p>You can easily use a retargeting ad to prompt these visitors, even after they’ve left your site, to come back and make a purchase.</p> \n<h3>2. Promote website content with social media ads.</h3> \n<p><img alt=\"social media ads example featuring dollar shave club\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/SEO%20vs.%20PPC%20When%20to%20Optimize%20and%20When%20to%20Pay%20for%20Traffic-3.png?width=300&amp;name=SEO%20vs.%20PPC%20When%20to%20Optimize%20and%20When%20to%20Pay%20for%20Traffic-3.png\" title=\"\" width=\"300\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 300px;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://sproutsocial.com/insights/facebook-ad-examples/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>While you want your content to rank organically, you can give it a quick boost by promoting it on social media.</p> \n<p>Not only do these kinds of ads help with <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-distribution?__hstc=45788219.ca6fa96b1444ad1af0b0b1debe5f22a0.1621995985031.1621995985031.1621995985031.1&amp;__hssc=45788219.1.1621995985031&amp;__hsfp=2831226065&amp;_ga=2.31360252.2124293733.1621995984-1118394532.1621995984\">content distribution</a>, but they could potentially help you acquire essential backlinks that’d boost your rankings.</p> \n<p>Also, it’s going to be a shame not to promote your latest blog post, guide, report, or case study after spending hours creating it.</p> \n<h3>3. Collect data From ads to improve your SEO strategy.</h3> \n<p>PPC campaigns grant you access to a lot of data — keyword search volumes, keywords your competitors are bidding for, highest converting calls-to-action, and so on.</p> \n<p>Aimed with all of this data, you’d be able to create better SEO strategies with less effort.</p> \n<h2>SEO vs. PPC Statistics</h2> \n<h3>SEO</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>Google is responsible for over <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/216573/worldwide-market-share-of-search-engines/#:~:text=Google%20has%20dominated%20the%20search,share%20as%20of%20June%202021.\">92.47%</a> of global web traffic.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://ahrefs.com/blog/search-traffic-study/\">90.63%</a> of online content gets zero traffic from Google, with only 0.21% getting over 1000 visits per month.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://sparktoro.com/blog/in-2020-two-thirds-of-google-searches-ended-without-a-click/\">35.18%</a> of browser-based Google searches resulted in an organic link click in 2020.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://ahrefs.com/blog/search-traffic-study/\">99.2%</a> of website pages have less than 100 backlinks.</li> \n <li>Google processes over <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-search-statistics\">5.6 billion</a> searches per day (or 2 trillion searches per year.)</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing/seo-trends?_ga=2.47785070.830295185.1621993439-1955934222.1621993439&amp;hubs_post=blog.hubspot.com/marketing/tabid/6307/bid/1514/paid-search-vs-organic-search.aspx&amp;hubs_post-cta=64%25\">64%</a> of marketers actively invest in SEO.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>PPC</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>The Google Display Network reaches <a href=\"https://ads.google.com/intl/en_ng/home/campaigns/display-ads/#:~:text=Display%20ads%20can%20help%20you,sites%20like%20Gmail%20and%20YouTube.\">90%</a> of Internet users worldwide.</li> \n <li>Search advertising spending was <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/276671/global-internet-advertising-expenditure-by-type/#:~:text=In%202021%2C%20search%20advertising%20spending,billion%20U.S.%20dollars%20by%202022.\">$144.8 billion</a> in 2021, compared to <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/topics/4312/search-advertising/\">$58 billion</a> in 2020.</li> \n <li>More than <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/435252/adblock-users-worldwide/\">https://backlinko.com/ad-blockers-users</a>.</li> \n <li>The highest average monthly cost-per-click (CPC) in Google Ads search advertising is in the insurance industry at <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/1115432/us-search-advertising-cpc/\">$18.57 per click</a>.</li> \n <li>The cheapest CPC in Google Ads search advertising is in the electronics industry at <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/1115432/us-search-advertising-cpc/\">77 cents per click</a>.</li> \n <li>The average Facebook Ads Click-Through Rate across all industries is <a href=\"https://www.thedrum.com/profile/whatagraph/news/facebook-ctr-and-how-to-increase-it#:~:text=The%20average%20Facebook%20Ads%20click,is%20different%20for%20every%20industry.\">1.1%</a>.</li> \n</ul> \n<h2>Final Thoughts</h2> \n<p>Whether you choose to go with SEO or PPC ultimately depends on your business situation. So take your time to evaluate the pros and cons of both SEO and PPC to see which is the right fit for you. And if possible, integrate the two strategies to see even more outstanding results for your business.</p> \n<p>Editor's note: This post was originally published in July 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in July 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" .hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn52@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-26-50-135_ef864c5b92a25966.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647246408229},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:26:48","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:26:48","title":"How to Write a Great Value Proposition [5 Top Examples + Template]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/write-value-proposition","description":"<p>Your company’s value proposition is the core of your competitive advantage. It clearly articulates why someone would want to buy from your company instead of a competitor.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>So how do you actually write a value proposition statement that's strong enough to lift conversion rates and sales? In this article, you’ll learn the definition of a value proposition, what a value prop isn't, examples of some of the best value props we’ve seen, and tactics to create amazing value props.</p> \n<a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=99cdb31b-6412-4e6a-a1f4-86fd92d432fa&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img \" style=\"border-width: 0px; /*hs-extra-styles*/; margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px\" alt=\"→ Download Now: 15 Free Value Proposition Templates\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/99cdb31b-6412-4e6a-a1f4-86fd92d432fa.png\" align=\"middle\" /></a> \n<span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; font-weight: 400;\">We’ll cover:</span> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/write-value-proposition#value-proposition-definition\">What is a value proposition?</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/write-value-proposition#value-proposition-vs-mission-statement\">Value Proposition vs Mission Statement (vs Others)</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/write-value-proposition#value-proposition-canvas\">How to Create a Value Proposition Canvas</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/write-value-proposition#value-proposition-elements\">Elements of a Value Proposition</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/write-value-proposition#value-proposition-templates\">Value Proposition Templates</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/write-value-proposition#value-proposition-examples\">Value Proposition Examples</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/write-value-proposition#how-to-write-value-proposition\">How to Write a Value Proposition</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/write-value-proposition#value-proposition-tactics\">Tactics to Develop an Effective Value Proposition</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/write-value-proposition#what-makes-good-value-proposition\">Let’s summarize: What makes a good value prop?</a></li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<p>Ready to dive in?</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Value propositions are one of the most important conversion factors. A great value proposition could be the difference between losing a sale — and closing it.</p> \n<p>For that reason, it’s important to create one that accurately represents your products and services and makes it clear why you’re the best choice. However, writing it from scratch is hard. Download our templates below so you can follow along with the rest of the post.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Your value proposition is a unique identifier for your business. Without it, buyers won’t have a reason to purchase what you sell. They may even choose a competitor simply because that business communicates its value proposition clearly in its <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/marketing-campaigns\">marketing campaigns</a> and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/sales-process-\">sales process</a>.</p> \n<p>That said, you might think: <em>Isn’t my value prop interchangeable with, say, my slogan?</em></p> \n<p>Nope. It’s easy to confuse your value proposition with other similar <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-are-brand-assets\">brand assets</a>, such as your mission statement, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/brand-slogans-and-taglines\">slogan</a>, or tagline. We break down the differences below.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Value Proposition vs Mission Statement</h2> \n<p>Your value proposition details what you offer customers and why they should choose you, while a mission statement details your objective as an organization. While the two can have points in common, a value prop is more product- and service-oriented while a mission statement is more goal-oriented.</p> \n<p>Here are two examples for HubSpot and our CRM platform:</p> \n<p><strong>Value Proposition:</strong> “An easy-to-use CRM.”</p> \n<p><strong>Mission Statement:</strong> “To help businesses grow better.”</p> \n<h3>Value Proposition vs Slogan</h3> \n<p>A slogan is a short, catchy statement that brands use in marketing campaigns to sell a specific product. While your value proposition wouldn’t necessarily go in an ad (at least, not usually), a slogan would. The most important thing to note is that a company can have different slogans for different campaigns or products.</p> \n<p>Here are two examples from De Beers Group:</p> \n<p><strong>Value Proposition:</strong> “Exquisite diamonds, world-class designs, breathtaking jewelry.”</p> \n<p><strong>Slogan</strong>: “A diamond is forever.”</p> \n<h3>Value Proposition vs Tagline</h3> \n<p>A tagline is a short statement that embodies a certain aspect of your brand or business. While a value proposition is more concrete, a tagline can represent a concept or idea that your business stands for. Most businesses have only one tagline that is instantly recognizable and connected to their brand.</p> \n<p>Here’s an example from Apple:</p> \n<p><strong>Value Proposition</strong>: “The best experiences. Only on Apple.”</p> \n<p><strong>Tagline</strong>: “Think Different.”</p> \n<h3>Value Proposition vs Mission Statement vs Slogan vs Tagline</h3> \n<p>Now, let’s look at an example of a business that has all four: Nike. Remember that slogans can differ depending on the campaign.</p> \n<p><strong>Value Proposition</strong>: “Customizable performance or lifestyle sneakers with unique colorways and materials.”</p> \n<p><strong>Mission Statement:</strong> “To bring inspiration and innovation to every athlete in the world.”</p> \n<p><strong>Slogan</strong>: “Twice the guts. Double the glory.”</p> \n<p><strong>Tagline</strong>: “Just do it.”</p> \n<p>TLDR; While your value prop should help differentiate you from the rest of the industry, keep in mind it's not a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/brand-slogans-and-taglines\">slogan</a>, tagline, or mission statement. Those types of copy are important accessories to your brand, but your potential customers and employees don't choose one business over the other solely based on these elements.</p> \n<p>Your value proposition goes deep into the problems you want to solve for buyers, and what makes your product or service the perfect solution.</p> \n<p>Now, before you write the statement itself, it’s important to create a value proposition canvas.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p>Taking these three elements into consideration, you'll be able to make your own after you build a value proposition canvas.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p><img alt=\"Value Proposition Canvas Visual\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Write%20a%20Great%20Value%20Proposition%20%5B4%20Top%20Examples%20+%20Template%5D-3.png?width=650&amp;name=How%20to%20Write%20a%20Great%20Value%20Proposition%20%5B4%20Top%20Examples%20+%20Template%5D-3.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\" title=\"\" width=\"650\" /></p> \n<p>The value proposition canvas is made up of two major components: the customer profile and the value map.</p> \n<p>Here’s how to make one:</p> \n<h3>Step 1: Create a customer profile to represent your target buyer.</h3> \n<p>The customer profile makes up the first half of the value proposition canvas. When performing this exercise, you’ll want to start with this section first so that their wants and needs can influence the overall value proposition canvas.</p> \n<p>The customer profile consists of three areas:</p> \n<h4>Customer Jobs</h4> \n<p>What is the task your customer needs to complete or the problem they’re trying to solve with your product or service? The answer to this question sums up the “customer job” or the purpose of your product or service in the eyes of the customer.</p> \n<h4>Customer Expectations</h4> \n<p>“Expectations” are also referred to as “gains” — in other words, what your customer is hoping to gain from doing business with you. No matter what you sell, your ideal customer will have an expectation of what that product or service will do for them. In this section, you’ll use research to explain what your customers expect from you in order to purchase your product.</p> \n<h4>Customer Pain Points</h4> \n<p>As your customer completes their “customer job,” what pains do they experience? Do they take any risks while they do the customer’s job? Do they experience any negative emotions? These pain points should be considered so that you include the most helpful products and services on the value map side of the value proposition canvas.</p> \n<h3>Step 2: Create a value map for your products and services.</h3> \n<p>In this section of the value proposition canvas, three specific sectors help describe what the business offers to the customer.</p> \n<h4>Gain Creators</h4> \n<p>These are features your products or services have that make the customer happy. Think creatively about the elements of happiness your customers experience. Consider their financial and social goals as well as their <a href=\"https://cxl.com/blog/psychographics/\">psychographics</a>.</p> \n<h4>Pain Relievers</h4> \n<p>In the section above, we discussed customer pains. This section will define exactly how your business will help them overcome those pain points.</p> \n<h4>Products &amp; Services</h4> \n<p>While this section won’t list every single product or service your company offers, it should include the ones that will create the most gain and alleviate the most pains for your customers.</p> \n<h3>Step 3: Determine value proposition-customer fit.</h3> \n<p>Once you’ve completed the value proposition canvas exercise, the next step will be to determine how your value proposition fits within the customer profile. To do this, you’ll use a ranking process that prioritizes products and services based on how well they address the customer profile.</p> \n<p>All together, your value proposition canvas should look like this:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/value-proposition-canvas-example.png?width=650&amp;name=value-proposition-canvas-example.png\" alt=\"value proposition canvas example \" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<p>Next up, let’s go over the elements you should include in your value proposition when you’re creating it and publishing it on your website.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Elements of a Value Proposition</h2> \n<p>Your value proposition will most often appear on your website. While you can include it on marketing campaigns and brochures, the most visible place is your home page and, if you’d like, your product pages.</p> \n<p>There are three main elements of a value proposition: the headline, the subheadline, and a visual element.</p> \n<h3 style=\"color: #434343; font-size: 14px;\"><img alt=\"The elements of a value proposition\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Write%20a%20Great%20Value%20Proposition%20%5B4%20Top%20Examples%20+%20Template%5D-Oct-01-2021-04-55-04-13-PM.png?width=650&amp;name=How%20to%20Write%20a%20Great%20Value%20Proposition%20%5B4%20Top%20Examples%20+%20Template%5D-Oct-01-2021-04-55-04-13-PM.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\" title=\"\" width=\"650\" /></h3> \n<h3>Headline</h3> \n<p>The headline of your value proposition describes the benefit the customer will receive as a result of making a purchase from your business. The headline can be creative and catchy, but it should be clear and concise, first and foremost.</p> \n<h3>Subheadline or Paragraph</h3> \n<p>The subheadline or paragraph should explain in detail what your company offers, who it serves, and why. In this section, you can elaborate on the information in the headline.</p> \n<h3>Visual Element</h3> \n<p>In some cases, a video, infographic, or image may convey your value proposition better than words alone can. Enhance your message with these visual elements to capture your audience’s attention.</p> \n<p>To better visualize these tools, here are a couple templates to follow when formatting a value proposition.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Value Proposition Templates</h2> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/value-proposition-templates?hubs_post-cta=image\"><img alt=\"hubspot 15 free value proposition templates\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Write%20a%20Great%20Value%20Proposition%20%5B4%20Top%20Examples%20+%20Template%5D.png?width=624&amp;height=624&amp;name=How%20to%20Write%20a%20Great%20Value%20Proposition%20%5B4%20Top%20Examples%20+%20Template%5D.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" title=\"\" width=\"624\" height=\"624\" /></a><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/value-proposition-templates?hubs_post-cta=imagebottom\">Download for Free</a></p> \n<p>We've crafted 15 templates to help you create an amazing value proposition for your brand — and pairing each of them with an example of how they may look for a real business. <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/value-proposition-templates?hubs_post-cta=body&amp;hubs_post=blog.hubspot.com/marketing/write-value-proposition\">Click here</a> to download these free value proposition templates for your business.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p>Now that we’ve reviewed the elements, visual tools, and templates — let’s look at some brand examples that effectively identify and satisfy its customer needs.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Because value propositions are typically internal information and rarely stated publicly, finding a value proposition example to model yours after can be difficult. We’ve taken the liberty of using the value proposition canvas and applying it to some successful companies that have been recognized by the <a href=\"https://www.theacsi.org/\">American Customer Satisfaction Index</a> (ASCI).</p> \n<p>In these examples, you’ll see real-world instances of customer gains and pains aligned with well-known products and services offered by these companies.</p> \n<h3>1. HubSpot: \"An easy-to-use CRM.\"</h3> \n<p><strong>Headline</strong>: \"An easy-to-use CRM.\"&nbsp;</p> \n<p><strong>Subheadline/Paragraph</strong>: \"HubSpot’s CRM platform has all the tools and integrations you need for marketing, sales, content management, and customer service.\"</p> \n<p><strong>Visual Element</strong>:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/value-proposition-example-hubspot.jpeg?width=650&amp;name=value-proposition-example-hubspot.jpeg\" alt=\"value proposition example: hubspot\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<p>Most companies can benefit from using a CRM — even freelance businesses and small family-owned firms. The problem is that most systems are over-complicated and cobbled together, not to mention expensive.</p> \n<p>HubSpot’s value proposition aims to target active CRM users who are tired of handling over-complicated systems, and beginners who are intimidated by legacy options. To that end, the product’s value proposition emphasizes its ease-of-use and ability to synchronize different teams across the business. The brand includes an image of a smiling woman to show what it would be like to use the product in your team (hint: it’s so easy, it’ll make you smile).</p> \n<h4>HubSpot Value Proposition Canvas</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/value-proposition-canvas-example.png?width=650&amp;name=value-proposition-canvas-example.png\" alt=\"value proposition canvas example: hubspot\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<h5>Customer Profile</h5> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Customer Jobs</strong>: HubSpot customers need to effectively enable their sales teams to do their best work while avoiding complicated workflows.</li> \n <li><strong>Gains</strong>: Customers want to increase their sales rep productivity levels and boost sales.</li> \n <li><strong>Pains</strong>: There are plenty of CRM options, but they’re often overcomplicated and create silos.</li> \n</ul> \n<h5>Value Map</h5> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Gain Creators</strong>: The HubSpot CRM platform offers streamlined contact management software and productivity tools that will help sales teams do their best work.</li> \n <li><strong>Pain Relievers</strong>: The user-friendly interface and unified platform offers ease-of-use and high visibility across systems.</li> \n <li><strong>Products &amp; Services</strong>: The HubSpot CRM platform includes Sales Hub, an enterprise-level sales software that’s simple yet powerful enough to cater to the needs of businesses small and large.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>2. FedEx: \"Manage your Home Deliveries\"</h3> \n<p><strong>Headline:</strong> \"Manage Your Home Deliveries\"</p> \n<p><strong>Subheadline/Paragraph:</strong> Sending and receiving packages is convenient and safe for individuals who want to ship ideas and innovations across the globe.</p> \n<p><strong>Visual Element:</strong></p> \n<p><img alt=\"value proposition examples: FedEx\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Write%20a%20Great%20Value%20Proposition%20%5B4%20Top%20Examples%20+%20Template%5D-1.png?width=650&amp;name=How%20to%20Write%20a%20Great%20Value%20Proposition%20%5B4%20Top%20Examples%20+%20Template%5D-1.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\" title=\"\" width=\"650\" /></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 13px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://www.fedex.com/en-us/home.html\" style=\"font-style: italic; text-decoration: underline;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>If you own a business, shipping and packaging prpoducts is likely a significant part of your operations, but it can be a time-consuming, labor-intensive, and plain inconvenient process. If you’re a consumer, you’ve likely experienced driving to a shipping office to get your package after a missed delivery. Both of these are significant pain points for FedEx’s target customers.</p> \n<p>FedEx’s value proposition makes it clear that it will make managing your deliveries much, much easier — whether you’re a business or a consumer.</p> \n<h4>FedEx Value Proposition Canvas</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/value-proposition-canvas-example-fedex.png?width=650&amp;name=value-proposition-canvas-example-fedex.png\" alt=\"value proposition canvas example: fedex\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<h5>Customer Profile</h5> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Customer Jobs: </strong>FedEx customers want to share ideas and innovations with other individuals by shipping goods around the world.</li> \n <li><strong>Gains:</strong> Customers want a hassle-free way to return online orders and are looking for a safe and secure way to receive their packages.</li> \n <li><strong>Pains: </strong>Returning a package at a FedEx shipping center can be inconvenient, and managing home deliveries can be a hassle.</li> \n</ul> \n<h5>Value Map</h5> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Gain Creators:</strong> Customers can drop off their FedEx packages at places they shop most like Walgreens or Dollar General, and have peace of mind knowing where their package is at all times.</li> \n <li><strong>Pain Relievers:</strong> Thousands of FedEx drop-off locations across the country, receive notifications when a package is en route and inform the driver where to leave the package.</li> \n <li><strong>Products &amp; Services:</strong> FedEx Drop Box locations make returning packages convenient, and the FedEx Delivery Manager reroutes or reschedules deliveries to work with the customer’s schedule.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>3. LG: \"State-of-the-art Living Experience\"</h3> \n<p><strong>Headline:</strong> \"State-of-the-art Living Experience\"</p> \n<p><strong>Subheadline/Paragraph:</strong> LG SIGNATURE delivers an innovative product design that creates an exceptional living experience for people who want to achieve a state-of-the-art living experience.</p> \n<p><strong>Visual Element:</strong></p> \n<p><img alt=\"value proposition examples: LG Signature\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Write%20a%20Great%20Value%20Proposition%20%5B4%20Top%20Examples%20+%20Template%5D-Oct-01-2021-04-55-03-23-PM.png?width=650&amp;name=How%20to%20Write%20a%20Great%20Value%20Proposition%20%5B4%20Top%20Examples%20+%20Template%5D-Oct-01-2021-04-55-03-23-PM.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\" title=\"\" width=\"650\" /></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 13px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://www.lg.com/us/lg-signature\" style=\"font-style: italic; text-decoration: underline;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>The right home appliances can make your at-home experience easy and hassle-free — or it can quickly create headaches with low power efficiency and outdated features. In its value proposition, LG targets customers who are willing to spend just a little more on the right appliance in exchange for a comfortable, hassle-free, and luxurious experience.</p> \n<p>Even the imagery helps you imagine what your life would be like after purchasing an LG appliance.</p> \n<h4>LG Value Proposition Canvas</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/value-proposition-canvas-example-LG.png?width=650&amp;name=value-proposition-canvas-example-LG.png\" alt=\"value proposition canvas example: lg\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<h5>Customer Profile</h5> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Customer Jobs:</strong> LG customers want simple, yet innovative technology that helps them achieve a state-of-the-art living experience.</li> \n <li><strong>Gains: </strong>Customers have an intuitive and responsive experience with each appliance they interact with inside their homes.</li> \n <li><strong>Pains:</strong> There are too many unnecessary buttons and features on appliances that get in the way of a simple living experience</li> \n</ul> \n<h5>Value Map</h5> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Gain Creators:</strong> Customers can use technology to enhance their home experience without needing to read a manual.</li> \n <li><strong>Pain Relievers:</strong> LG offers a simple design that focuses on the user and their lifestyle.</li> \n <li><strong>Products &amp; Services: </strong>LG SIGNATURE delivers an innovative product design that creates an exceptional living experience.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>4. Subaru: \"The most adventurous, most reliable, safest, best Subaru Outback ever.\"</h3> \n<p><strong>Headline:</strong> \"The most adventurous, most reliable, safest, best Subaru Outback ever.\"</p> \n<p><strong>Subheadline/paragraph:</strong> The 2022 Subaru Outback takes drivers to the most adventurous places in style with the most advanced safety technology.</p> \n<p><strong>Visual element:</strong></p> \n<p><img alt=\"value proposition examples: Subaru \" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Write%20a%20Great%20Value%20Proposition%20%5B4%20Top%20Examples%20+%20Template%5D-2.png?width=650&amp;name=How%20to%20Write%20a%20Great%20Value%20Proposition%20%5B4%20Top%20Examples%20+%20Template%5D-2.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\" title=\"\" width=\"650\" /></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 13px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://www.subaru.com/vehicles/outback/index.html\" style=\"font-style: italic; text-decoration: underline;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Subaru knows that its target audience uses its Outback SUVs for outdoor adventures. So in its value proposition, it makes it clear that the Outback will help its drivers go off the road safely and in style. Even more, it states as much right in the headline.</p> \n<p>If I were a potential Subaru customer, I’d know exactly what I’m getting from that headline alone. That’s why it’s so important to think about your wording, because it’s likely the first thing potential buyers will see.</p> \n<h4>Subaru Value Proposition Canvas</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/value-proposition-canvas-example-subaru.png?width=650&amp;name=value-proposition-canvas-example-subaru.png\" alt=\"value proposition canvas example: subaru\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<h5>Customer Profile</h5> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Customer Jobs: </strong>Subaru customers want to explore the world’s most adventurous places in a reliable and safe vehicle</li> \n <li><strong>Gains: </strong>Customers want to explore the land in a stylish and spacious SUV and look for advanced technological elements in their vehicles that enhance performance and safety</li> \n <li><strong>Pains:</strong> The safest vehicles are not the most visually appealing, and some SUVs aren’t equipped for all-weather or all-terrain environments</li> \n</ul> \n<h5>Value Map</h5> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Gain Creators:</strong> Subarus have a stylish exterior and interior with ample ground clearance that protects the vehicle against damage from the environment and advanced technology to reduce crashes and make long road trips safer.</li> \n <li><strong>Pain Relievers:</strong> Subarus have a rugged blacked-out trim for style and protection, 9.5-inch ground clearance for better stability and performance, and driver-assist technology that helps drivers see better, prevent crashes, manage cruise control, and brake automatically in emergency situations.</li> \n <li><strong>Products &amp; Services:</strong> The 2022 Subaru Outback with standard eyesight assist technology, automatic pre-collision braking, adaptive cruise control, and lane-centering.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>5. Samsung: \"Get Ready to Unfold Your World\"</h3> \n<p><strong>Headline:</strong> \"Get Ready to Unfold Your World\"</p> \n<p><strong>Subheadline/paragraph:</strong> This is everything you'd want in a premium, durable, 5G smartphone. Then we made it unfold — revealing a massive screen so you can watch, work and play like never before.</p> \n<p><strong>Visual element:</strong></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img alt=\"value proposition examples: Samsung Galaxy\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/How%20to%20Write%20a%20Great%20Value%20Proposition%20%5B4%20Top%20Examples%20+%20Template%5D-4.png?width=650&amp;name=How%20to%20Write%20a%20Great%20Value%20Proposition%20%5B4%20Top%20Examples%20+%20Template%5D-4.png\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; width: 650px;\" title=\"\" width=\"650\" /></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 13px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://www.samsung.com/us/smartphones/galaxy-z-fold3-5g/\" style=\"font-style: italic; text-decoration: underline;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>In its value proposition, Samsung effectively targets its most tech-savvy segment by front-lining its most innovative design to date: a foldable phone that can double as a mini-tablet. Even more, it solves a common pain point for some customers: owning both a tablet and a mobile device can feel unnecessary, so why not get the best of both worlds?</p> \n<p>Samsung’s value proposition for its foldable mobile device is smart, well-targeted, and visually stunning.</p> \n<h4>Samsung Value Proposition Canvas</h4> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/value-proposition-canvas-example-samsung.png?width=650&amp;name=value-proposition-canvas-example-samsung.png\" alt=\"value proposition canvas example: samsung\" width=\"650\" style=\"width: 650px;\" /></p> \n<h5>Customer Profile</h5> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Customer Jobs: </strong>Samsung customers are tech-savvy and follow the latest trends, driven by efficiency and aspirational lifestyles.</li> \n <li><strong>Gains: </strong>Customers want an all-in-one way to enjoy media, work productively, and have a fun experience all in the palm of their hands.</li> \n <li><strong>Pains:</strong> Common smartphones have size limitations that strain entertainment viewing, gameplay, and work capabilities.</li> \n</ul> \n<h5>Value Map</h5> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Gain Creators:</strong> Samsung offers a unique and expansive design with capabilities beyond that of an average smartphone, offering the most advanced technology to help customers perform tasks to fulfill work and play.</li> \n <li><strong>Pain Relievers: </strong>Samsung provides a smartphone that displays content in tablet-like viewing and displays up to three apps simultaneously.</li> \n <li><strong>Products &amp; Services:</strong>The Galaxy Z Fold3 5G folding 6.2-inch smartphone with dynamic AMOLED 2X screens, ultra-thin glass with S Penfold edition, and super-strong lightweight armor aluminum frame.</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<p>You’ve seen some brilliant value proposition examples, now let’s break down how to make your own.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>Step 1: Identify your customer's main problem.</h3> \n<p>While this will require some upfront research, you can get a head start on this aspect of the value proposition by speaking with different members of your team. Customer service reps, marketing specialists, and salespeople can fill in the gaps about what problems your customers are looking to solve by using your product or service.</p> \n<p>For example, let’s say your business sells tax software on a subscription basis and automated templates are included in the software package. Your ideal customer is looking for an affordable and user-friendly way to access complicated tax documents for their business. In this example, your business’s offerings could be the solution they need.</p> \n<h3>Step 2: Identify all the benefits your products offer.</h3> \n<p>This step can be as simple as listing out every product you sell and describing its primary benefit. The benefit should be concise and focused on a single customer need.</p> \n<p>In our tax software example, you’d list each tax template, explain the benefit it provides, and why a customer would need it.</p> \n<h3>Step 3: Describe what makes these benefits valuable.</h3> \n<p>Next, add another sentence that explains why this benefit matters to the customer.</p> \n<p>Using the same example above, the value would be that customers have affordable tax documentation at their fingertips — something that would normally cost them thousands of dollars.</p> \n<h3>Step 4: Connect this value to your buyer's problem.</h3> \n<p>Next, pair the buyer’s problem to the elements that make your product or service valuable. Do they align? If so, you’re ready to refine your value proposition to differentiate your offerings from the competition. If they don’t align, repeat the steps above until you find a valid buyer need and a viable solution your business offers to meet that need.</p> \n<p>There’re three templates we think do an excellent job of connecting value to buyer pain points:</p> \n<h3>Step 5: Differentiate yourself as the preferred provider of this value.</h3> \n<p>Finally, polish your value proposition to make it unique. Is there a specific customer service offering your business provides that others don’t? Do you offer any additional services that other companies charge for? These elements can help differentiate your value proposition from competitors while keeping the focus on the buyer’s needs.</p> \n<p>Once you understand these steps, you can easily implement them into value proposition templates as follows.</p> \n<h4>Value Proposition Templates</h4> \n<ul> \n <li> <h5><strong>Steve Blank Method</strong></h5> </li> \n</ul> \n<p>Instead of focusing on the features themselves, Blank saw the need to emphasize the benefits derived from the features in a simple sentence. By following this formula you’ll connect the target market and their pain points to the solution:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><em>“We help (X) do (Y) by doing (Z)”</em></p> \n<ul> \n <li> <h5><strong>Geoff Moore Method</strong></h5> </li> \n</ul> \n<p>Moore provides a template that’s more specific in identifying the industry categories alongside the benefits customers value. This makes a more clear value proposition formula as follows:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><em>“For [target customer] who [needs or wants X], our [product/service] is [category of industry] that [benefits]”</em></p> \n<ul> \n <li> <h5><strong>Harvard Business School Method</strong></h5> </li> \n</ul> \n<p>According to HBS a value proposition is executed best when it answers the following questions:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><em>What is my brand offering?</em></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><em>What job does the customer hire my brand to do?</em></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><em>What companies and products compete with my brand to do this job for the customer?</em></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><em>What sets my brand apart from competitors?</em></p> \n<a></a> \n<p>Now that we’ve gone through steps and templates to follow, there’s some tactics we think you should keep in mind.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>1. Conduct research to determine the value proposition of your competitors.</h3> \n<p>Because your value proposition is the differentiating factor between your business and the competition, it’s important to research the propositions of your closest competitors. You can use the value proposition canvas in this post to determine how each company meets the needs of your buyer persona.</p> \n<p>Be honest here — it’s tempting to focus on the areas in which your competition doesn’t excel, but you’ll have a better idea of where your product or service fits within the market if you key in on your competitors’ strengths.</p> \n<h3>2. Explain the value of your products and services.</h3> \n<p>You’re probably familiar with outlining the features and benefits of your product and service offerings. This tactic takes that concept a step further. By matching the benefits of your offerings to specific values that your customers have, you’ll be able to align what your business provides with what your customers need.</p> \n<h3>3. Describe the benefits your ideal customer will experience when they choose your product or service over the competition.</h3> \n<p>When crafting this part of your value proposition, include details about how your product or service will benefit the customer and use examples where you can. Videos, photos, and live demonstrations are all effective ways to illustrate your value proposition because they show the customer exactly what they can expect from your business.</p> \n<h3>4. Develop a unique value proposition for each buyer persona you serve.</h3> \n<p>Ideally, you’ll be focusing your marketing efforts on a specific target audience. You’ll also find that this audience will have different needs based on their buying behaviors. Buyer personas can help you segment your larger audience into groups of customers with similar desires, goals, pain points, and buying behaviors. As a result, you’ll need a unique value proposition for each persona. Different products and services you offer may solve certain <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/uncover-business-pain\">customer pain points</a> better than others, so developing a value proposition for each persona will better serve each one.</p> \n<h3>5. Test your value proposition with your audience using various marketing channels.</h3> \n<p>Each of these tactics will likely be developed internally by your team which means you’ll want to validate your work with your target audience. Your value proposition will be communicated through various marketing channels like your website, social media accounts, video, audio, and in person. Test your proposition with members of your audience (both existing customers and non-customers) using each of these channels. Tools like<a href=\"https://www.usertesting.com/\"> </a><a href=\"https://www.usertesting.com/\">UserTesting</a> can help you streamline this feedback process so that you can implement changes quickly to finalize your value proposition.</p> \n<p>We know the makings of a value proposition, so how can you make it a good one? Here’s the last three tips we have for you.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>What makes a good value proposition?</h2> \n<h3>Clear Language</h3> \n<p>Your value proposition should aim to address a primary customer need. This limited focus helps keep your value proposition clear and easy to understand. With just one main idea to comprehend, your audience will be able to quickly decide whether or not your product or service will be the best solution for them.</p> \n<h3>Specific Outcomes</h3> \n<p>Next, you’ll want to communicate the specific outcomes your customer can expect to receive from your product or service. Will they save time? Demonstrate how. Will their workflow become more manageable? Show a before and after workflow diagram. The specific outcomes will be critical components of your value proposition as they’ll exemplify exactly how your customers will use your solution to solve their problems.</p> \n<h3>Points of Differentiation</h3> \n<p>Not only are your potential customers evaluating your business’s offerings based on their own needs, but they’re also comparing what you offer against competitors. As a result, your value proposition will need to include detailed points of differentiation. These key points will help customers understand exactly what sets your company apart.</p> \n<h2>Compose a Remarkable Value Proposition</h2> \n<p>The factors that influence a potential customer to become a loyal customer are limited. Whether your industry has a lot of opportunities to differentiate (like retail) or virtually no unique identifiers (like dairy), you’ll find that a value proposition will help you understand your ideal customer and position your business as the best solution for their needs. Use the tactics, tips, framework, and examples in this post to craft your unique value proposition.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in June 2018 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p><a class=\"cta_button\" href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/cs/ci/?pg=512ec060-3806-4142-9fdd-160f6341ea4d&amp;pid=53&amp;ecid=&amp;hseid=&amp;hsic=\"><img
